Posts.Title: Update - Provenge Therapy Completed

Posts.Content: Hello Mom. Good news for dad is that he has been recurrence free for almost 3 years. I would agree with you that based on his PSA trend, sooner would be the choice. Must studies show early SRT to be most effective with a PSA of . 1 or lower. I am on my phone typing, but I will post the links tomorrow from work. For most men, SRT is not all that bad. U may get some bowel issues, but they don't last long. The hardest part will be getting the timing down to have a full bladder before each session. That can take a little practice, but with 37/38 treatments coming, you will need to get the hang of it. Most of the SE if you are going to have any will be long after SRT is over. Those would be potential urinary issues. For now move forward without delay for the best potential outcome. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Looks like dad's headed to salvage radiation. Your experiences appreciated!

Posts.Content: Hello Truckin: Welcome aboard, sorry that you find yourself here. I see where you are planning on surgery, and given the stats that u have listed, it looks like u have a excellent chance for a cure. All G6 and G7 (3+4) puts you in the low-intermediate risk group. Good to hear you are going to MDA, several guys here have had a positive experience there. ( also a major cancer center) Read Dr. Patrick Walsh's book ( 3rd edition) " surviving prostate cancer". Lots of good information and it will help you get a feel for what's ahead. Lots of peaks and valleys, but you will get thru it. The days pass quickly, and in no time you will be cancer free. Keep asking questions, and remember you are not alone. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Zero club membership renewal

Posts.Content: Vince: All of us like to say, " I am not a doctor" which is true. But I, for one, have learned just as much from this forum as I have when I go and visit my medical team. Not that they don't want to talk to me, they just don't have the time. They are great doctors, but busy. That being said, LVI is when the Pathologist looks under the microscope and sees cancer in the blood vessels leading to the lymph system. Another adverse pathology finding that one would rather not have. However, it's prognostic value is uncertain, and at times controversial. I would not worry to much about it for now. Focus on healing. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Researching Best Doctors in Illinois

Posts.Content: Hello h60.... my forum brothers have done a good job explaining your pathology report. Pt3a is not the news u want to hear, but G7 ( 3+4) is nothing to get concerned about. Your doctor has no idea if he got all the cancer out. He can guess, and that's about it. Your tested lymph nodes were negative, but you did have possible lymphatic invasion, which is just another adverse factor which would allow the cancer to get into your bloodstream or lymph system. There are conflicting views as to how serious a pathological feature this is. The good news is the rest of your report is fine. With only a G7 3/4.... even in a SRT situation I think u will be fine. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Gleason Score 7 - What Tx

Posts.Content: Wallart: Welcome to the forum. I feel for the situation both u and your husband find yourself in. Please pardon my straight talk. As I read your post, I can't help but just shake my head and wonder.....what in the world is going on!! The PSA numbers that you refer to should have been enough to alert any medical professional that action was/is required. Eight years ago his PSA was 32? And what did the doctor recommend? Waiting eight years? While a healthy diet surely can be of benefit, I can assure you that it will not cure any existing PCa. Honestly, after 10 years of sitting around doing nothing, your husband may qualify as a modern miracle. All that being said, it may not be to late. Take action NOW!! Psa numbers that high are not a good sign. Sorry to sound harsh. This is a forum of support and encouragement. So let me encourage you. If your husband does not take action, he may not have another 10 years to think about it. Keep us posted on his condition. If you act now, modern treatments could keep him alive for many years. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Ray

Posts.Content: Mike: Since you are currently on Casodex, and I assume the shot you will be receiving will be Lupron, you still have time to wait for the 3 month PSA. The ADT will stop the cancer in it's tracks while you heal. With a 1.1 at six weeks, it probably won't get much better to the point where it will change the course of your treatment. So hang in and heal, and then get the 3 month test. I am going to assume the ADT will start knocking your PSA down. But do not be misled, you still need the SRT to shoot for the cure, and it is still possible! Stay strong brother. MM

Posts.Title: Post Op 9 months Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Hello Cajun: Thank u for the information, your case has become a bit clearer. Basically, u are me! pt3bNO. Since u have not had any HT since the 30 days of casodex before your operation, we can assume that your numbers are not being "masked" by anything. For now, I would let myself heal as much as possible, and go along for as long as I can without additional treatment. ( u do not mention your continence or any ED issues) I would monitor my PSA every 8-12 weeks, and when it goes to 0.03 or greater, I would pull the trigger. Using the uPSA test, a reading of >0.03 for high risk people like yourself is very indicative of BCR. I would get all my ducks in a row, and be ready to act when your uPSA tells u to do so. Your PSA level will be the most important factor in determining the potential of the success with ADT/SRT. For now sit tight, but be on top of this every 8-12 weeks. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Hello h60.... my forum brothers have done a good job explaining your pathology report. Pt3a is not the news u want to hear, but G7 ( 3+4) is nothing to get concerned about. Your doctor has no idea if he got all the cancer out. He can guess, and that's about it. Your tested lymph nodes were negative, but you did have possible lymphatic invasion, which is just another adverse factor which would allow the cancer to get into your bloodstream or lymph system. There are conflicting views as to how serious a pathological feature this is. The good news is the rest of your report is fine. With only a G7 3/4.... even in a SRT situation I think u will be fine. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: Hello Mom. Good news for dad is that he has been recurrence free for almost 3 years. I would agree with you that based on his PSA trend, sooner would be the choice. Must studies show early SRT to be most effective with a PSA of . 1 or lower. I am on my phone typing, but I will post the links tomorrow from work. For most men, SRT is not all that bad. U may get some bowel issues, but they don't last long. The hardest part will be getting the timing down to have a full bladder before each session. That can take a little practice, but with 37/38 treatments coming, you will need to get the hang of it. Most of the SE if you are going to have any will be long after SRT is over. Those would be potential urinary issues. For now move forward without delay for the best potential outcome. Best, MM

Posts.Title: 6 Weeks post Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Truckin: Welcome aboard, sorry that you find yourself here. I see where you are planning on surgery, and given the stats that u have listed, it looks like u have a excellent chance for a cure. All G6 and G7 (3+4) puts you in the low-intermediate risk group. Good to hear you are going to MDA, several guys here have had a positive experience there. ( also a major cancer center) Read Dr. Patrick Walsh's book ( 3rd edition) " surviving prostate cancer". Lots of good information and it will help you get a feel for what's ahead. Lots of peaks and valleys, but you will get thru it. The days pass quickly, and in no time you will be cancer free. Keep asking questions, and remember you are not alone. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Zero club membership renewal

Posts.Content: Vince: All of us like to say, " I am not a doctor" which is true. But I, for one, have learned just as much from this forum as I have when I go and visit my medical team. Not that they don't want to talk to me, they just don't have the time. They are great doctors, but busy. That being said, LVI is when the Pathologist looks under the microscope and sees cancer in the blood vessels leading to the lymph system. Another adverse pathology finding that one would rather not have. However, it's prognostic value is uncertain, and at times controversial. I would not worry to much about it for now. Focus on healing. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Finally time

Posts.Content: Hey Caddy: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here, but at least it is with a G6. Your case seems to be local, the only thing that would concern me in what u have written is that u have 5 positive cores. That probably means a call for action. While the Cat scan may show that the disease is contained, that is not a certainty. One never knows until the pathology, should you be choosing surgery. I would agree that you have no reason to rush, so I would get a few more opinions and check out all options. Speak with a Robotic surgeon, and speak with a RO. The side effects are something to not take lightly, as they can be life altering. Pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book "The guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". Lots of good information that will get you started. Keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Age 68 and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Wallart: Welcome to the forum. I feel for the situation both u and your husband find yourself in. Please pardon my straight talk. As I read your post, I can't help but just shake my head and wonder.....what in the world is going on!! The PSA numbers that you refer to should have been enough to alert any medical professional that action was/is required. Eight years ago his PSA was 32? And what did the doctor recommend? Waiting eight years? While a healthy diet surely can be of benefit, I can assure you that it will not cure any existing PCa. Honestly, after 10 years of sitting around doing nothing, your husband may qualify as a modern miracle. All that being said, it may not be to late. Take action NOW!! Psa numbers that high are not a good sign. Sorry to sound harsh. This is a forum of support and encouragement. So let me encourage you. If your husband does not take action, he may not have another 10 years to think about it. Keep us posted on his condition. If you act now, modern treatments could keep him alive for many years. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Better Path Report Than I had hoped for :)

Posts.Content: Hello Mike: Interesting post. I think the "Who Are Us" probably could be changed to "Who am I? Most of what you have said about who stays on the forum is correct. But, I think it is more about the person, and who they are and their life situation. Time plays a major part in forum participation. What is it that a person does everyday? Does he/she have the time for this? Make no mistake, it is a commitment. I for one have a great deal of admiration for the 2 guys who have already responded to your thread. One guy has a minor case, one guy no case at all. Yet they are all over this board reaching out to help others and provide support and information, paying it forward. Why am I still around? To pay back all the good things that have happened to me by joining this forum. I feel a debt of gratitude to those who have helped me during this ordeal. Think about it, total strangers reaching out to help others, it has been quite amazing. With nothing in it for themselves! This is not to be critical of those who have come and gone. Life gets in the way of many things. I guess it depends upon how a person feels inside themselves. For myself, I will continue to pay it forward, and stay the course. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: SRT completed!

Posts.Content: Mike: Since you are currently on Casodex, and I assume the shot you will be receiving will be Lupron, you still have time to wait for the 3 month PSA. The ADT will stop the cancer in it's tracks while you heal. With a 1.1 at six weeks, it probably won't get much better to the point where it will change the course of your treatment. So hang in and heal, and then get the 3 month test. I am going to assume the ADT will start knocking your PSA down. But do not be misled, you still need the SRT to shoot for the cure, and it is still possible! Stay strong brother. MM

Posts.Title: Post Op 9 months Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Mike: The key thing is that u have started ADT, and that will control the cancer while you wait for SRT. They may not suspect any mets, but they are trying to guard against any micro-mets which would not show up on any scans. Just worry about healing, and taking one day at a time. Getting used to the HT, etc. It is a change in one's life. Given that u had a positive node, they will keep u on it for awhile. But stay the course Mike, you stand a good chance of beating this, and congrats on getting that PSA response. That is impressive. Keep us posted. MM

Posts.Title: First Post-OP PSA

Posts.Content: Hey Caddy: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here, but at least it is with a G6. Your case seems to be local, the only thing that would concern me in what u have written is that u have 5 positive cores. That probably means a call for action. While the Cat scan may show that the disease is contained, that is not a certainty. One never knows until the pathology, should you be choosing surgery. I would agree that you have no reason to rush, so I would get a few more opinions and check out all options. Speak with a Robotic surgeon, and speak with a RO. The side effects are something to not take lightly, as they can be life altering. Pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book "The guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". Lots of good information that will get you started. Keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Post Op 9 months Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Hello Cajun: Thank u for the information, your case has become a bit clearer. Basically, u are me! pt3bNO. Since u have not had any HT since the 30 days of casodex before your operation, we can assume that your numbers are not being "masked" by anything. For now, I would let myself heal as much as possible, and go along for as long as I can without additional treatment. ( u do not mention your continence or any ED issues) I would monitor my PSA every 8-12 weeks, and when it goes to 0.03 or greater, I would pull the trigger. Using the uPSA test, a reading of >0.03 for high risk people like yourself is very indicative of BCR. I would get all my ducks in a row, and be ready to act when your uPSA tells u to do so. Your PSA level will be the most important factor in determining the potential of the success with ADT/SRT. For now sit tight, but be on top of this every 8-12 weeks. Best, MM

Good luck, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Mike: Interesting post. I think the "Who Are Us" probably could be changed to "Who am I? Most of what you have said about who stays on the forum is correct. But, I think it is more about the person, and who they are and their life situation. Time plays a major part in forum participation. What is it that a person does everyday? Does he/she have the time for this? Make no mistake, it is a commitment. I for one have a great deal of admiration for the 2 guys who have already responded to your thread. One guy has a minor case, one guy no case at all. Yet they are all over this board reaching out to help others and provide support and information, paying it forward. Why am I still around? To pay back all the good things that have happened to me by joining this forum. I feel a debt of gratitude to those who have helped me during this ordeal. Think about it, total strangers reaching out to help others, it has been quite amazing. With nothing in it for themselves! This is not to be critical of those who have come and gone. Life gets in the way of many things. I guess it depends upon how a person feels inside themselves. For myself, I will continue to pay it forward, and stay the course. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Content: Hey Ourtime: I am a Gleason 8 (4+4) When my current uro delivered the news, she ran by me what is called the Partin tables, a method used at John Hopkins ( or developed by a uro there) to predict what you are asking. Google John Hopkins Partin tables and you may plug in your husbands numbers. Mine are as follows: 59% organ confined, 32% EPE ( just outside the capsule ) 6% chance to the seminal vesiciles, and 3% chance to the lymph nodes. Now, I just went to chiguys link to sloan ket and the numbers for me were much worse. So, I can't help you there. For now i am going to go with the uro who sat me down and gave me this information as one of the tools for her recommendations for treatment. Once again to be clear, I am not sure about the sloan ket link. The partin tables are also discussed in Dr. Walsh's book. My best, MM

Posts.Content: Mark. FWIW, outcomes for G7 (4/3) and G8 4/4 are fairly close, or similar. I remember reading that early on in my case, going from 8 to 7 on biopsy, to 9 on pathology. Factor in your 90% pattern 4, and it probably applies well to u. Great report, u should consider yourself very fortunate. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Is there a not quite zero club?

Posts.Content: Hey Rooster: If all goes well, you will not need to know anything or become worried about catheter maintenance. There may not be anything to do. Make sure your shorts have pockets, this way when u move about u can hang the bag from your pockets. I would question having a extra mattress on your bed. I actually went the other way. I slept in the guest room with the low bed. Easier to get in and out. The higher the bed, the more difficult. Your feet will not be on the floor. Just one guy's opinion. I wanted my feet to hit the floor when I sat up. BTW....my hernia operation was 5X worse than the RALP. I was able to get around quite well after RALP. Not so much with the hernia. U should be fine. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Polysporin for catheter treatment

Posts.Content: Rooster: You may not need anything. If u do, Vaseline jelly works just as well. U don't need a applicator, a q-tip will work just fine. U r just putting it around where the catheter is inserted in your penis. BTW...half the stuff they told me I needed I never used. The 3 most important things are baggy shorts/ sweats, a nice recliner, and depends. (Extra absorbent) Don't waste your money running around buying all the crap they tell u. Buy it as needed. U may not need any type of ointment, rubber gloves, wipes, blah, blah, blah. Since it is summer, get some baggy shorts, hang the bag in your pocket, and pee away!! Use the big bag so u don't have to change it often. Get a long cord with the bag ( hospital provided) and u can sleep in your bed. Keep the bag below u. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Begin Radiation Next Week

Posts.Content: Hello Aconher. Welcome to the forum. Sorry to hear that your father is battling cancer for the second time in his life. Once is enough for anybody. The good news is that the case you are showing us is not a serious case, or perhaps I should say that you are classified as lower intermediate risk. ( assuming nothing gets worse) Given the stats, I would assume that his scans will be negative, and that he and his doctors will have plenty of time to decide on treatment options. I would recommend that you speak with a surgeon, and a RO to find out which treatment options suit you best. This looks like a local case, so take heart in that your father will be just fine. Good luck, and keep us posted on his progress. MM

Posts.Title: Small Cell Prostate

Posts.Content: To your first question, some uPSA tests will just give 2 decimal points. It just depends on the "assay " being used. Not all of them give 3 decimal points. Most RP at the major cancer centers employ the ePLND for all men. I have read though of lower risk cases where they do not do them. The case to which you refer was G7 (3+4) so maybe that's why. Now that he has PM, if he does end up having radiation, make sure the plan covers the prostate bed and local lymph nodes, known as a "boost". Get them all done at once. With PM, I sure would like to have had the LND. Hope that helps. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Lupron Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hey Jaybee: From what you have written, I see nothing to be concerned about at this point. Your pathology report was a victory, and you should be feeling a sigh of relief. pT2c post-op is not all bad. G7 (4+3) not the end of the world. Rest easy, there is a very good chance he is cured. Jim215 and Chuck have covered the finer points of your post. Keep us posted on your Aug. 5th appointment. And remember, it takes 8-12 weeks after surgery to feel good again. It is a major operation. Give it time. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: First holiday season with cancer.

Posts.Content: Hello Flourish: Welcome to the forum. Sorry for what you are going thru as a couple. Another side effect of PCa....the gift that keeps on giving. ( Please note my sarcasm). You don't mention anything about ADT, or anything about the effects on your sex life. My apologies if that statement was a bit to personal. This disease has many different faces, and none of them are good. Many men go thru what you are describing, myself being one of them. Lots of body changes and various feelings of what the hell just happened to me. It takes some time to come to grips with the "new normal". Things will never be the same...but they can be even better on certain levels. If you could create a signature and tell us more about your husband, perhaps that would give a clearer picture. I guess what I am saying is what you have described is NOT unique to u. Many of us are going thru it. Don't give up, your husband did not ask for PCa! He needs to get past the dark side, and then u two can work on things. Please keep us posted. Warmest Regards, MM FWIW, we have a Forum sister with the Handle "Ready2Fight". She is a lovely woman, and one of the kindest people I have come to know. She is well educated, and very giving of her time. Send her a PM if u like, perhaps another woman's perspective would be of some help. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: UK study of PC screening

Posts.Content: Hello Gary. There are many studies and various opinions as to how long one should be on HT. As with most things PCa, there is no clear cut answer. The standard of care for someone with your pathology would probably be all u have done plus 2 full years of ADT. I know its tough, but you will make it thru. Your PSA, while low, was never undetectable after RP. You have LN involvement. I would go with what the University of Chicago and Loyola Cancer Center told me...2 years. Its a long road, but Im almost done. I have a signature, but it does not show up when using my iPhone. Click on my name and take a look. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: middle of SRT and Hormone - PSA .02 = problem?

Posts.Content: Rob: "In other words, the decision was all mine... My fear now is, what happens when this finally wears off"? That is the million $$$ question!! I look at it this way: To date, I have done all I can. My Uro told me that since I have been on HT for 2 years ( final shot wears off on May 15th ) that I could expect this to stay in my system for over a year. I really will not know much until well into 2019, and my "T" level may never return to normal. In addition to hitting it with everything INCLUDING the kitchen sink, I have also made lifestyle changes to hopefully add a few percentage points of success to my side. I have done my best, let's see what happens. Hope this finds u and the wife doing well. Best regards, MM

Posts.Title: Finding a good surgeon

Posts.Content: Rooster:Since your RP failed, the next bag of tricks is to shoot for a cure or durable ( many years) remission via SRT/ HT. First of all, u may be ok. This is the hard part, the waiting game. Eligard/ Lupron may work for many years. Who's to say 2 years? Everyone is different, and many men have great responses for much longer than that. HT not only does what Roblee suggested, but along with radiation can kill cells. Hopefully any stray cells that may be floating about. Should your PSA continue to rise and u become hormone refractory, there are additional bullets to fire before becoming stage 4. U just don't automatically go to stage 4. Many treatments available and others in the pipeline to tame this beast. Hope this helps. MM

Posts.Content: Rooster: I used to ask my RO at the university of Chicago all those kind of questions. Not much BS out of this woman. She had more than one stage 3 patients who were also N1 at DX. (Advanced local). During my RT, she was still in contact with them 10-15 years later. Btw... I don't know your stats, but it is possible that your HT/ SRT is successful. I believe I posted a link in another thread that u can look up giving you the odds. Or better yet, I'll post it tomorrow when I find it. Hang tough Rooster. MM

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hey Brite: Sorry to year about your urologist/surgeon. Much more common than we would like to think. Lets move on. I would get a 6 week uPSA and see where u are at that point. Even with your high PSA, that time frame would be a good starting point to see where he is at. I would not wait 3 months. Surely by 8 weeks the half life of PSA will have expired and get u a accurate look. Yes, I do have the name of a RO who was recommended to me that is out of Hyde Park. Let me look it up and pass it on. I will reply tomorrow. Im not sure of Dr. McCalls locations. I know for sure she is at the Frankfort/ Lenox location. Check it out. Shes worth it. At this stage All u would be needing is a consultation to start getting your ducks in a row. Start with Dr. S at Hyde Park. He is a straight shooter who tells it like he sees it, but really cares about the patient. I liked him. You are very early in the process, get the ball rolling with Dr.S as soon as u can. See what he thinks. Im currently being treated at Loyola Medical. My cousin is my PCP who got me in with my current urologist. If we need to find additional options, I will make some calls to him. The big 4 in Chicago.....Northwestern, UC, Loyola, Rush. Keep me posted, dont wait take action now and get in to see him soon. Best, MM
Posts.Title: Second Opinions for Advanced Prostate Cancer in the Chicago Area

Posts.Content: Hello Gary. There are many studies and various opinions as to how long one should be on HT. As with most things PCa, there is no clear cut answer. The standard of care for someone with your pathology would probably be all u have done plus 2 full years of ADT. I know its tough, but you will make it thru. Your PSA, while low, was never undetectable after RP. You have LN involvement. I would go with what the University of Chicago and Loyola Cancer Center told me...2 years. Its a long road, but Im almost done. I have a signature, but it does not show up when using my iPhone. Click on my name and take a look. Good luck, MM
Posts.Title: Looking for opinion

Posts.Content: Hello Brite: Just saw your post. I am afraid my forum sister R2F gives me to much credit. I'm no expert, but I do have a few suggestions for u here in the Chicago area. Ok, so u just had a RP. It says in your signature that it was in October 2017. Why are u starting Lupron right now? Can u tell me anything about his PSA post-op? Has he even been tested yet? At this stage I would not even be talking to a urologist/surgeon. As a pT3B NO, I would be speaking to a MO or a RO. Maybe they are being aggressive because of your pre-op PSA, I don't know. That would be my guess. Here in Chicago the RO that I would recommend would be from the University of Chicago ( Frankfort affiliate) Dr. Ann McCall. Probably the best doctor that I have come across during my treatments. A lovely woman, always has time for u, and answers EM in about an hour. She's the best. For an MO, I would choose Dr. Russell Szmulewitz at the UC. ( Located in Hyde Park in the city) He is Assistant Professor of Hematology/Oncology. Very matter of fact, but a real good guy. I would not go to a Urologist at this stage, their work is done. If u could provide more information as to his current state, I may be able to help more. Best of Luck, MM..............If u need more help, just ask

Posts.Content: Congrtas F2. Hang in there, it gets better each day. Just take it easy, don't really lift anything for 8 weeks. Use the stool medicine for a BM. Your doctor should have given u a prescription. I use the depends ( extra absorb) during the day, and the pull up at nite. I'm dry at nite, just a lack of confidence. Down to 1 pad during the day. If you have questions, ask away. I am now 5.5 months from surgery. Here's looking forward to a pristine path report. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Second Opinions for Advanced Prostate Cancer in the Chicago Area

Posts.Content: Hello Cyclone: Welcome to the forum, glad to have a person of your caliber around. I feel like I have known you for quite some time, as I have read countless posts by u on another forum. I'm glad that you are here, as you have quite a way with words and stories. ( all in a good way) You are the official poet laureate of cancer forums! I knew right away that you were in education, as my greatest fear would be following your words with having to construct a post of my own. What has impressed me most about your journey is....YOU! Your endless words of encouragement to others, offering hope and guidance to those in need. Your picking up on when someone needs help, or knowing when to be a good listener. I admire the amount of time you give to others, and the willingness to share your story. You have a wealth of experience in both life and PCa, please stick around, you will be a valuable addition. Now on to the important stuff.....Take ISU and the 6.5 at home tomorrow. They won't let us down. TCU is ripe to be had! I would tell you to hang in, but you already know how to do that. Talk soon Cyclone....MM

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas Everyone!

Posts.Content: gsteve: A move from .01 to .02 may just be a bit of noise. I would not be to concerned, but I would be testing my PSA every 3 months. Any increase above 0.03 could be a indication of BCR. Your correct about 1 thing, your GP knows nothing. If that is his idea of giving you advice, I would tell him to stick to what he knows. You should be seeing a urologist, or RO. Beware, many Uros have a annoying habit of waiting to long to initiate SRT. I would almost just make a appointment with the RO. You are correct to be concerned about any increase in PSA. It begs your attention. Best, MM

Posts.Title: slight increase in psa 4 years post robotic

Posts.Content: Rooster:Since your RP failed, the next bag of tricks is to shoot for a cure or durable ( many years) remission via SRT/ HT. First of all, u may be ok. This is the hard part, the waiting game. Eligard/ Lupron may work for many years. Who's to say 2 years? Everyone is different, and many men have great responses for much longer than that. HT not only does what Roblee suggested, but along with radiation can kill cells. Hopefully any stray cells that may be floating about. Should your PSA continue to rise and u become hormone refractory, there are additional bullets to fire before becoming stage 4. U just don't automatically go to stage 4. Many treatments available and others in the pipeline to tame this beast. Hope this helps. MM

Posts.Title: 1 year Post Op Update

Posts.Content: Hello Jet. Thanks for the reply. Not sure I get it, perhaps someone more knowledgeable will chime in. The neurovascular bundles are located in the soft tissue that surrounds the prostate gland. Your tumor was in the bundle. You had EPE, with negative margins. We have already discussed that at length in several posts on this forum. I would have to think the invading of the nerve bundles caused the pathological staging u received. The question I have still stands. Why is the surgeon telling u it was all contained? I have a guess, but just found ur case curious. In any event, wishing u all the best. MM
Posts.Title: 1 year Post Op Update

Posts.Content: Congrtas F2. Hang in there, it gets better each day. Just take it easy, don't really lift anything for 8 weeks. Use the stool medicine for a BM. Your doctor should have given u a prescription. I use the depends ( extra absorb) during the day, and the pull up at nite. I'm dry at nite, just a lack of confidence. Down to 1 pad during the day. If you have questions, ask away. I am now 5.5 months from surgery. Here's looking forward to a pristine path report. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hey Brite: Sorry to year about your urologist/surgeon. Much more common than we would like to think. Lets move on. I would get a 6 week uPSA and see where u are at that point. Even with your high PSA, that time frame would be a good starting point to see where he is at. I would not wait 3 months. Surely by 8 weeks the half life of PSA will have expired and get u a accurate look. Yes, I do have the name of a RO who was recommended to me that is out of Hyde Park. Let me look it up and pass it on. I will reply tomorrow. Im not sure of Dr. McCalls locations. I know for sure she is at the Frankfort/ Lenox location. Check it out. Shes worth it. At this stage All u would be needing is a consultation to start getting your ducks in a row. Start with Dr. S at Hyde Park. He is a straight shooter who tells it like he sees it, but really cares about the patient. I liked him. You are very early in the process, get the ball rolling with Dr.S as soon as u can. See what he thinks. Im currently being treated at Loyola Medical. My cousin is my PCP who got me in with my current urologist. If we need to find additional options, I will make some calls to him. The big 4 in Chicago.....Northwestern, UC, Loyola, Rush. Keep me posted, dont wait take action now and get in to see him soon. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Did I make the right choice.

Posts.Content: gsteve: A move from .01 to .02 may just be a bit of noise. I would not be to concerned, but I would be testing my PSA every 3 months. Any increase above 0.03 could be a indication of BCR. Your correct about 1 thing, your GP knows nothing. If that is his idea of giving you advice, I would tell him to stick to what he knows. You should be seeing a urologist, or RO. Beware, many Uros have a annoying habit of waiting to long to initiate SRT. I would almost just make a appointment with the RO. You are correct to be concerned about any increase in PSA. It begs your attention. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Thanks gang. Was a busy weekend, and I just saw this on Sunday nite. What a lucky man I am to have people like u all In my corner, and in my life. If there was or is a silver lining in the PCa mess, it has been meeting and conversing with all of u. Had the PSA draw on May 11, hope to get the results Monday or Tuesday. Thank u all for thinking of me! R2F.... thanks for initiating the thread. Your are a special woman. Happy Mothers Day....MM
Posts.Title: Good Luck Tomorrow MM16

Posts.Content: Hello Brite: Just saw your post. I am afraid my forum sister R2F gives me to much credit. I'm no expert, but I do have a few suggestions for u here in the Chicago area. Ok, so u just had a RP. It says in your signature that it was in October 2017. Why are u starting Lupron right now? Can u tell me anything about his PSA post-op? Has he even been tested yet? At this stage I would not even be talking to a urologist/surgeon. As a pT3B NO, I would be speaking to a MO or a RO. Maybe they are being aggressive because of your pre-op PSA, I don't know. That would be my guess. Here in Chicago the RO that I would recommend would be from the University of Chicago ( Frankfort affiliate) Dr. Ann McCall. Probably the best doctor that I have come across during my treatments. A lovely woman, always has time for u, and answers EM in about an hour. She's the best. For an MO, I would choose Dr. Russell Szmulewitz at the UC. ( Located in Hyde Park in the city) He is Assistant Professor of Hematology/Oncology. Very matter of fact, but a real good guy. I would not go to a Urologist at this stage, their work is done. If u could provide more information as to his current state, I may be able to help more. Best of Luck, MM..............If u need more help, just ask

Posts.Content: Hey Nick: That is about as good as you could have hoped for. I do not remember your risk status, but u might want to consider the uPSA test, in addition to being tested more than once in a year. Once done with SRT, and because u are receiving 3-month shots of Lupron, I would think that they should be testing u before each shot? Like once every 3 months. Since your PSA is doing well, I would assume that your "T" level is in the correct place, but a check on that could not hurt either. As for me, doing as well as I could have asked. So far, so good. We shall see....good luck on the HT, it takes a toll on you. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Still in the Zero club!

Posts.Content: Hello Paul. Welcome to the forum. Sorry you have to be here, but at least you are here with a Gleason 6. If you would care to list your stats in a signature page, many folks here will be able to ease some of the stress that you are experiencing. As I said, if all you have to worry about is the Gleason 6, my guess is that you have a excellent chance for a complete cure, and will be done with treatment after your RALP. A G6 prostate cancer is very low-risk. I'm not positive, but I don't think the cancer cells of a G6 are capable of spreading. Given your extremely low PSA, I would think that is has not spread and is confined to the capsule. To sum up, you are probably 10 car lengths in the clear!!( based on what you have written) What you should be thinking is I am going to be fine, and within a year my life will be back to normal. Your case, as you have presented it, is just not that serious. It is completely normal for the mind to wonder and dark thoughts to enter. That will ease as time moves along. Don't worry now about what "might" occur after the surgery. Just focus on the here and now. If all they found on the biopsy is a G6 ( 3+3), even a small upgrade is not a big worry. For now, concentrate on making smart decisions based on what you know now. I assume you have picked a surgeon who has at least 300-400 RALPS under his belt. Your main concern now is the best surgeon you can find, and your SE and cancer cure will be just fine. Be nice to your wife, we all need people to stand behind us!! Remember, you are not alone, we all are here for you. Best Regards, MM

Best, MM

Posts.Title: 2 years Post-Prostatecotomy PSA Rising ?,

Posts.Content: With all due respect, if a few troubled days and weeks are your biggest problems, you should consider yourself quite fortunate. The PSA test has alerted many on this forum to potential trouble, and caught this hideous disease while still curable. While I realize the biopsy can be a touch uncomfortable, if done by a good uro using all the proper anesthesia, its a small price to pay to know you are cancer free. I'm hoping that my regular PSA tests will lead me to a PC free outcome. No offense, and we all are entitled to our own opinion, but your post kind of hit a nerve.

Posts.Title: Post Pathology Report

Posts.Content: Hey Jimmy: As you will see from my signature profile, I have been all over the board as far as my diagnoses and staging went. I think the answer to your question may hinge on actually knowing your staging. I choose surgery because my clinical staging was T2c. Meaning it was contained to the capsule. Regrettably, it did not turn out that way. My pathological staging or final stage was pT3bNOMO. Herein lies the problem. In many cases, surgery is not curative with T3 staging. Some yes, some no. Many of the T3 patients find themselves facing this situation. Meaning having surgery, and then facing secondary treatment. I guess what I am saying is you may end up having to have radiation and end up in the same place if you just would have started radiation in the first place. Had I have known this in my situation, I may have choose some sort of brachytherapy/ ADT and not had the additional issues associated with surgery. I don't know, tough call. With one G9 and many G8, you find yourself in a high risk category. All this is coming from a guy who just had surgery. My readings and research are leading me to think that for T3 patients, some sort of radiation/HT combo may be just as useful, without having to go thru 2 procedures. BTW, the CT scan was probably just of the pelvic Lymph nodes. That would not tell u much about possible PM, EPE, SV... etc. Perhaps others here will chime in on how to get a better read on that. Hang in there, we are all here for u. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Glad tidings to all

Posts.Content: Big: I will throw my 2 cents into the ring. Your pathology report is not all bad. Your PSA is 0. I would wait, you are jumping the gun. I would be keeping my eye on the PSA using the ultra-test, and I would test every 8 weeks, even if I had to pay for it myself. I would also be lining up my ducks, just in case the need arises. Go to the RO and get some different opinions. Do all the upfront leg work now, and be ready to act in a moments notice. I would give myself every chance to heal, and use my uPSA results as my guide. I really see nothing to do.....for now. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Swarren. I guess I will disagree ever so slightly with what has already been said. PCa does not have to be contained to be cured. It certainly makes it more likely, but you received Lupron to not only aid in the radiation process, but to kill any cells that potentially are not in the radiation field. There has been research that shows it can happen. ( killing of stray cells) As Pratoman says, a lot depends upon your specific case. In the world of high-risk PCa, the word "cured" should be used with the utmost caution. Please tell us more about yourself, if comfortable. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Couple Of Questions Re: Salvage Radiation & Hormone Therapy

Posts.Content: Hello BAB. Welcome to the forum. Brother MF, as usual, has covered most of the bases. I would just add that with 12+ cores, and 2 of them G7 (4+3) I would go ahead and get a second reading of the slides. Any core with a dominant pattern 4 should be taken seriously, and I would get a second reading just to be sure. So far u would be classified as Grade group 3, if I am not mistaken. ( higher intermediate risk-group). This all being said, check out all your options, and the first step is getting a second reading. Cost is around 250$. Don't take anything for granted, and during this journey one is best to expect the unexpected. Keep us posted on the slide results, we are here to help u. You are not alone. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Bad news pathology report

Posts.Content: Hello Kbolieu. Welcome to the forum. I am at work and I saw this post. Honestly, this post is making my skin crawl. Not because of your husbands Dx, but because of the surgeons behavior in this case. I would probably be looking to throw him off the top of the nearest building. With this high risk case, to tell you that the best move is surgery, without talking about any other potential options, is downright brutal. I'm sorry, I just have to vent on this. But, that is all behind you now. Yes, get to MDA ASAP. Take a deep breath. They will point u in the correct direction. If you could create a signature and list all your husbands stats, that would be helpful. Stay strong, there are many treatments and options out there. Get away from this goofball surgeon. Go to MDA. They will help you with a game plan. Yes, you need to see a MO and a RO. Be pro-active, there is still plenty of time to have a positive outcome. And yes, some potential treatments down the road may keep him near the place where he is being treated. More to follow. Best, MM

Posts.Title: 2 weeks into 6 week round of Radiation

Posts.Content: Hello BAB. Welcome to the forum. Brother MF, as usual, has covered most of the bases. I would just add that with 12+ cores, and 2 of them G7 (4+3) I would go ahead and get a second reading of the slides. Any core with a dominant pattern 4 should be taken seriously, and I would get a second reading just to be sure. So far u would be classified as Grade group 3, if I am not mistaken. ( higher intermediate risk-group). This all being said, check out all your options, and the first step is getting a second reading. Cost is around 250$. Don't take anything for granted, and during this journey one is best to expect the unexpected. Keep us posted on the slide results, we are here to help u. You are not alone. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Wish I could be of more help Sportbug. So you say your a G7 ( 3+4). At the bottom of your stats, u have 1 core 4+3? Is this correct? Why HT so soon out of the gate? Kind of curious as to your treatment plan for a intermediate risk case. As far as the RT, I had some loose bowels, but the biggest issue was the full bladder and the timing of the radiation. The drive home in that regard was no picnic. As time went by, I needed a restroom. Had some severe I have to go now issues. What u are experiencing is way beyond. Check it out and let us know. Did you have any diagnostic tests that made HT necessary right away? Or was it the 4+3? Good luck sportbug. MM

Posts.Title: Newbie here folks

Posts.Content: Hello Kbolieu. Welcome to the forum. I am at work and I saw this post. Honestly, this post is making my skin crawl. Not because of your husbands Dx, but because of the surgeons behavior in this case. I would probably be looking to throw him off the top of the nearest building. With this high risk case, to tell you that the best move is surgery, without talking about any other potential options, is downright brutal. I'm sorry, I just have to vent on this. But, that is all behind you now. Yes, get to MDA ASAP. Take a deep breath. They will point u in the correct direction. If you could create a signature and list all your husbands stats, that would be helpful. Stay strong, there are many treatments and options out there. Get away from this goofball surgeon. Go to MDA. They will help you with a game plan. Yes, you need to see a MO and a RO. Be pro-active, there is still plenty of time to have a positive outcome. And yes, some potential treatments down the road may keep him near the place where he is being treated. More to follow. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Approved for Provenge

Posts.Content: Rptrman: Sorry to hear of the tough time that you are having. I am also on Lupron, been so for a total of 4 months. I am experiencing the hot flashes and some bathroom issues. Not good, but to this point in time, manageable. Dosage of Lupron Injection depends on the condition being treated, ( extent of) and the patient's age and sex. There may be other drugs that can interact with the Lupron Injection to help you with some of the issues you are having. Perhaps you should have a conversation with your MO and explain your concerns. For some men, the side effects become to much to handle. Many will have severe reactions. See if your MO can help you in this regard. You should not be sitting in this much discomfort. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: 2.5 yrs later - psa rises.

Posts.Content: Hello Glenn. Well for not having your PSA checked for 5 years with basically a G8, I would say as of now you are quite lucky. While .9 is getting up there, and would put you into a late salvage category, it does not necessarily mean it has metastasized. You are certainly playing with fire, and I would be contacting a RO immediately. For someone with no additional treatment other than primary, and to ignore it for 5 years, I would have expected a much higher number. Act now! Best, MM
Posts.Title: Reoccurence After Nine Years(?)

Posts.Content: Rptrman: Sorry to hear of the tough time that you are having. I am also on Lupron, been so for a total of 4 months. I am experiencing the hot flashes and some bathroom issues. Not good, but to this point in time, manageable. Dosage of Lupron Injection depends on the condition being treated, ( extent of) and the patient's age and sex. There may be other drugs that can interact with the Lupron Injection to help you with some of the issues you are having. Perhaps you should have a conversation with your MO and explain your concerns. For some men, the side effects become to much to handle. Many will have severe reactions. See if your MO can help you in this regard. You should not be sitting in this much discomfort. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Content: Mitch: What you have described is what has become the "cluster #*#*" of today's medical practice. At least in terms of administration. I am also surprised that ALL slides were not sent to Dr. Epstein. I would contact them and tell them in no uncertain terms that you would like all of YOUR slides sent to Dr. Epstein. This way your mind will be at ease. If you get charged another 250 bucks by Dr. Epstein for the additional readings, so what? Well worth it. Leave no stone unturned. And as said before, Dr. Epstein is the final word. Good Luck. MM

Posts.Title: Second Opinion - Dr. Epstein

Posts.Content: Hello CMC: Not much to add here from what Brother RobLee has offered. I just want to welcome u to the forum, and let u know that u are not alone. Based on the information given, I would go under the assumption that u have a serious case, although that does not mean it can't be controlled and managed for many years to come. For now, I would be taking this case to a major cancer center, and look for meetings with a RO and MO. If u are in a remote location, perhaps u could indicate where u live and others will have some suggestions as to treatment centers. It is a lot to take in, but the beginning is always the hard part. Please keep us informed as to the results, and again RobLee has offered excellent advice. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Sept. We are here to help. Could you please post his most recent stats in the signature page. It will make it easier to comment. Also 2 questions come to mind. I assume he is a pT3b. Was he offered ADT when he had the SRT? If so, did he decline? SRT/ADT combined will give you a 50% better outcome ( or chance of) than either one alone. There are many studies supporting this. I am currently under going HT, happy to share my experiences. The more information u can give us, the better. Please list his history since the SRT he received 6 months after RALP. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Approved for Provenge

Posts.Content: John: From one pT3b to another, looks like you are doing well. How long are they keeping u on HT? I am surprised that they are not testing u with the uPSA, given your higher risk status. Have they been testing your "t" levels all along? In answer to your question regarding staying on Casodex after the first few months, it really is up to the RO. Mine told me it was not necessary after the SRT ended. Kind of there is no right or wrong on that one. Some combine the 2, others do not. Best of luck, and congrats on the "ZERO"!!!! MM

Posts.Title: Darolutamide Looking Good

Posts.Content: Hello RNFA: I join the others in welcoming u to the forum. Yes, that is a very high number for any age, and I would do a repeat just to double check. Once that action is taken, I would develop a plan from there. As Southsider points out, if it is 60, there is probably cancer present. However, additional testing may still allow your treatment to produce a cure. No way to tell until things play out. One thing for sure, do not ignore it. Keep us posted, MM

Posts.Content: Wish I could be of more help Sportbug. So you say your a G7 ( 3+4). At the bottom of your stats, u have 1 core 4+3? Is this correct? Why HT so soon out of the gate? Kind of curious as to your treatment plan for a intermediate risk case. As far as the RT, I had some loose bowels, but the biggest issue was the full bladder and the timing of the radiation. The drive home in that regard was no picnic. As time went by, I needed a restroom. Had some severe I have to go now issues. What u are experiencing is way beyond. Check it out and let us know. Did you have any diagnostic tests that made HT necessary right away? Or was it the 4+3? Good luck sportbug. MM

Posts.Content: Hello Sunny: Dave from Md gives good advise, and he is correct about you should feel like you are raising the penis. All that being said, I would like to point out that Kegels do not work for everyone. I know many men who did all their kegels, to no avail. If you talk to 10 different uros, u will get 30 diifferent answers. Another one of the many frustrating aspects of the treatment process. Some say this, others say that. I have done 1000's of kegels, and it has not helped me to where I am totally dry. And I did them before and after surgery. Honestly, I do not think there is any set answer. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: All alone with no support

Posts.Content: Hello Anne: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here and deal with this dreadful disease. Since your surgery date is not until 9/11, u might want to take the time before then to do some research and homework. BTW...a surgery on 9/11? That date and surgery don't seem to go together!! Since your husband has already been DX as a cT3a, you owe it to yourself and him to explore all your treatment options. T3 means the horse has already left the barn, and while a cure is still very possible, you need to go about this with the least amount of SE as possible. Surgery may not be curative by itself, and then u will find yourself in the SRT and perhaps other treatment modalities type of situation. Check out all your options, see a RO and learn about the various forms of radiation therapy. I am the poster boy for SE, and I would just like to pass along my experience on the subject. Be your own advocate, and ask questions. This is a life changing event, and the decisions u make now will be forever. I am available anytime to be helpful. Best regards, MM

Posts.Title: One year anniversary....

Posts.Content: Hello Srcoffee: Welcome to the forum. Not knowing all your stats, and what exactly u are dealing with, it might be hard to give u the best advice. Going on what u wrote, I can make the following comments. I believe the synergies of combining the RT and the ADT can be much more effective than either one alone. There is a wide range of opinion as to what is the proper length of time. In my high risk case, standard of care is what u see in my signature. I asked my doctor if the ADT kills stray cells that may be floating around ( when I first began SRT). He said they think it might, but he could not give me a conclusive yes. I would at least continue the ADT after radiation for 6 months....I would liken it to being on antibiotics, and deciding to not finish the prescribed amount. You have the "unhappy G7" with a dominant pattern 4. You may have something worse...just hard to tell. Not trying to scare u, but we each must make a decision as to how hard we want to go at it. Again, if u could fill out the signature forms, I'm sure some of the smarter forum brothers will be along to chime in. Best to u, MM

Posts.Title: New Member, Wife

Posts.Content: Hey Kozmic: On this one I would defer to your doctor. The better shape your in, the easier the recovery and the surgery will go. Not sure of your situation, but if the surgeon says it can't wait one year, call me crazy, I would tend to believe him. I was 200lbs. on sept 15th when my PSA was discovered to be out of whack. I kind of new something was up, so I just started a diet and exercise program. It's only a hour of exercise a day, plus eating right. I got down to 182 for my surgery. And I feel great!! If my sorry self can do it, so can you. What's more important than your overall health? Excess weight can cause all sorts of issues with surgery, and aftercare. Start something and take baby steps. 10 or 15% of something is better than 100% of nothing. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: New diagnosis, new member & question regarding 2nd opinion

Posts.Content: Hello firemana: Others here have given u sound opinions and directions. I had this exact conversation with my RO at the UC. The bottom line... a very low PSA, I believe the threshold was 2.5 or so accompied by a high grade Gleason would indicate a very aggressive tumor. Meaning 2.5 or less and a G8-10 are very rare. A high grade Gleason not showing a higher Psa value is to be taken very seriously. Not trying to scare u, just relating a topic of discussion with my RO. In other words, if given the choice, I'd rather have a G9 with a Psa of 5.9 than one with a 2.5 PSA. Check it out with your medical team. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: The good stuff

Posts.Content: H60: Among all my other issues of Pathology, LVI was also a risk factor to ask about. My team ( all 3 doctors) told me that while it would be better to not have it show up, it's prognostic value has been unclear in several studies. Having positive lymph nodes would be far more of a concern. Your pathology looks pretty decent, you should be very happy! And positive! Your chances for a cure remain strong, and their is much hope. Your Gleason score is very moderate, so take a breath and stay focused. Have a good holiday, and know that your PCa is under full control. Stay the course, hang in my brother. MM

Posts.Title: Prostate surgery??

Posts.Content: Delta: You are not missing anything. For now, I would do nothing. Your PSA is 0.01, and you do say that u are using the uPSA. I would continue to test every 2 months, and would only become concerned when a trend developed above 0.03, which recent studies have shown to be a accurate indicator of BCR. For what it's worth, SRT is not that big of a deal for most men. The SE are not to bad, and they go away in short order. If u do need it at some point in the future, sooner rather than later will produce the best outcomes. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Size matters? With robotic prostatectomy.

Posts.Content: Hey Kozmic: On this one I would defer to your doctor. The better shape your in, the easier the recovery and the surgery will go. Not sure of your situation, but if the surgeon says it can't wait one year, call me crazy, I would tend to believe him. I was 200lbs. on sept 15th when my PSA was discovered to be out of whack. I kind of new something was up, so I just started a diet and exercise program. It's only a hour of exercise a day, plus eating right. I got down to 182 for my surgery. And I feel great!! If my sorry self can do it, so can you. What's more important than your overall health? Excess weight can cause all sorts of issues with surgery, and aftercare. Start something and take baby steps. 10 or 15% of something is better than 100% of nothing. Good luck, MM

Posts.Content: Hey Cubs Fan: Welcome to the other side, and congrats on what seems to be a speedy recovery. I am also being treated at Loyola right now, so know that you are in good hands. I am sorry about the pathology report, but don't give up the ship. While you had several of the same adverse findings as I had, my doctors are still not ruling out a possible cure. You need to be aggressive and have the attitude that you are going to kick this in the a****. Your best bet is to attack when this is in the early stages, so I would be asking the RO about both HT and ART/SRT combined. You stand a better chance of success when combining the 2. You also have the additional issue of ductal PCa, which may require seeing a PCa specialist who has handled those sort of cases. Good News: You have NO and have no SVI. Those are 2 huge positives. Go on the offensive, and tell the doctor u want to be aggressive. Much like your Cubs, you will be staging a late inning rally. Keep me posted on how you are doing. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Am i at the right path?

Posts.Content: Mic: larger prostate can give off more PSA. Most MD/ Uro would start u on 10 days of Cipro to take care of any infections and the re-evaluate ur PSA. How accurate is your free PSA? Every person is different, so it's hard to tell. Your number warrants some sort of explanation. In any case, don't get to far ahead of yourself. There are several reasons for elavated PSA numbers that have nothing to do with PCa. Get the MRI / biopsy, be proactive. Keep us posted. Best, MM
Posts.Title: Am i at the right path?

Posts.Content: H60: It's basically the same thing as LVI. It is cancer seen in the small blood vessels while the pathologist looks under the microscope. Basically the terms are the same. It's not the lymph nodes themselves, it's the blood vessels or lymphatic system, just another way for the cancer to travel. It's prognostic significance is unclear. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Radiation vs Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hello Tom: Based upon your signature, you seem to be as low risk case. Your G score was favorable, and you are a T2, all good news. That being said, your trend is a bit of a concern. I would be keeping my eye on it, and would be testing more often. U are now at what is considered the "new" number to watch as it pertains to predicting BCR. >.03. I would be talking to a RO, and just get another opinion. Standing in your shoes, I would be pro-active, and have a contingency plan. I find your trend a concern, ultra PSA or not. On a positive note, even if this was BCR, the chances of it being local are very good. A cure would still be in your future. Studies have shown that the old number of .1 is being used less and less, especially in high risk cases. In addition, the sooner you act, the better the outcome. Since you have had surgery, I would not concern myself with any of the old rules regarding what to refrain from. U don't have a prostate. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Mr. Softee still in Zero Club

Posts.Content: Mic: larger prostate can give off more PSA. Most MD/ Uro would start u on 10 days of Cipro to take care of any infections and the re-evaluate ur PSA. How accurate is your free PSA? Every person is different, so it's hard to tell. Your number warrants some sort of explanation. In any case, don't get to far ahead of yourself. There are several reasons for elavated PSA numbers that have nothing to do with PCa. Get the MRI / biopsy, be proactive. Keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Bernard/ John. Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. RP, SRT, and HT can spell the end of natural erections. Those 3 things are very tough to overcome. Posts.Title: 0.1 PSA after surgery ... is this good or bad?

Posts.Content: Gary: Yes I did, and I am still on ADT until April/May of 2018. Happy to answer any questions. Im on my phone, which when I post doesnt produce a signature. Click on my name and U can view my history. I started Casodex on 4/1/16 and was on it until the end of radiation. My first lupron shot was 4/15/16. Being a PT3bNO, G9 ( 4+5), I wanted to throw everything at this including the kitchen sink! The studies I have read told me to increase my odds of any potential cure, I needed to take this path. Please pardon my straight talk. ADT sucks. The side effects were and have been difficult, but I have just told myself this is what I need to do. I will be on it for 2 years. The SE really hit me at the 3 month mark. Among them... bad sweats, weight gain in the stomach area, bone pain, joint pain. My hands got so bad I couldnt move my thumb joint. I fall asleep ok, but wake up every 2 hours. Honestly, its beem brutal. Sorry, not going to bullshit anyone. I walk an average of 4/5 miles per day, and in the winter lift weights. I wont even go into the sexual SE or incontinence issues. Most guys arent as bad as me. I was never given the chance to heal. I am currently on the nutrisystem diet and achieving some success. I was always thin and trim, and in excellent shape. Ok, enough. The good news? My PSA has been <0.05 for 14 months. I have given myself every chance to beat this. Not saying you or anyone else should follow this path. I have chosen living as my # 1 goal. We shall see how I do. I have read many of your posts. You are a very smart man, so Im sure u will do what is best for u. Im here to help if needed. Best, MM
Posts.Title: Brother going for salvage radiation--what should he expect

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Samie Staples and catheter out and all appears to be fine. Received pathology report also today. Upgraded from Gleason 7 4+3 to 8 4+4....lymph nodes negative for malignancy...one with sinus histiocytosis...2.4cm x 0.9 tumor size...involving 20 to 25%...right seminal vesicles involved by tumor...right lateral margin involved by tumor, distal margin negstive, proximal margin - sent for 2nd opinion...lymphovascular and perineural invasion not identified...pathological staging pT3b pNO pM Comment: Immunohistochemica stain Pankeratin is pending to assess the proximal margin and will be reported in a addedum. This case will be sent for a second opinion. The above is taken from the written report we received. Urologist says to have PSA tested in 3 months and return to discuss next steps based on PSA finding. Any comments on above appreciated and welcomed! We know this is not as good as we hoped. Hey Samie. Looks like your hubby and I have the same pathology reports. Or very close. First, let me say that when it happened to me I was a bit shaken up. It kind of scares you! But, I have spoken with many people and some of the guys on this site helped me understand that there is still a good chance for a cure. pT3b means that it has just escaped the prostate, but as our esteemed moderator pointed out to me " it's still in the neighborhood". The lymph nodes were negative. Good sign. Pt3 cases are more difficult, but not insurmountable. If needed, AR, SRT, etc could kill off any remaining cells. And who knows, your surgeon may have gotten it all. Chuck, Michael F, and Prato all helped me get thru the initial worry. For now, the PC is out of you and we both need to concentrate on getting better with the SE. Many of the surgeons have different protocol regarding the next steps. Mine is a 6w and a 12W PSA. then we shall see what happens. Mine friend Trinity3 is the same as us via John Hopkins. I will keep u posted on any information I receive. Hang in there, as prato told me " grieve for a bit, then get off the mat and get back in the game!! Keep us posted. Regards, MM

You do not need to see the Urologist anymore, his job is done. Do not waste anymore time. U need to see a good RO and get a plan going. The clock is ticking....Best, MM

Posts.Title: How long should I be on ADT (hormone therapy)?

Posts.Content: Hey PDV: Coukd u list some of your brothers stats. Is he getting ADT with the SRT? There are fatigue issues, but nothing to bad. If he is going to be required to have a full bladder, that is something that can cause some uncomfortable times, until u get the timing down. I would try and go somewhere that is convenient, as the drive to and from will occur 5x a week for 7-8 weeks. There is possible radiation burn, but you can get cream for that. The main problem for me was the timing of the bladder. I had a couple meltdowns, but once I figured it out, it worked out. The radiation simulation was kind of a bummer, but thats only one day. List his stats, I may have more to offer. The actual time under the arc is short and no problem. Keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Jim: Welcome to the forum. Sorry you have to be here, but with a G6 and T2 staging, a complete cure is on the horizon. It sounds like you have the "garden variety" PCa, so first of all please realize that it is completely curable. When time permits and you receive the information, please post your stats on the signature page. Others will be along to chime in and help you thru this process. You are not alone. The more information we have, the better advice we can give. Pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to surviving Prostate Cancer. Third Edition. This will help you get a clear understanding of what lies ahead. With a G6 you may not need treatment right now, perhaps qualifying for AS protocol. Keep us posted. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Title: PSA down, Clean scan!

Posts.Content: Gary: Yes I did, and I am still on ADT until April/May of 2018. Happy to answer any questions. Im on my phone, which when I post doesnt produce a signature. Click on my name and U can view my history. I started Casodex on 4/1/16 and was on it until the end of radiation. My first lupron shot was 4/15/16. Being a PT3bNO, G9 ( 4+5), I wanted to throw everything at this including the kitchen sink! The studies I have read told me to increase my odds of any potential cure, I needed to take this path. Please pardon my straight talk. ADT sucks. The side effects were and have been difficult, but I have just told myself this is what I need to do. I will be on it for 2 years. The SE really hit me at the 3 month mark. Among them... bad sweats, weight gain in the stomach area, bone pain, joint pain. My hands got so bad I couldnt move my thumb joint. I fall asleep ok, but wake up every 2 hours. Honestly, its beem brutal. Sorry, not going to bullshit anyone. I walk an average of 4/5 miles per day, and in the winter lift weights. I wont even go into the sexual SE or incontinence issues. Most guys arent as bad as me. I was never given the chance to heal. I am currently on the nutrisystem diet and achieving some success. I was always thin and trim, and in excellent shape. Ok, enough. The good news? My PSA has been <0.05 for 14 months. I have given myself every chance to beat this. Not saying you or anyone else should follow this path. I have chosen living as my # 1 goal. We shall see how I do. I have read many of your posts. You are a very smart man, so Im sure u will do what is best for u. Im here to help if needed. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Good news, I guess... how's everyone doing?

Posts.Content: Hello Rooster. For high risk cases, pT3b such as yourself, they do know that 2 years are better than 6 months. That has been shown in various studies. The question is what happens between the 6 month mark and extending out for a few years. There are so many different views that I will relate to you what my MO told me. He likened it to not taking antibiotics for the entire course. They would not be as effective. He also pointed me to the study in the following link.https://www.astro.org/uploadedFiles/...1580_FINAL.pdf As with all things PCa, one can get a lot of different answers. However, all of my Doctors, MO, Ro, Uro, etc have insisted on 2 years in my case. I believe they called this the DART study. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: How long should I be on ADT (hormone therapy)?

Posts.Content: Rooster. I had this on my computer that I had read in a PCblog regarding the question of how long. The statement had something to do with the curative intent of using ADT. once again I found this on a PCa Blog. It radio-sensitizes the cancer and then cleans up any hormone sensitive cells that the radiation did not kill. In clinical trials among high risk men, it significantly improves outcomes. Some of the more hormone-resistant cells apparently take longer to kill off. Undoubtedly, there is an abscopal effect too.

Posts.Content: His psa is stable..but at 0.12. His 3 month psa was 0.10. So, I get what u are saying about doubling time, etc. His psa certainly is not exploding forward, but even at 3 months with the half life of psa, most if not all should be out of your system. A 0.12 3-month psa after Ralp would send me running to the doctor for a answer. What you are saying to him is that he might be one of the exceptions or one-offs. With his rather favorable pathology report, this might be a local issue than could be solved right away. I am really wanting to hear what his doctors have been saying to him for the past year. My fear is this is yet another example of a Uro who waits....and waits....and waits....This flies in the face of everything I have been told at both the UC and Loyola medicine..confused. MM

Posts.Title: Home resting after surgery

Posts.Content: Hey there Rob: First on the PSA....Congrats! That is the type of response that u want to see, and let's hope that NO TREND will develop...just lots of Zeros. I am very happy to see that u are doing well, gives many of us hope that there is lite at the end of this tunnel, and it's not a train! In answer to your ADT comments and T levels, I thought u would like this. I asked the same questions and received this response.... As to when ADT will wear off, that is highly individual. In this study, testosterone recoved for 36.9% 66.3%, 86.3% and 92.6% at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months, respectively. But they were only on ADT for 9 months, I think you should expect it to take longer in your case. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3739223/ As you are well aware, I will be on ADT for 2 years, ending this May 15th. I think u had 18 months. To your comment regarding doctors, if they told us what they should they would have no patients...we would all run like hell!! Good luck tomorrow my friend, and congrats again on the PSA. U deserve it. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Wife: Yes, this entire PCa thing a long exhausting process. Standing in your shoes, I would be seeing a Mo and RO immediately. If your current doctor is not giving you enough guidance, keep moving along until you find a doctor who will. With your husbands PSA heading northbound, I would not be wasting anytime. ADT and/or radiation therapy is the next standard step. Given his higher risk case, sooner rather than later. Hang in there, your husband is lucky to have you in his corner. Best of Luck, MM

Posts.Title: AUS 800 dr installed.

Posts.Content: Rooster. I had this on my computer that I had read in a PCblog regarding the question of how long. The statement had something to do with the curative intent of using ADT. once again I found this on a PCa Blog. It radio-sensitizes the cancer and then cleans up any hormone sensitive cells that the radiation did not kill. In clinical trials among high risk men, it significantly improves outcomes. Some of the more hormone-resistant cells apparently take longer to kill off. Undoubtedly, there is an abscopal effect too.
Posts.Title: How long should I be on ADT (hormone therapy)?

You had a appointment with the RO in Oct. of 2018...what did they say? garyi and DJ are very smart forum brothers, I am wondering what they see here that I do not. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: Hey Nick: You ask a great question...Why would they tell u that u had zero chance of a cure, if they were treating u with curative intent? My take on your situation is that it is similar to Rob's and mine. ( Me having the G9, u both less) Your undetectable psa only means that u are responding to treatment. It means that u are hormone sensitive, instead of Hormone refractory. All good things. The ability to tolerate ADT has nothing to do with your long term prognosis...meaning the SE. Much more time needs to pass for all of us before any proclamations can be made. Given how long you have been on HT, you should probably expect it to take many months before returning to a "reasonable" T level. Good to hear from u, and keep us posted. MM

Posts.Title: 18 Months on Lupron update

Posts.Content: Hey there Rob: First on the PSA....Congrats! That is the type of response that u want to see, and let's hope that NO TREND will develop...just lots of Zeros. I am very happy to see that u are doing well, gives many of us hope that there is lite at the end of this tunnel, and it's not a train! In answer to your ADT comments and T levels, I thought u would like this. I asked the same questions and received this response.... As to when ADT will wear off, that is highly individual. In this study, testosterone recoved for 36.9% 66.3%, 86.3% and 92.6% at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months, respectively. But they were only on ADT for 9 months, I think you should expect it to take longer in your case. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3739223/ As you are well aware, I will be on ADT for 2 years, ending this May 15th. I think u had 18 months. To your comment regarding doctors, if they told us what they should they would have no patients...we would all run like hell!! Good luck tomorrow my friend, and congrats again on the PSA. U deserve it. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Good luck Consult1. Lots of good advice and ideas from u and other forum brothers. About the only thing I would add is that I didn't end up using 75% of the stuff I bought. Main components.... big bag for the catheter situation, and a long rope or line so if u want to lie down, it won't get caught. Baggy shorts like those athletic ones. They have the pockets to hook the line in when u walk. Comfortable place to sit/ recline. Wishing u all the best. Looking forward to hearing good news. MM

Posts.Content: Hello Fire: It is my understanding that PSA MAY not a good indicator for ductal PC. Many times ductal will not give off any ( or little) PSA and hence the disease becomes advanced before one begins treatment. I have read that after DX, many docs are using scans to monitor the situation. Perhaps others with more knowledge will chime in soon. Wishing u the best, MM

Posts.Title: Just got great news!

Posts.Content: Hey Rob: First, I just wanted to say best of luck with all that you and your wife are going thru. U both are great examples of a couple who are there for each other, for better or worse. Bad enough what you have endured, but then to have you wife ill just seems all wrong! Praying for both of you each day. Now to your post. You had RP. What was your level of continence at the six month mark? I had surgery in Dec. of 2015. I am a fellow pT3B. By the 4-5 month mark, I was about a 9 on the scale of 10. Then I had SRT/HT, and I went back a bit to where I am now, about 7/8. One pad a day, unless i am working out, then it gets bad. My Uro told me that I will not know my situation until later this year. Almost 2 years after. Did u ever regain any continence? Just curious, and I guess what i am saying is don't give up. Keep working on it! Best of luck to u and your wife. MM

Posts.Title: Overthinking? LOL

Posts.Content: Hello Cubs: As you can see from my signature, I am now also at Loyola. I would be following your RO, not the surgeon. His job is over, at this stage u should be consulting with a RO and possibly a MO if u want a second opinion. The surgeon does just that, the rest of your treatment path at this time has little to do with him. As far as Casodex and Lupron for now, that sounds about right. You are now entering a full hormonal blockade. Some RO will keep u on the Casodex for the duration of the time u are receiving SRT. No real right or wrong way after that time frame is up. As it pertains to the SE, u can expect them to rear their ugly head in about 4 weeks. Hang tough, u will get thru this and if I can be of any help, feel free to PM at anytime. Best, MM
