Posts.Title: Follow up on the rise in my PSA

Posts.Content: Hello Bass: Welcome to the forum. Could you create a signature and tell us more about your case? PSA history, any and all treatments you have received, G score, etc. If you are currently on ADT, the scans and appointments for now probably won't have as much meaning as they will when you get off of it. For now, your PSA is being suppressed. Need more information to help u. What is GcMAF? I am not familiar with that. The ADT that u are on is known as front line HT. There are more in the event that you become CR to them. The hell with any doctor who will not help you or not answer any reasonable question. They are not always right, and many of them do not know a damn thing other than exactly what their specialty is. I would show them the door, and leave no stone unturned in finding a doctor who will show you the proper consideration. Let us know . Best, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Jennifer. Sorry to hear of your father's troubles. You don't say what you dads PSA history has been, but his current PSA of .02 is very good news. It means that he is responding to treatment. That's a good thing. Is it a smoke screen? No, not really. It is showing that the 1st and 2nd line treatments that have been available to him are working. His PSA is telling u that. Was the mass from his bladder related to the PCa? Or are you saying that he also had bladder cancer? Not to many G10 guys, but plenty of G8/9, myself included. Hopefully others will be along to chime in, and perhaps you can give us a few more answers regarding his bladder. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Vanessa: Sorry to hear about your father. The Side effects that you are describing are very common with HT/ ADT. You said that your father stopped the shots about a month ago. Lupron has a half life equal to at least half the time he has been/was on it, many times much longer. He needs to be seeing a top MO right away, as there are many other hormone treatments that can help you father, and keep him around for many years. If you would care to post his stats, it may help us in seeing what his case is. Please keep us posted, and remember that you need to be in the care of a MO, right away. Best, MM

Posts.Title: I'm that guy

Posts.Content: Cubs: What they are offering you is pretty much standard of care for your case. ( not sure about the ductal component and how that would change things) given your PM and G9, Im surprised that it will only be a 6 month course. Most of us in this risk category find ourselves in the 18-24 month camp. There are several schools of thought on length of ADT, you could possibly discuss this with your RO. I would ask to start the ADT right away, as it will hold the cancer at bay while you get the RT in order. You dont want your PSA going any higher while you wait for RT to begin. Some RO will start u on Casodex for a few weeks to prevent testosterone flare, and keep u on it the entire time u are on the LHRH ( lupron). Others will just omit the Casodex after a few months. No right or wrong way there, just different RO ways of doing things. Its not easy, but u will make it thru. As for the clinical trial, no opinion on that. May depend on the amount of radiation u are receiving, along with any boost that might occur to the PLN. Wishing u the best possible outcome, MM

Posts.Title: What strength of viagra or cialis can i use?

Posts.Content: Hello Mike: I am also 2 years out, and I have tried the injections and the pills to try and keep up penile rehab. Nothing has worked, and as you have said the injections became much to painful. If u are using trimix, one of the 3 drugs is the one that causes the pain. Try having you doctor change the dose on that one, it may provide some relief from the ache. As for the pills, I would be taking 100mg every other day and not just taking the drug, but u must have the stimulation by whatever means necessary. Working the tissues! U do not have a signature, so I do not know the extent of your treatment for the PCa. In my case, it may just be a penile implant will be the only thing that works. Which ever brand of pills you decide, I would up the dose to what I told u. BTW...there is a pharmacy in MI that you can get the the active ingredient in Viagra ( sildenafil) 100 20mg pills for around $75. You will need a RX. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Content: EMS: If your question is can inflammation of the prostate affect the free PSA as well as the PSA level the answer is yes. Free PSA is just that, floating around and not attached to any proteins. It will clear out of the bloodstream quicker because it is a smaller cell or I guess molecule, thus returning to it's true level faster than PSA. Hang in there and pump the brakes!! You are going to be just fine and those kids of yours will enjoy having Dad around for many, many, years. My guess is this is a infection, given all you have told us. you are not alone. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: Hello jls85: Thanks for checking back in with the pathology report on your SO. Well, it is not what we want to hear, and it is a difficult dx. That being said there is reason for hope. U can still be cured, and this report is not insurmountable. U do not say what the final staging is, so I am going to assume u are a G8 with a T3 tumor. With any 5 component G score, it increases the odds for micro-metastasis. That all being said, I would take the pro-active approach with this. I would not wait until October for my first PSA. That is 12 weeks. Given your PSA, the half-life will be taken into account by 6-7 weeks, and you should have a good indication of where you stand. I would also be getting my ducks in a row with a RO. Do it now. You may not need it, but I would not be wasting any time. With your pathology, your Uro wants your 1st test at 12 weeks? Your Uro's job is now over, and I would go and speak with a RO. Do not ask a Uro surgeon about radiation, they don't know a damn thing. Take a aggressive approach and throw everything at this including the kitchen sink. IF...you find yourself needing additional treatment, you will have a small window to act. Cancer takes no days off. For now just heal. SRT has few SE. It will depend upon where u are at with ED and continence at that point in time. More on all that later. If u need to talk more or are in need of greater detail, PM me or just ask. Best, MM

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: Hello Moonshadow: Welcome to the forum. Sorry to hear about your fathers tough Dx. Now that the cancer has escaped and gone to his hips and spine, a cure will not be possible. I'm happy to report that is all the bad news. The good news? Many stage 4 men can get this under control and live for many, many years. The ADT will act to stop the cancer while your Dad remains hormone sensitive. This will be his front line hormone therapy. It also should knock the hell out of his PSA and send it plummeting. The EBRT will help control the cancer and the pain. It should be noted that the PCa survival rate for the next 5 years is very high. There are a host of second line hormonal treatments, and other treatments beyond those. Many new things coming down the pike for advanced cases. There is hope. I have seen men with PSA numbers in the thousands that are around for a long time. Life will be different on ADT, but it's manageable. Your father is lucky to have you in his corner. Make sure your team consists of a top notch RO and MO. If the mets get tough, they can also spot radiate. Hang around, others will be chiming in soon. Summing up, although a cure may not be possible, there are many options to keep your dad around for years. Keep us posted. BTW....... u a Cat Stevens fan? I'm being followed by a moonshadow......MM

Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Rob: I am glad to hear that u have sought out the proper medical attention. My ex-wife had a history of depression in her family, and it entered into our lives after about 10 years of marriage. The next 10 years were an absolute shit show. I have first hand knowledge of what u are going thru, and please follow the doctors orders to the letter, it will help on the road to your recovery. My ex thought she knew more than the doctors, and that made things even worse. You discussed in paragraph 3 the relationship between cancer and depression, giving out some stats. To be honest, none of that surprises me. I think most of us have those feelings, it's just a matter of degree. The symptoms that u have described were a clear cry for help. Not sure what the hell your doctor was thinking. In another thread and post, I made the comment that this disease was depressing, and that I have my darker moments. I feel that this is quite normal. I mean think about it, your life gets turned upside down. This has happened to me at a young age. Not only did I get PCa, but I fell into a sub-group of 15% of the men DX who have a high-risk case. Christ, if that doesn't get a person down, you must have ice flowing thru your veins. My life has been forever changed. What to do about it? I guess I am from the school that things are what they are. I did not ask for this stinking disease. I did not engage in any behavior that would have made me anymore likely to get it. It has happened, and my future will depend on how I react to it. I have done all I can do to give myself the best chance at a possible cure/ long term remission. I have been pro-active. I have left no stone unturned. Knowing all this, I just move along. When I think about it, I am not depressed. I'm just PISSED off! LOL! The flip side for me is that I have been a over achiever in life, and have received far more than I have deserved. I guess the wheel is round, and what lies in front of me I will deal with. I have refused to let this rotten disease run my life. I'm back in the game of life, and doing whatever the hell I want. Don't be hard on yourself. As I read your paragraph on the well, I had a few days like that. It's ok to feel whatever way u want, and you don't need to worry about what anybody thinks, feels, or says. Your particular case is even harder than most, and adding your wife into the mix, I think you are doing just fine. Your contributions to this forum have been many, add that up with your compassion to the other men on here, and I see a great guy who has had a rough time. Stay focused, take the medication, stay the course. There will be better days ahead, and you will conquer these demons. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Hello jls85: Thanks for checking back in with the pathology report on your SO. Well, it is not what we want to hear, and it is a difficult dx. That being said there is reason for hope. U can still be cured, and this report is not insurmountable. U do not say what the final staging is, so I am going to assume u are a G8 with a T3 tumor. With any 5 component G score, it increases the odds for micro-metastasis. That all being said, I would take the pro-active approach with this. I would not wait until October for my first PSA. That is 12 weeks. Given your PSA, the half-life will be taken into account by 6-7 weeks, and you should have a good indication of where you stand. I would also be getting my ducks in a row with a RO. Do it now. You may not need it, but I would not be wasting any time. With your pathology, your Uro wants your 1st test at 12 weeks? Your Uro's job is now over, and I would go and speak with a RO. Do not ask a Uro surgeon about radiation, they don't know a damn thing. Take a aggressive approach and throw everything at this including the kitchen sink. IF...you find yourself needing additional treatment, you will have a small window to act. Cancer takes no days off. For now just heal. SRT has few SE. It will depend upon where u are at with ED and continence at that point in time. More on all that later. If u need to talk more or are in need of greater detail, PM me or just ask. Best, MM

Posts.Title: One Down. First PSA Post RP

Posts.Content: EMS: If your question is can inflammation of the prostate affect the free PSA as well as the PSA level the answer is yes. Free PSA is just that, floating around and not attached to any proteins. It will clear out of the bloodstream quicker because it is a smaller cell or I guess molecule, thus returning to it's true level faster than PSA. Hang in there and pump the brakes!! You are going to be just fine and those kids of yours will enjoy having Dad around for many, many, years. My guess is this is a infection, given all you have told us. you are not alone. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Cubs: To be fair to the surgery aspect, if you talk to uro-surgeons, they shake their head no to my above post. My current surgeon at Loyola, where you are at, keeps telling me my course of treatment is the best chance for long term success. It seems with this disease that, unlike other illness, has so many different views from so many medical professionals. Example for radiation. University of Chicago and Dana Farber for SRT use a dosage of 68.4 GY, and a boost of 1.8 GY. At other big name cancer centers, it's 70-72 GY. Maybe that's why I am on ADT longer, to make up for the smaller dosage. I do know one thing....There are no bad doctors at Loyola or UC. Best, MM

Posts.Title: One Year Result, No longer zero, but in No Man's Land

Posts.Content: Hello. Your SO had surgery on the 27th of June, and the Uro is doing a PSA in 4 weeks? I'm not a doctor, but that seems to soon. There is a mathematical equation for calculating the half life of PSA. My guess is this is to soon. Moving on....Yes, the earliest would be 3 months, but it depends on the PSA. ( use the ultra test) If needed, ADT could put the brakes on cancer progression while you heal. For now pump the brakes. U don't need any secondary treatments.... until you do. U just need to be prepared. Don't take this wrong, but uro surgeons are starting to annoy me. I think u would be better served moving on to a RO. Best, MM

Stay on top of things, tell your SO he's going to beat this. It can be a tough road, but G8/ T3 can be beaten! Stay strong. MM

Posts.Content: Hello Mintlatte: Welcome to the forum. I am sorry to hear about your husband's difficult DX. Given a PSA of 6800, that would probably indicate a Stage 4 case. You say they did the biospy on a lymph node? Is this reading of 6800 a typo? Sad to report, these cases can happen. Sometimes the symptoms don't appear until it is to late for a cure. But that does not mean it can't be controlled for many years! Lets start with where do u live? If all the information u are telling us is correct, I would get straight to a MO at a major cancer center. Any exact stats you can tell us about your husband will help us answer questions. Stay strong, there are many treatments out there that can get control of this and keep your husband around for a long time. There is hope. His initial treatment plan will probably be HT/Chemo. But get us some solid info and we can go from there. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Incontinence returns

Posts.Content: 1. Had catheter removed 6 days post-op. 2.No control for about 2 months. 3. Regained some control at the 3 month mark 4. At the 5-6 month mark I was totally dry at nite , and about a 7/8 out of 10 during normal daily activity. 5. In regard to the last four questions, had no real penile problems ( not counting ED) 6. My situation changed upon the start of SRT. My continence went south. Wonderful. Especially during physical activities. I now find myself dry during my job ( desk) and walking around the house stuff. Golf, changing a pad every six holes. Walking the course and swinging, the pad is soaked. It SUCKS! I walk four miles on non-golf days, 1 pad is soaked. IT SUCKS! Weight Lifting....1 pad soaked. Did I mention it SUCKS? Sorry guys, just venting. Been thru a billion kegals, PT, etc, etc. The beat goes on. MM

Posts.Title: Young with High PSA and Very Scared

Posts.Content: Jeff: Welcome to the forum. Sorry about the tough time that you have experienced. For what it's worth my MO from the UC has a advised me on the following: Weight Lifting and cardio activity have been proven to be very helpful. The following are what he would recommend: Soy products taken as food. Broccoli. Green tea, and pomegranate taken as food or in pill form. Told me to concentrate on those four and throw all else away. In addition, my RO will not let me take anything until SRT is completed, as some antioxidants do not mix well with RT. Once again, nice to see your big PSA drop, wishing you the best. MM

Posts.Title: Firstpost

Posts.Content: Hello Moonshadow: Welcome to the forum. Sorry to hear about your fathers tough Dx. Now that the cancer has escaped and gone to his hips and spine, a cure will not be possible. I'm happy to report that is all the bad news. The good news? Many stage 4 men can get this under control and live for many, many years. The ADT will act to stop the cancer while your Dad remains hormone sensitive. This will be his front line hormone therapy. It also should knock the hell out of his PSA and send it plummeting. The EBRT will help control the cancer and the pain. It should be noted that the PCa survival rate for the next 5 years is very high. There are a host of second line hormonal treatments, and other treatments beyond those. Many new things coming down the pike for advanced cases. There is hope. I have seen men with PSA numbers in the thousands that are around for a long time. Life will be different on ADT, but it's manageable. Your father is lucky to have you in his corner. Make sure your team consists of a top notch RO and MO. If the mets get tough, they can also spot radiate. Hang around, others will be chiming in soon. Summing up, although a cure may not be possible, there are many options to keep your dad around for years. Keep us posted. BTW....... u a Cat Stevens fan? I'm being followed by a moonshadow......MM
Posts.Title: Father with metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Rob: I am glad to hear that u have sought out the proper medical attention. My ex-wife had a history of depression in her family, and it entered into our lives after about 10 years of marriage. The next 10 years were an absolute shit show. I have first hand knowledge of what u are going thru, and please follow the doctors orders to the letter, it will help on the road to your recovery. My ex thought she knew more than the doctors, and that made things even worse. You discussed in paragraph 3 the relationship between cancer and depression, giving out some stats. To be honest, none of that surprises me. I think most of us have those feelings, it's just a matter of degree. The symptoms that u have described were a clear cry for help. Not sure what the hell your doctor was thinking. In another thread and post, I made the comment that this disease was depressing, and that I have my darker moments. I feel that this is quite normal. I mean think about it, your life gets turned upside down. This has happened to me at a young age. Not only did I get PCa, but I fell into a sub-group of 15% of the men DX who have a high-risk case. Christ, if that doesn't get a person down, you must have ice flowing thru your veins. My life has been forever changed. What to do about it? I guess I am from the school that things are what they are. I did not ask for this stinking disease. I did not engage in any behavior that would have made me anymore likely to get it. It has happened, and my future will depend on how I react to it. I have done all I can do to give myself the best chance at a possible cure/ long term remission. I have been pro-active. I have left no stone unturned. Knowing all this, I just move along. When I think about it, I am not depressed. I'm just PISSED off! LOL! The flip side for me is that I have been a over achiever in life, and have received far more than I have deserved. I guess the wheel is round, and what lies in front of me I will deal with. I have refused to let this rotten disease run my life. I'm back in the game of life, and doing whatever the hell I want. Don't be hard on yourself. As I read your paragraph on the well, I had a few days like that. It's ok to feel whatever way u want, and you don't need to worry about what anybody thinks, feels, or says. Your particular case is even harder than most, and adding your wife into the mix, I think you are doing just fine. Your contributions to this forum have been many, add that up with your compassion to the other men on here, and I see a great guy who has had a rough time. Stay focused, take the medication, stay the course. There will be better days ahead, and you will conquer these demons. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Now What: Interesting comment on who it means more to. On Saturday nite I was with my girlfriend and after a few Tito's martinis, dinner, a bottle of wine, and a after dinner drink, we decided to give it a try. ( we were not driving) We have both found humor to get us thru this. Using the pills, but not much happening yet. After all the gymnastics of getting ready, it was a flop!! But, we laughed. She affectionately calls me JPP.....Johnny pee pee pants!! Even though the sex didn't work, we still are having fun being together until it does. I think it means way more to me than her. She doesn't care, she just loves me. ( As long as she can still go shopping for all her stuff) LOL! My point: have fun together and tell hubby not to be hard on himself. It's way to early in the game to get down. Stay positive and be there for each other. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Mintlatte: Welcome to the forum. I am sorry to hear about your husband's difficult DX. Given a PSA of 6800, that would probably indicate a Stage 4 case. You say they did the biospy on a lymph node? Is this reading of 6800 a typo? Sad to report, these cases can happen. Sometimes the symptoms don't appear until it is to late for a cure. But that does not mean it can't be controlled for many years! Lets start with where do u live? If all the information u are telling us is correct, I would get straight to a MO at a major cancer center. Any exact stats you can tell us about your husband will help us answer questions. Stay strong, there are many treatments out there that can get control of this and keep your husband around for a long time. There is hope. His initial treatment plan will probably be HT/Chemo. But get us some solid info and we can go from there. Good luck, MM

I would just go back to using the same test as u have been. You are a lower risk case, and the uPSA just causes u additional worry. Chart those results, and see what happens. Using the same assay allows u to avoid these types of situations. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: New to Forums! 56 Year old with stage IV prostate cancer (bone mets)

Posts.Content: Rob. Sorry for what you are going through. It seems like there are so many issues on so many different levels. I like the idea of the support group offered by Another. Venting and talking and letting the anger out are very natural things. Especially given all that's going on in your life. Like another im divorced, so I understand the lonely part of the relationship that u referred to. As time passes, things got better for me. Don't give up on yourself, your wife/ relationship, or your treatments. Stay the course, it's tough now but the AUS from what I've read can be a life changer. We all get down, it's the nature of this beast. Try to engage your wife into taking walks, spending some time together. You guys have come far together, find ways to reconnect. Keep me posted, stay strong. MM
Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Cubs: Having been through all this mess, I think I would have gone a different route. I agree with Fairwind. If you need to go through what men like you and I have/will, I would choose the radiation path. Both surgery and radiation will "de-bulk"the tumor. The side effects of surgery, radiation, and ADT are tough. Really tough. No need to go through it twice. In addition the outcomes for Brachy, IMRT, and ADT combined seem to do better long-term for us high risk guys. The only fly in your case is the intraductal PCa component. Not sure how that figures in. Check out this link I found during my readings. Best, MM https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...-or-ebrt-only/

Posts.Content: Cubs: Having been through all this mess, I think I would have gone a different route. I agree with Fairwind. If you need to go through what men like you and I have/will, I would choose the radiation path. Both surgery and radiation will "de-bulk"the tumor. The side effects of surgery, radiation, and ADT are tough. Really tough. No need to go through it twice. In addition the outcomes for Brachy, IMRT, and ADT combined seem to do better long-term for us high risk guys. The only fly in your case is the intraductal PCa component. Not sure how that figures in. Check out this link I found during my readings. Best, MM https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...-or-ebrt-only/

Posts.Content: 1. Had catheter removed 6 days post-op. 2.No control for about 2 months. 3. Regained some control at the 3 month mark 4. At the 5-6 month mark I was totally dry at nite , and about a 7/8 out of 10 during normal daily activity. 5. In regard to the last four questions, had no real penile problems ( not counting ED) 6. My situation changed upon the start of SRT. My continence went south. Wonderful. Especially during physical activities. I now find myself dry during my job ( desk) and walking around the house stuff. Golf, changing a pad every six holes. Walking the course and swinging, the pad is soaked. It SUCKS! I walk four miles on non-golf days, 1 pad is soaked. IT SUCKS! Weight Lifting....1 pad soaked. Did I mention it SUCKS? Sorry guys, just venting. Been thru a billion kegals, PT, etc, etc. The beat goes on. MM

Posts.Content: Keto: I would be asking about whether or not you should be starting ADT. Since the PCa has gone at least into the SV, that treatment phase may be in your future. If so, better to start ASAP. This way the cancer will remain on hold and not advance any, while you decide on a treatment path. I would be asking about which treatment ( or co-treatments) would present the least amount of SE. You are probably facing Surgery+Radiation+ADT...or IMRT+Brachy+HT. Ask about odds for a cure and long term cancer control. You did have 43 cores, and only 4 positive. And u are G7. A cure could still be possible, but u need to take action now. I would ask about length of time on ADT, and what the standard of treatment is for u. I think your are located in Europe? Is that correct? Sometimes treatments are different overseas. You want an aggressive approach, so with SVI u also want to treat the local PLN. Good luck, keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Firstpost

Posts.Content: Hey 1000: Welcome to the forum, sorry that your situation brings u here. For now, just take it one thing at a time. It is quite normal to be scared, and the entire beginning of this PCa mess can be very unnerving. Since at this point u don't know anything, step one is to get to the URO and start the process. U are correct, a PSA of 29 might mean some cancer, but please keep in mind that most of the PCa Dx are very curable. Since u have other issues going on, your psa spike could be related to something else, no way of telling until you see the Uro. I would start with working on a few of your other health issues, and get moving on this ASAP. Your first appt.?.......probably a DRE, and then I would guess either some antibiotics and/or scheduling a biopsy. Hang in there, as the days move on, things will become clearer...Please keep us posted. MM

Posts.Content: Cubs: To be fair to the surgery aspect, if you talk to uro-surgeons, they shake their head no to my above post. My current surgeon at Loyola, where you are at, keeps telling me my course of treatment is the best chance for long term success. It seems with this disease that, unlike other illness, has so many different views from so many medical professionals. Example for radiation. University of Chicago and Dana Farber for SRT use a dosage of 68.4 GY, and a boost of 1.8 GY. At other big name cancer centers, it's 70-72 GY. Maybe that's why I am on ADT longer, to make up for the smaller dosage. I do know one thing....There are no bad doctors at Loyola or UC. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: 1. Had catheter removed 6 days post-op. 2.No control for about 2 months. 3. Regained some control at the 3 month mark 4. At the 5-6 month mark I was totally dry at nite , and about a 7/8 out of 10 during normal daily activity. 5. In regard to the last four questions, had no real penile problems ( not counting ED) 6. My situation changed upon the start of SRT. My continence went south. Wonderful. Especially during physical activities. I now find myself dry during my job ( desk) and walking around the house stuff. Golf, changing a pad every six holes. Walking the course and swinging, the pad is soaked. It SUCKS! I walk four miles on non-golf days, 1 pad is soaked. IT SUCKS! Weight Lifting....1 pad soaked. Did I mention it SUCKS? Sorry guys, just venting. Been thru a billion kegals, PT, etc, etc. The beat goes on. MM

Posts.Title: Hello Again and Zero Club Renewal

Posts.Content: Hello: You don't say what his post-op Gleason score was? If it was a G6, I would be less worried than the presence of any pattern 4 cells. In any event, the trend is going in the wrong direction. If necessary, SRT has the greatest odds of success when your PSA is the lowest. Studies have shown that it is the single most deciding factor. I would be talking to a RO and getting that opinion....many uros have the annoying habit of waiting....and waiting....and waiting. Can't hurt to get your ducks in a row, just in case. Best to you and your husband. MM

Posts.Title: Update and question

Posts.Content: Hey 1000: Welcome to the forum, sorry that your situation brings u here. For now, just take it one thing at a time. It is quite normal to be scared, and the entire beginning of this PCa mess can be very unnerving. Since at this point u don't know anything, step one is to get to the URO and start the process. U are correct, a PSA of 29 might mean some cancer, but please keep in mind that most of the PCa Dx are very curable. Since u have other issues going on, your psa spike could be related to something else, no way of telling until you see the Uro. I would start with working on a few of your other health issues, and get moving on this ASAP. Your first appt.?.......probably a DRE, and then I would guess either some antibiotics and/or scheduling a biopsy. Hang in there, as the days move on, things will become clearer...Please keep us posted. MM

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: Alex: Your father is lucky to have such a wonderful, caring daughter. Don't put to much into the survival statistics. They vary greatly from one case to another. There are many men in your father's situation who live for many, many years. Today's treatments can control the cancer for long periods of time. Lots of new stuff coming down the pike. Make sure your dad is seeing a top MO at a major cancer center. ( if possible) Don't give up hope or assume the worst, there are lots of options out there. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Hello Again and Zero Club Renewal

Posts.Content: Hello Sheldon: while you are on ADT, a sexual relationship becomes almost impossible. While you may find that the mechanism still works, as time passes by you will probably not even care. Many men ( myself included) try the pills, pump, shots... u can see a doctor to get a view of all that, and see if something can work for u. To be honest, I found sex on ADT to be more of a bother. Sorry, just being honest. Talk to your partner and let her know thats its difficult. Those who have never experienced ADT have no idea. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Lupron and libido

Posts.Content: Another: With respect to u I will make the following comments: I lost my libido shortly after I started ADT. It still has not returned, and I am not depressed. I try my best to lead a normal life, while knowing I have been dealing with a high risk case of PCa. Your second statement is more of a problem for me. I had zero problems sexually before my "triple play" of treatments. My sexual arousal and attraction disappeared when I began ADT, I doubt that it was a just a coincidence. My question....what do u think I should be blaming? Lots of respect for u and your contributions to the forum, you are mostly right about so many things. Please enlighten me. MM

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: Hello Mike. Welcome back. All things considered, your .3 PSA is not all bad. Nice to see it drop. So far, the treatments seem to be working. SRT side effects can vary from person to person. For some it went smoothly, for others, not so much. Of my 38 treatments, happened about 10 times, my big issue had to do with the full bladder ( moving it out of the field of radiation) and the ability to not burst while waiting for the machine. Had some intense moments, but made it through. U will need to be able to time things, and develop a feel for it as you begin. The ride home was a situation where I had to pee, so I always made sure of my route and where to stop. The urinary issues were the big thing. Lots of having to rush to the bathroom. I had my treatments the last time they had each day, 415. I made sure of no traffic by doing this, as I lived in opposite direction of the flow. These are all the things I thought about to make it easier. Also have them give u lotion for skin burn. It's a pain, but manageable. Let me know if I can help. Best, MM
Posts.Title: Mike A Update

Posts.Content: Hey 1000: Welcome to the forum, sorry that your situation brings u here. For now, just take it one thing at a time. It is quite normal to be scared, and the entire beginning of this PCa mess can be very unnerving. Since at this point u don't know anything, step one is to get to the URO and start the process. U are correct, a PSA of 29 might mean some cancer, but please keep in mind that most of the PCa Dx are very curable. Since u have other issues going on, your psa spike could be related to something else, no way of telling until you see the Uro. I would start with working on a few of your other health issues, and get moving on this ASAP. Your first appt.?.......probably a DRE, and then I would guess either some antibiotics and/or scheduling a biopsy. Hang in there, as the days move on, things will become clearer...Please keep us posted. MM

Just a bigger project. Best, MM

Posts.Title: 3+ 4 and 4+3 - Is there REALLY a Difference?

Posts.Content: Hello: You don't say what his post-op Gleason score was? If it was a G6, I would be less worried than the presence of any pattern 4 cells. In any event, the trend is going in the wrong direction. If necessary, SRT has the greatest odds of success when your PSA is the lowest. Studies have shown that it is the single most deciding factor. I would be talking to a RO and getting that opinion....many uros have the annoying habit of waiting....and waiting....and waiting. Can't hurt to get your ducks in a row, just in case. Best to you and your husband. MM

Posts.Title: Lupron and libido

Posts.Content: Hello Sspanda: Welcome to the forum, sorry to hear of your father's situation. I am not sure where you live or who is in charge of your dad's treatment, but one thing that stands out is the inaction that has taken place since his surgery. I have noticed that urologist's tend to wait...and wait...and wait. My first suggestion would be to see a MO. Is you dad still on HT? If not, and assuming that his PCa is still hormone sensitive, that would probably be the first thing. ( Just going back on Lupron or Firmagon) There are other treatments when Firmagon and Lupron no longer work. A qualified MO will be able to guide u. Many of these second and third line hormones can give you years of a durable remission. IMO, your current medical team has done you no favors. Your 2/3 month post-op PSA was .11. Why would they wait until November to begin treatment? Another option...I had a phone conversation with a man who was kind of in this same boat. He lives in the south. He had one bone met, and had it radiated I think at the Dattoli Cancer center in south Florida. Now this is not a cure, and most often was or is done to control the pain. But this man told me he wanted to just do this to in his mind, control things. He did say that they give you a Free phone consultation, so what do u have to lose? Once PCa has metastasized, there is no cure. But with prompt treatment and action, your father could have many quality years left. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Treatment options for metastases post Radical Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hello livin. Welcome to the forum. No need to panic, but definitely time to act. I'm not quite clear on your posted information. Are you saying he has been on AS with a G7 4+3 in four cores? Or was all this just discovered and there was a biopsy some time ago? I'm counting 9 positive cores on this biopsy, is that correct? What were his original findings, if any? I would agree with Brother Rob Lee that radiation is probably his best bet given his age. You need to have both a CT scan and a bone scan before any treatment decisions can be made. Given the amount of cancer he has, and his age, I would be seeing a RO pronto. If this is caught early enough, a cure is still possible. Please keep us posted on his progress, and please know that your husband will be around for many years. Good luck. MM

Posts.Title: Doc says time to do something.

Posts.Content: Gail: Now here is a subject I can comment on. I had a few similar feelings about some of the doctors that I have encountered during this mess. ( Some folks call this a journey, I will use the term mess!! lol) Patient care seems to be handled more by the "staff" than by the actual doctor. I can't tell u some of the frustration I have encountered. These "staff members" just seem to think every case is the same. " See you in 3 months, see you in six months, let's make a appointment for your yearly PSA" Really? What about if I have a problem? Oh, contact us on mychart. Gee, thanks for nothing. I went to several different doctors until I found one who could actually return a damn EM or phone call. They seem to forget that they work for us. Without the patient, they are worthless. I'm on a roll!!! I have FIRED a few doctors and met with several until I became comfortable with who was treating me. If your current doctor has only 5 minutes for u, or can't return a call or EM in a reasonable amount of time, find a new doctor. I have been my own advocate in this medical mess. If I did not like what I was hearing, I kept digging. Thanks to this FORUM, I have been able to stay ahead of the game in my treatment. This approach has led me to my current RO, who is great. Totally on the top of her game. Carries her I-phone around with her, you get an answer in 15 minutes. Keep searching for someone who wants to take a interest in u, they are out there. Say hello to Cliff. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Sheldon: while you are on ADT, a sexual relationship becomes almost impossible. While you may find that the mechanism still works, as time passes by you will probably not even care. Many men ( myself included) try the pills, pump, shots... u can see a doctor to get a view of all that, and see if something can work for u. To be honest, I found sex on ADT to be more of a bother. Sorry, just being honest. Talk to your partner and let her know thats its difficult. Those who have never experienced ADT have no idea. Good luck, MM

Posts.Content: Dave: I would agree with RobLee. There have been enough studies to now know that the combination of HT/SRT is far more effective than SRT alone. All that is left to debate is the length of time one is on it. And yes, this has become the standard of care. If u are going to go thru the RT, my view is to throw everything at the cancer before more time passes by. If u have any "stray cells" out there that are not local, the ADT will at least give u a chance at killing them off. They think this is possible, but not totally sure. Without ADT, this is not possible. Just my view.....best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Hey wbigs: Welcome to the forum. Hope we can be of help to you, lots of good people on this site. A few questions/comments come to mind. I am not sure why your doctor would tell you that basically the PCa was all contained to the prostate gland. No way he could know that at this point in time. There has been no microscopic examination. Enhanced imaging can give you a real good clue, but many times upon examination things turn out differently. The good news is that with your low PSA, it's more than likely that it is contained and is 100% curable. Please remember that each case is different, and your father's and uncle's PCa is really of no relevance to yours. There is a family/bloodline link, but as far as what method of treatment and case outcomes, they are not the same. Not trying to discourage you in any way, just kind of keeping you in the loop. Try and get us more information, and we will all be here for u. With your low PSA and young age, I am sure this was caught in time for a complete recovery. We are glad you jumped in and joined the group. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Dave: I would agree with RobLee. There have been enough studies to now know that the combination of HT/SRT is far more effective than SRT alone. All that is left to debate is the length of time one is on it. And yes, this has become the standard of care. If u are going to go thru the RT, my view is to throw everything at the cancer before more time passes by. If u have any "stray cells" out there that are not local, the ADT will at least give u a chance at killing them off. They think this is possible, but not totally sure. Without ADT, this is not possible. Just my view.....best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Gail: Now here is a subject I can comment on. I had a few similar feelings about some of the doctors that I have encountered during this mess. ( Some folks call this a journey, I will use the term mess!! lol) Patient care seems to be handled more by the "staff" than by the actual doctor. I can't tell u some of the frustration I have encountered. These "staff members" just seem to think every case is the same. " See you in 3 months, see you in six months, let's make a appointment for your yearly PSA" Really? What about if I have a problem? Oh, contact us on mychart. Gee, thanks for nothing. I went to several different doctors until I found one who could actually return a damn EM or phone call. They seem to forget that they work for us. Without the patient, they are worthless. I'm on a roll!!! I have FIRED a few doctors and met with several until I became comfortable with who was treating me. If your current doctor has only 5 minutes for u, or can't return a call or EM in a reasonable amount of time, find a new doctor. I have been my own advocate in this medical mess. If I did not like what I was hearing, I kept digging. Thanks to this FORUM, I have been able to stay ahead of the game in my treatment. This approach has led me to my current RO, who is great. Totally on the top of her game. Carries her I-phone around with her, you get an answer in 15 minutes. Keep searching for someone who wants to take a interest in u, they are out there. Say hello to Cliff. Best wishes, MM

Just a bigger project. Best, MM

Posts.Title: 3+ 4 and 4+3 - Is there REALLY a Difference?

Posts.Content: Hey Aldeny. For what it's worth, I would not put it off for much longer if you want some success down the road. According to my doctor, penile rehab should begin at the earliest possible time. I have been taking 100mg of sildenafil ( active ingredient in Viagra) 3x per week since my surgery. It is very important to keep the blood flowing. I am also on the shots, but waited on that until the 3-4 month post-op time frame. I get the pills from a pharmacy in Michigan, very cheap. Your doctor would have to call it in for you, but its 60 20mg pills for about 58 dollars. They work the same as the expensive stuff. My University of Chicago uro uses them. Don't give up, it takes time. I'm not there yet, but seeing some signs of life. PM me if needed. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: So, tomorrow is my 9 month surgery anniversary.....

Posts.Content: Congrats Ron! Truth is, none of us really knows what lies ahead. As many on this site have pointed out, no two cases are alike. That's why I stopped comparing my situation with someone else's. Yes, I was dealt a tough hand. But, things could be much worse. Just go to a few of the other cancer sites on here. Brings tears to my eyes. I think we all are lucky to at least have legitimate hope. Lots of good things coming down the pipe for prostate cancer. Hell, there may even be a vaccine by the time my son is 40. (He's 22). Enjoy the good moments, and congrats on a great result. Wishing you the best possible outcome. MM

Posts.Title: After davinci RP for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hey Red. I am assuming that u are talking about Casadex. That is given by some RO prior to taking Lupron to avoid what is called testosterone Flare. That is why they are giving that to you for now. It may only last for about 4 months until the end of ART. Most RO at that point just let you continue on with lupron. To that end, I really can't see why you are stuck in this Zytiga thing. It is VERY expensive, and without proper medical coverage, can be financially devastating. Plus, u don't need it now. I think your doctors have you on the correct path. I know your head is spinning, I've been there. You seem to be doing all the right things, and you will not know anything regarding your cure potential for a long while. Remain optimistic, all your numbers right now look pretty good. Stay in the present. U have a decent chance at a very favorable outcome. Congrats on the kids, much to be proud of. Nice to see stories of our children's success. Remember, you are not alone. Best, MM

Posts.Title: New to all of this

Posts.Content: Max: Hope you are feeling better. What's going on with ur PSA is probably quite simple. They, or the surgery, didn't get it all. Basically you are a pt3a with NO. Good news? Your Gleason score was downgraded to 3+4. That's excellent news. Your PSA at this point should be undetectable. Pardon my straight talk. A PSA at your stage of .5-.6 needs to be dealt with while the cancer is at its weakest. I would be seeking out a RO to discuss the next steps. My guess is some sort of HT plus SRT is in your future. On a positive note, it is still probably local, which means decisive action right now can still produce a cure. I would be seeking to make a game plan now, while u are still healing. The RO can start a short course of ADT to hold the remaining cancer at bay. Then u can proceed. Stay strong, ur LN were negative, and your G score is minor. Studies have shown the earlier one starts ART/SRT, the better the outcome. PSA is the most significant factor to consider. Best, MM
Posts.Title: I wasn't ready for this...

Posts.Content: Thank u Ron. David: Congrats on beating back the beast! In your prior post, you said you were G8 with Lymph node involvement. Your scans are now clean. Have you talked to a RO? You may now be able to "spot" radiate or have some options in that regard. In your case, I would think you will be on ADT for 2-3 years before you get a vacation. Your medical team should be the MO and the RO. I would not be just seeing a urologist. I would not even bother asking others about their results after ADT was discontinued. Every case is different. Only one thing is for sure...when you go off of it, you are on the clock. That's when u will know. General standard of care in your case is probably at least 2 years. Good news is that your body is showing a great response. Once we can see some more information, we can go from there. What's your PSA history? Keep us posted

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Hello All. I am trying to get back into the forum, reaching out and helping others as my forum brothers did for me. It has been a helluva year. I want to apologize for my absence, lots of turmoil to deal with. Let's see.....PCa, divorce, fathers death, to name three. Wanted to say hello to all, and get back into the swing of things. To that end, today's UPSA rolled another winner. <0.05. That's as low as it gets at the UC. Wanted to let everyone know, because in the battle against this beast, we all must rejoice in the good news while we can. So for now, circle the wagons, I'm still in the game. My heartfelt thanks for all the support I have received here. Looking forward to helping others. Warmest Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Some good news

Posts.Content: Hello Redbelly. I would like to welcome you to the forum, and please feel free to ask questions of us and vent as much as u like, u are not alone. I would agree with Fairwind, you are getting way ahead of urself with the Zytiga. I believe your current course of treatments wound be standard protocol. There is no insurance company that will pay for Zytiga at this stage. You sound like a pT3bNO? If so, we have that in common. I'm on the I phone, so my signature does not show up. Look me up, u can see my signature by clicking on my name and going to one of my posts. I am very impressed by the fact that u had 34 negative lymph nodes. That is a good sign. Pump the brakes on all the other things. Just focus on the HT and the ART. You never know, u may be able to catch a cure. You have every reason to be positive, you are taking a very aggressive approach!! Stay the course, and keep your chin up. It's nice to see someone going after this with a vengeance. Well done!! Best, MM

Posts.Title: New to forum

Posts.Content: Hey Red. I am assuming that u are talking about Casadex. That is given by some RO prior to taking Lupron to avoid what is called testosterone Flare. That is why they are giving that to you for now. It may only last for about 4 months until the end of ART. Most RO at that point just let you continue on with lupron. To that end, I really can't see why you are stuck in this Zytiga thing. It is VERY expensive, and without proper medical coverage, can be financially devastating. Plus, u don't need it now. I think your doctors have you on the correct path. I know your head is spinning, I've been there. You seem to be doing all the right things, and you will not know anything regarding your cure potential for a long while. Remain optimistic, all your numbers right now look pretty good. Stay in the present. U have a decent chance at a very favorable outcome. Congrats on the kids, much to be proud of. Nice to see stories of our children's success. Remember, you are not alone. Best, MM
Posts.Title: New to forum

Posts.Content: Max: Hope you are feeling better. What's going on with ur PSA is probably quite simple. They, or the surgery, didn't get it all. Basically you are a pt3a with NO. Good news? Your Gleason score was downgraded to 3+4. That's excellent news. Your PSA at this point should be undetectable. Pardon my straight talk. A PSA at your stage of .5-.6 needs to be dealt with while the cancer is at its weakest. I would be seeking out a RO to discuss the next steps. My guess is some sort of HT plus SRT is in your future. On a positive note, it is still probably local, which means decisive action right now can still produce a cure. I would be seeking to make a game plan now, while u are still healing. The RO can start a short course of ADT to hold the remaining cancer at bay. Then u can proceed. Stay strong, ur LN were negative, and your G score is minor. Studies have shown the earlier one starts ART/SRT, the better the outcome. PSA is the most significant factor to consider. Best, MM
Posts.Title: I wasn't ready for this...

Posts.Content: Hello All: Thank u all for the kind words and responses. A special thanks to brother RobLee for taking the time to convey his own personal situation, and what I may be facing. Much appreciated. On to my appointment...My regular Uro has referred me to a Uro who just does the AUS 800 and the implant. They are both associated with Loyola Medicine in Chicago, Loyola being one of the big four in Chicago. Upon meeting me, he gave me an exam and based on my leakage, told me I was a potential candidate for the AUS 800. He said potential because not everyone is. In my case, he is worried about the SRT and the effect on the scar tissue around the now gone prostate area. He said I will need to under go a procedure in a few weeks, meaning I will be scoped and he will exam what he has to work with. He told me he will numb or freeze the area, and that I will feel nothing. During this time, I will be able to see what he is pointing out on the screen. Due to the SRT, he also said that this IS NOT a 100% solution. Right now at my desk job and daily life, I am using about 1 large pad per day. Not bad. My problem is when I exercise, golf, yard stuff, go out and have a few drinks, any sort of real activity. Then things just get bad. Rob, I'm not sure I have any other choice but to give this a shot. He told me he could improve my situation by about 75/80%, and life would improve. I liked the fact that he was honest, and told me the truth straight up. He also pointed out that these devices usually have a life of 5-10 years, all depending upon the person, etc. when the thing wears out, time to do it again. Thanks PCa...LOL! As for the penile implant, he will not do them both at the same time. He said there is to much going on with these devices, and that he wants to take one step at a time. The implant could be done 3 months after the AUS 800, assuming things go well. He did say there would be a week or so of discomfort, but after all the other treatments, so what? He did not mention the implant being bulky or awkward...good question to ask him. He did say that the AUS will, along with the implant, prevent leakage during a sexual encounter. ( fingers crossed) To Roblee's point about the sexual thing...as of now I have no interest in sex either. I was on ADT for 25 months, and will continue to feel the effects well into late 2019. If I were not in a relationship for 6 years with my GF, I would just say the hell with it. I kind of feel like I am doing it for her/us, and perhaps that is the right thing to do. IDK. Rob has given me some questions to ask when I return to the Uro on Oct 11th. Much like Rob, right now I am wondering if I will ever feel a damn thing sexually again. The beat goes on...Stay strong...MM

AgeInfo.Phrase: improve my situation by about 75 80%  and life would improve

Posts.Content: Hey Samie: I realize what a tough position you must be in. The lady in the middle of your husband and his proper care. Kind of a fine line to dance upon. SV involvement used to be a pathological finding that precluded radiation. But that was 15-20 years ago. Mostly because those cases were so much more advanced back then. PCa testing and awareness have changed dramatically since then. Many people with SV involvement are having RT today. It is not the adverse finding that it was 10-15-20 years ago. Not trying to make a mountain out of this, but I guess I'm just not clear what your surgeon is referring to. But, he is the doctor, not me. Good luck with everything Samie, and keep us posted on your progress. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Content: Hey Samie: Thank u for asking how I am doing. I am fine and moving along in hopes of a cure. I am throwing everything including the kitchen sink at my PCa. As you can see, I am also a pT3bNO. With that said, why would your surgeon say what he did about AR/SRT not being effective? How could he know that yet? Your husband was negative lymph nodes and, as of now, no metastases. Truth is, nobody knows as of now. If he were to receive AR/SRT, he would not know the answer until afterward. And depending upon HT, not until that left his system. If there was any cancer left in the prostate bed, they could kill it and he would be cured. If it already was or is in a micro-metastases state, then radiation would be futile. Again, nobody knows. "Assay" is the methodology used to calculate the PSA. Different labs have different ways of doing it. One labs undetectable might be another's whatever. With a pre-op PSA of 39 and a G8, I would be all over this like a hawk. I would want to know the exact PSA, and the method being used. And I would not wait another 3 months to be tested. Just me, I'm a pro-active guy. Talk to a RO/MO. Be your own boss. BTW, even if people like us run into stone walls, there are TX out there to keep us going for many years. And a lot coming down the pipeline. Your husband is very lucky to have such a loving and caring wife. Best regards, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Dking: Welcome to the forum. Lots of good people here to help you and your husband through the process. Not trying to scare you, but your husband is considered a high-risk case. PI means that the cancer is or has spread to the space surrounding the nerve. When found on a biopsy, it MAY suggest that the cancer has spread outside of the prostate, or has a higher chance of having done so. For now, that is the least of your concerns. Intraductal Carcinoma is not the garden variety of prostate cancer. I would suggest that you go to a major cancer center and see a specialist who has experience with IDC-P. Most PCa cases are adenocarcinoma. I would suspect that unless you go to a major cancer center, they may not be familiar with the treatment of this particular type of PCa. Keep in mind that any PCa can be cured if still contained, and many none-contained cases can be cured or successfully managed for many, many, years. Where do you live? Many of my forum brothers are standing ready to help with suggestions of the best medical facilities. Let us know how we can help. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Question about perineural invasion

Posts.Content: Hello All: Been a member since the fall of 2015, when this mess entered into my life. I don't post as much anymore, life has kind of got in the way. In addition, there are so many smart guys helping out that sometimes I feel that I am not needed as much. Today I am heading for my Appt. that is in the post title, and when I return I will post the results for all who may be interested. Given my high risk status, I was never allowed the time to heal, and having to proceed so quickly to ADT/SRT hurt my continence and ED issues. The good news is that I seem to be doing well so far, now I am just trying to get back to a bit more normal of a life. Best to all in this fight....MM

Posts.Content: Hello Samie: Not sure I would agree with what is going on. Could u provide more information? Was your husband pT3bNo Mx? Was there already lymph node involvement? What is his exact PSA? What type of "assay"? He may need aggressive treatment. AR/ SRT and/ or possible HT could possibly cure him. It is a small window that you may have, each day that goes by is another day the time frame closes. Have you spoke with a MO or a RO? Remember, your surgeons job is over. If you could provide more data, we may be able to help you. I am not saying you need to rush into radiation, he may be fine. However, most high risk cases find themselves headed in that direction. The more information you can provide, the better we can help. Best regards, MM

Posts.Title: First post-op PSA.....

Posts.Content: Hello All: Thank u all for the kind words and responses. A special thanks to brother RobLee for taking the time to convey his own personal situation, and what I may be facing. Much appreciated. On to my appointment...My regular Uro has referred me to a Uro who just does the AUS 800 and the implant. They are both associated with Loyola Medicine in Chicago, Loyola being one of the big four in Chicago. Upon meeting me, he gave me an exam and based on my leakage, told me I was a potential candidate for the AUS 800. He said potential because not everyone is. In my case, he is worried about the SRT and the effect on the scar tissue around the now gone prostate area. He said I will need to under go a procedure in a few weeks, meaning I will be scoped and he will exam what he has to work with. He told me he will numb or freeze the area, and that I will feel nothing. During this time, I will be able to see what he is pointing out on the screen. Due to the SRT, he also said that this IS NOT a 100% solution. Right now at my desk job and daily life, I am using about 1 large pad per day. Not bad. My problem is when I exercise, golf, yard stuff, go out and have a few drinks, any sort of real activity. Then things just get bad. Rob, I'm not sure I have any other choice but to give this a shot. He told me he could improve my situation by about 75/80%, and life would improve. I liked the fact that he was honest, and told me the truth straight up. He also pointed out that these devices usually have a life of 5-10 years, all depending upon the person, etc. when the thing wears out, time to do it again. Thanks PCa...LOL! As for the penile implant, he will not do them both at the same time. He said there is to much going on with these devices, and that he wants to take one step at a time. The implant could be done 3 months after the AUS 800, assuming things go well. He did say there would be a week or so of discomfort, but after all the other treatments, so what? He did not mention the implant being bulky or awkward...good question to ask him. He did say that the AUS will, along with the implant, prevent leakage during a sexual encounter. ( fingers crossed) To Roblee's point about the sexual thing...as of now I have no interest in sex either. I was on ADT for 25 months, and will continue to feel the effects well into late 2019. If I were not in a relationship for 6 years with my GF, I would just say the hell with it. I kind of feel like I am doing it for her/us, and perhaps that is the right thing to do. IDK. Rob has given me some questions to ask when I return to the Uro on Oct 11th. Much like Rob, right now I am wondering if I will ever feel a damn thing sexually again. The beat goes on...Stay strong...MM

AgeInfo.Phrase: improve my situation by about 75 80%  and life would improve

Posts.Title: To Radiate or not?

Posts.Content: Hey Samie: Thank u for asking how I am doing. I am fine and moving along in hopes of a cure. I am throwing everything including the kitchen sink at my PCa. As you can see, I am also a pT3bNO. With that said, why would your surgeon say what he did about AR/SRT not being effective? How could he know that yet? Your husband was negative lymph nodes and, as of now, no metastases. Truth is, nobody knows as of now. If he were to receive AR/SRT, he would not know the answer until afterward. And depending upon HT, not until that left his system. If there was any cancer left in the prostate bed, they could kill it and he would be cured. If it already was or is in a micro-metastases state, then radiation would be futile. Again, nobody knows. "Assay" is the methodology used to calculate the PSA. Different labs have different ways of doing it. One labs undetectable might be another's whatever. With a pre-op PSA of 39 and a G8, I would be all over this like a hawk. I would want to know the exact PSA, and the method being used. And I would not wait another 3 months to be tested. Just me, I'm a pro-active guy. Talk to a RO/MO. Be your own boss. BTW, even if people like us run into stone walls, there are TX out there to keep us going for many years. And a lot coming down the pipeline. Your husband is very lucky to have such a loving and caring wife. Best regards, MM

Posts.Content: Sudds: Hello and welcome to the forum. Just one thing to add, and comment on your last post. It is fine to talk with other family members, but each case is different. Radiation techniques and equipment have improved greatly over the years. U are in the enviable position of having time to consider all options. Nothing wrong with surgery, and we are all here to support any choice you make. But just be aware of all the SE of each treatment, and know that what happened to your family members has nothing to do with u. BCR can happen with all primary treatments. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: From one Midwest to another: Welcome to the forum, and I am happy that u are here with G6 PCa. ( would rather that u were not here at all!!) Sounds like u have a excellent doctor who has explained all the various options. A few areas of concern would be the number of positive cores, and the involvement you have. Not trying to scare u, but u have a great deal of cancer there. I hate to break the news, but there is no AS protocol on the planet that u would qualify for. I don't think any additional testing is really going to matter. Also, remember that things can get upgraded or the higher grade tumors can be missed on the biopsy. That happens over 20/25% of the time. All that being said, prompt action with your current stats could result in a cure, and getting this behind you. Wishing u the best, the forum brothers and sisters stand with u. MM

Posts.Content: Hello All: Been a member since the fall of 2015, when this mess entered into my life. I don't post as much anymore, life has kind of got in the way. In addition, there are so many smart guys helping out that sometimes I feel that I am not needed as much. Today I am heading for my Appt. that is in the post title, and when I return I will post the results for all who may be interested. Given my high risk status, I was never allowed the time to heal, and having to proceed so quickly to ADT/SRT hurt my continence and ED issues. The good news is that I seem to be doing well so far, now I am just trying to get back to a bit more normal of a life. Best to all in this fight....MM

Posts.Title: Continence and penile implant Appt

Posts.Content: Hey Samie: I realize what a tough position you must be in. The lady in the middle of your husband and his proper care. Kind of a fine line to dance upon. SV involvement used to be a pathological finding that precluded radiation. But that was 15-20 years ago. Mostly because those cases were so much more advanced back then. PCa testing and awareness have changed dramatically since then. Many people with SV involvement are having RT today. It is not the adverse finding that it was 10-15-20 years ago. Not trying to make a mountain out of this, but I guess I'm just not clear what your surgeon is referring to. But, he is the doctor, not me. Good luck with everything Samie, and keep us posted on your progress. Best Wishes, MM

There are many "cocktails" that a experienced MO who deals with advanced PCa can help you with. You just need to see that sort of MO, one who specializes in PCa with various complexities. You may still respond very well. Hang in there, and get to a new MO. Good luck. MM

Posts.Title: Wife's Chemo is finally over !!!

Posts.Content: Hello Jim. Welcome to the forum. Lots of good advice given to u by others. What stands out to me, as someone who has traveled done this road, is that u are wasting precious time. Then higher the PSA goes, the less effective the SRT will be. You have a trend which has been in place for some time. Studies have shown the PSA level is the single most important factor in the success or failure of SRT. You have beaten this beast now for 7 years, do not give up. Standing in your shoes, I would be pro-active and getting this lined up....yesterday! You are only 71, act now and you will be around for many, many , more years. What are you waiting for? Best of Luck, MM

Posts.Title: New Guy with salvage radiation questions

Posts.Content: Hello Dexter. Welcome to the forum, hopefully we can look at your case and provide some suggestions. Well first, it looks like the doctors at the VA are leaving me a bit puzzled. Why u were refused surgery, I don't know. Your bone and CT scan were clean, so I'm going to say there were no distant metastasis. Your PSA nadir was 0.49, so u went nadir plus 2 in April. Did u stop with the lupron, or is ur PSA rising while still on it? You may not be a candidate now for surgery, given the Brachytherapy and IMRT. That may not work. Anyway can u see another doctor at a cancer center and just get your drugs thru the VA? Not knowing your exact ADT status, I am wonderingly what your doctor means by stating you PSA will go down without HT. Huh? You may need to try another form of HT, second line drugs etc. My gut is telling me that u need to see a different MO for a second opinion. Start there and then worry about the prescription deal. Keep us posted, and good luck. MM
Posts.Title: Psa rising hormone therapy not working very concerned

Posts.Content: Hello Prowler. Welcome to the forum. Your first two sentences are spot on. At your current PSA level there is no need to rush, but I would be starting the process now. Make an appointment with a RO and get the ball rolling. Given your G8, I would request that I be given HT right now, thereby stopping the cancer while you investigate the process. PSA level is the single most important factor in determining outcomes from SRT. Right now u are in the " very early salvage group ". Keep it that way. I have the answers to ur last question in my notes at home. I will check in with that info later today. Stay strong. MM

Posts.Title: High PSA level - worried

Posts.Content: Zencat: To answer your 1st question, a PLND is or has become SOP. Actually, during the operation your surgeon will be taking out the lymph nodes and stopping the operation for several minutes. The dissected LN will be then viewed by the pathologist, and the report given to the surgeon. This is done during the operation. The report on your entire prostate, known as your path report, will be given to you about a week after the surgery. The implications from a negative report are good. Please keep in mind that all it really means is that the LN that were taken during the operation are negative. It says nothing about the others in the pelvic area. Your surgeon will be taking the lymph nodes that he believes would be most likely to be infected. I think it's the iliac LN. The ones that are traveling north in your body. PCa tends to move in that direction, moving towards the bone. A positive result would be another adverse factor that nobody wants. It can mean many things, none of them good. Given your profile to this point in time, I would not be overly concerned. Best Regards, MM
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Question

Posts.Content: Scott: Welcome to the forum. Hopefully your stay will be a short one. PSA varies a great deal from person to person. In today's world, many PCP will taken no action between 0-4. Doctors today are trained to look at the trend and the velocity that it is moving. 4-10 is kind of viewed as no man's land. My PSA pre-op was 5.9. It turns out that I have a high grade/risk disease. Many aggressive tumors don't put out a lot of PSA, so there is no way of knowing until u have the biopsy. Certainly with a positive DRE and a PSA over 20, something is going on. But, it may be one of several issues not related to PCa. I guess what I am saying is each case is different, so get the biopsy and go from there. I know it's hard, but try and remain calm and positive. Keep us posted on the results. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: First post-op PSA

Posts.Content: Hello Dexter. Welcome to the forum, hopefully we can look at your case and provide some suggestions. Well first, it looks like the doctors at the VA are leaving me a bit puzzled. Why u were refused surgery, I don't know. Your bone and CT scan were clean, so I'm going to say there were no distant metastasis. Your PSA nadir was 0.49, so u went nadir plus 2 in April. Did u stop with the lupron, or is ur PSA rising while still on it? You may not be a candidate now for surgery, given the Brachytherapy and IMRT. That may not work. Anyway can u see another doctor at a cancer center and just get your drugs thru the VA? Not knowing your exact ADT status, I am wonderingly what your doctor means by stating you PSA will go down without HT. Huh? You may need to try another form of HT, second line drugs etc. My gut is telling me that u need to see a different MO for a second opinion. Start there and then worry about the prescription deal. Keep us posted, and good luck. MM

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: Prowler: The latest in equipment is called Varian SCHTrueBeam. This is what I had at the University of Chicago. They are a cancer center/ teaching hospital. External Beam RT is delivered as either ( for most men) IMRT or IGRT. Intensity Modulated and Image Guided. There are a few other forms, but I am sure u will be looking at IMRT/IGRT or a combo of both. I am reading from the notes of my SRT plan, and that is what I am coming up with. Where ever u go, if this is what they are using, u are good to go. Not sure what u are near, but if u would like to tell us, perhaps some others can jump in and help out. Best of Luck, MM
Posts.Title: Best point to start SRT?

Posts.Content: Hello Prowler. Welcome to the forum. Your first two sentences are spot on. At your current PSA level there is no need to rush, but I would be starting the process now. Make an appointment with a RO and get the ball rolling. Given your G8, I would request that I be given HT right now, thereby stopping the cancer while you investigate the process. PSA level is the single most important factor in determining outcomes from SRT. Right now u are in the " very early salvage group ". Keep it that way. I have the answers to ur last question in my notes at home. I will check in with that info later today. Stay strong. MM

Posts.Title: Best point to start SRT?

Posts.Content: Hello Mike. Congrats on moving forward, you have now taken the next step on this journey to ensuring that you will have many more years! You have more than a few years left in you, you are just in the early stages of the game, with many more options and bullets to fire. Your PSA rise could be attributed to a few different factors, no better place to find out than MSK. IMHO, sitting around doing nothing is not a option. Ask questions, find answers, be aggressive with your own case. In the immortal words of T. Boone Pickens...a fool with a plan is better than a genius without one. Please keep us posted on what they have to say. Stay Strong Brother. Best, MM

Assuming what you are talking about is PCa ( what you were reading) I have never heard of anything so dire. Now, when I got my pathology report, that was painful! Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: Hello Mosserj: Just wanted to say Hi and a warm welcome to the forum. At first glance, your PC seems to be of the lower/ intermediate risk variety. That's a good thing. A PSA under 10 would probably indicate that this is a local or contained case. Also a good thing. As you said, stay calm and become your own advocate. Don't be afraid to ask questions both here and of your doctors. Get Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, the 3rd edition. ( The guide to surviving Prostate Cancer). Good read and it will help you understand the various options. Keep in mind this process is a long road with many peaks and valleys. We will be here to help you get through. My one concern with your situation is the number of cores that had PC. Meaning, you will need some sort of treatment. Don't mess around. You stand an excellent chance for a full cure. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Newbie with first results looking for comments

Posts.Content: Mike: I would agree with Fairwind. Uros have a annoying habit of waiting to long to do much of anything. I would take your case to a MO at a major cancer center. I see that u have not been on Lupron...i also would be seeing a doctor that does the uPSA. With your high risk status, I believe it is imperative. Without using the uPSA, it is hard to tell if your PSA ever really became undetectable. Assuming that you may still be hormone sensitive, lupron may still be a option. You may be finding yourself in a situation of being on intermittent HT, with the ability of taking some "vacations". There are several other hormonal drugs which may also be appropriate for your situation. Do this now while your PSA is still low. ( see the MO) I should point out that Trelstar is a LHRH, but perhaps Lupron would be more effective for u. IDK. Please keep us posted, and best of luck. MM

Many aggressive tumors don't put out a lot of PSA, so there is no way of knowing until u have the biopsy. Certainly with a positive DRE and a PSA over 20, something is going on. But, it may be one of several issues not related to PCa. I guess what I am saying is each case is different, so get the biopsy and go from there. I know it's hard, but try and remain calm and positive. Keep us posted on the results. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: 2nd opinion?

Posts.Content: Mike: from your signature I am under the impression that u have had RP, SRT, and HT. You currently have a rising PSA while u are on ADT. Given that u live in NJ, I would go to MSK, and not waste anymore time doing so. I’m not sure what your current Urologist can do for u, even with the title you mentioned. You need a top notch MO to review the case. Once in Texas, MDA would be my choice. They are at the forefront of damn near all things cancer. Stay on top of this and get moving... your current urologist may be correct in not taking any action right now, but I would rather hear that view from a MO at MSK. A rising PSA after your tri-modality of treatments requires immediate attention. Best, MM
Posts.Title: BCR after a year on ADT

Posts.Title: Still Zero

Posts.Content: Kentucky: Pump The Brakes!! You only have one core positive, and it is a G6!! Do not do anything until u speak with several doctors for opinions. You are in a ideal position, if there is such a thing. You probably will qualify under several AS Programs. Could you give us a bit more information? Family history, PSA History? DRE, etc.. I would get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book " Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". For now, DO NOT commit to anything. Any surgeon who wants to cut u open based on one G6 core......Lots to think about. Keep us posted. Best of Luck, MM

Hang in there, I'm sure u will be just fine. Good luck, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Mike: is your doctors appt. with one specialist, or more than one? If it's one, 1/2 hour should about do it. If u go in prepared, and have all your questions written out and perhaps send this specialist an EM beforehand with anything that they may need time to reflect on, u should be all set.
