Posts.Title: Shouldn't It Take Longer?

Posts.Content: Hello dimavvs: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here, but hopefully what you are experiencing is not related to PCa. Ok, first, it was a bit hard to follow what you are trying to say. I'm a bit confused about a urologist who preformed a colonoscopy? I can say that you are very young to have PCa, and also very young to have a PSA of 4.4. Seems a bit odd. PCa is a slow moving disease, so rapid spikes in PSA may indicate something else being wrong. Rather than sit here and go point by point about what you wrote, my advice would be to find a Urologist who will get to the bottom of this. Where do u live? perhaps once we find that out, folks on here can guide you to the proper place. U have listed a host of issues, my question is why is your current doc is not addressing them with the symptoms u are describing? Let's try to get u to a major medical center and solve these issues. My gut says this is not PCa, but u need to press on and find out about the bleeding, rash, etc. U have already been on Cipro once, that apparently did u very little good. Why again? Standing in your shoes, I would be aggressive in finding a urologist in a major medical center who is interested in helping you solve this problem. Hang in there, it may be nothing. As I said, you are very young to have PCa. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Shouldn't It Take Longer?

Posts.Content: Mike: I would agree with Fairwind. Uros have a annoying habit of waiting to long to do much of anything. I would take your case to a MO at a major cancer center. I see that u have not been on Lupron...i also would be seeing a doctor that does the uPSA. With your high risk status, I believe it is imperative. Without using the uPSA, it is hard to tell if your PSA ever really became undetectable. Assuming that you may still be hormone sensitive, lupron may still be a option. You may be finding yourself in a situation of being on intermittent HT, with the ability of taking some "vacations". There are several other hormonal drugs which may also be appropriate for your situation. Do this now while your PSA is still low. ( see the MO) I should point out that Trelstar is a LHRH, but perhaps Lupron would be more effective for u. IDK. Please keep us posted, and best of luck. MM

Posts.Content: 7Seas: I have been thru exactly what you are feeling. Stay calm. I was just DX on 10/1...10/7. I am going thru the process. Each day will get a bit better. U have a low-risk case of PC. I'm no expert, but from what I have learned in the past 5 weeks you are going to be just fine. This forum is a great place to ask questions and the people here are more than willing to help u along. LOTS of smart folks who are willing to reach out. Just take one day at a time. keep us posted and hang in there. Someone said this to me in a post..." You are going to be just fine". This applies to u. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: NEW GUY needs help with lab results.

Posts.Content: Kentucky: Pump The Brakes!! You only have one core positive, and it is a G6!! Do not do anything until u speak with several doctors for opinions. You are in a ideal position, if there is such a thing. You probably will qualify under several AS Programs. Could you give us a bit more information? Family history, PSA History? DRE, etc.. I would get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book " Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". For now, DO NOT commit to anything. Any surgeon who wants to cut u open based on one G6 core......Lots to think about. Keep us posted. Best of Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Searching for the right treatment

Posts.Content: Scott: Welcome to the forum. Hopefully your stay will be a short one. PSA varies a great deal from person to person. In today's world, many PCP will taken no action between 0-4. Doctors today are trained to look at the trend and the velocity that it is moving. 4-10 is kind of viewed as no man's land. My PSA pre-op was 5.9. It turns out that I have a high grade/risk disease. Many aggressive tumors don't put out a lot of PSA, so there is no way of knowing until u have the biopsy. Certainly with a positive DRE and a PSA over 20, something is going on. But, it may be one of several issues not related to PCa. I guess what I am saying is each case is different, so get the biopsy and go from there. I know it's hard, but try and remain calm and positive. Keep us posted on the results. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hello Mosserj: Just wanted to say Hi and a warm welcome to the forum. At first glance, your PC seems to be of the lower/ intermediate risk variety. That's a good thing. A PSA under 10 would probably indicate that this is a local or contained case. Also a good thing. As you said, stay calm and become your own advocate. Don't be afraid to ask questions both here and of your doctors. Get Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, the 3rd edition. ( The guide to surviving Prostate Cancer). Good read and it will help you understand the various options. Keep in mind this process is a long road with many peaks and valleys. We will be here to help you get through. My one concern with your situation is the number of cores that had PC. Meaning, you will need some sort of treatment. Don't mess around. You stand an excellent chance for a full cure. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Content: Howmany: Not much to add from what the other forum brothers have said, just wanted to welcome u to the group. FWIW, the biopsy in my case was a breeze. Highlander ( Chuck) gave me some good advice. In addition to having the general area frozen so there is no pain going in, have the doctor give the actual gland some medication. It worked very well for me. I also took a Valium 2/3 hours prior to the procedure. I took the easy way, and it worked. Best of Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Daddys PSA results and HT question :)

Posts.Content: Hey Wife. just got out myself. It sounds like they are doing all they can. The MoM should help. I had the bladder spasms which lasted around 2 hours, and the terrible constipation. Sadly, part of the game for some of us. I can only say what he is going thru is not that uncommon, and it WILL get better soon. Keep walking to get the bowels going, that worked for me. All recoveries are different, better days are ahead. Keep the MoM going, and they should be giving him some medicine to soften the stool. Don't be bashful about asking for the pain meds, nothing wrong with that. Good luck and keep us posted. MM

Posts.Title: Newbie with first results looking for comments

Posts.Content: Hey Fred: Sorry to hear of the ED situation. You have plenty of company, including yours truly. I had the same thing happen to me, and it just ruined the moment and was a complete disaster. However, better days are ahead. Just give things time and your continence will return. I think most men take up to a year to become fully dry. And by that I mean including physical activity. I am dry now, but not when I workout or play golf. Still got the small leaks. It's ok to want to scream and cry, normal human emotions. Look at it this way, you have a garden variety case of PCa. Chances are that you are now CURED!!! The most important thing is now behind you. There are many treatments for ED and your incontinence will be a thing of the past. You will have sex again, just a matter of time. Hang in there and be patient. Keep us posted on your progress. All the best, MM

Posts.Title: Surviving prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello illek: Welcome to the forum, sorry about the pathology report. What happened to u is exactly what happened to me. Are u being over treated? NO! Much like myself, u have a high risk serious case. From what I can gather, your risk is finding out about micro-mets as time goes by. Should that be the case, there is really nothing u can do about it but go into containment mode, which can last years. BUT, u may still have a chance at a cure if u throw everything at it right now! PCa takes no days off, and neither should u. Your window for a possible cure is now, using the 3 treatment whammy of RP, SRT/ART, and ADT. Why not give yourself every chance? Just my opinion. Your doctor seems to be on top of his game, they only other thing I would add is that a zero psa at this point just buys u time, u probably will not be able to avoid additional treatment. Best, MM

Posts.Title: RALP Pathology Stage T3b, Gleason 9, Invasion of Seminal Vesticles. How bad is it?

Posts.Content: Hey Gary. I did not travel to and from anywhere, but I did have the surgery and I think u are going way overboard. You will be at JH for at least one nite, and assuming all goes well will be released. U don't need 3 nites at a local hotel. I would just go home. U will have the catheter in, so u really don't need to worry about the bathroom. It will probably be a few days before u go #2, so no worries there. U won't need a wheelchair, ( I am assuming you are in otherwise good health) and any of the other items you are suggesting. Baggy shorts, bag to cover the bag, get on the plane ( couple hours?) and get back home. Example: upon checkout from the UC, I walked and carried my overnite bag. U are going to a lot of expense and trouble for nothing. Once again, all else being equal. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Month 3 PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hello Mike: Congrats on the good numbers, nice to see and bodes well at this point in time. My first question is given your status as pT3b, why is your doctor not checking u every 3 months at this point in time? Are u having the uPSA test? I would have the uPSA test and plan any possible SRT around what my PSA scores are showing. Anything above 0.03 on the uPSA scale is highly indicative of BCR, ( at least for high risk) and of course you could wait to see the trend. The best time to start SRT is early!! I would not wait much longer than .1...that is when I pulled the trigger. In your case, the target will be the prostate bed, along with what is known as the boost. ( local LN). That is really all they can do at this point. Good luck and keep us posted, MM

Posts.Title: Srt. Where do they aim/ put the tattoos ?

Posts.Content: Hello 52: Welcome to the forum. Sorry to hear of your tough DX, but please keep in mind that there are many treatments to keep u around for many years. Ok. What is your clinical staging? So your bone scan was negative, and the CT showed lymph node involvement? When you say it has spread down my legs, what exactly do you mean? They remove sample cores during a biopsy, what do u mean a tumor was removed? Just trying to get a clear picture of the situation. Even cases with +LN can be cured if caught early. Do not lose hope!! Why aren't they going to radiate? Your taking ADT will stop it in its tracks for now, there are EBRT and Brachy treatments that may offer u a cure, or a combo of both. Please give us as much information as possible, others will be chiming in soon. This game has just started, we will help u devolpe a plan. Hang in. MM

Posts.Title: Chances?

Posts.Content: Hello: Sorry to hear of your husband's past troubles, but glad you found us here at the forum. First, is the 8/2017 a typo? Seems odd that u would have that number in there. Is that correct? 73 years old is not to old for surgery, it would all depend upon the overall health of the patient. Sudden large movements would be less indicative of cancer than a slower rising trend. The only way to find out for sure if he has PCa is the biopsy. While not something that anyone looks forward to, most men get thru it without much issue. ( there are numbing jells, etc) To answer your last question, yes there are several forms of RT that are equal to surgery in hopes of a cure. To help ease your mind, please be aware that most PCa is very treatable, and with your husband's low PSA, it would suggest that he fits into this category. Please keep us posted, and good luck. MM

Posts.Content: Not totally sure about primary RT, but I believe the doses are higher than ART/ SRT. Standard of care for SRT is 68.4 GY. ( Dana Farber / University of Chicago). Some cancer centers give 70-72 GY. With today's rapid Arch machines, better control of toxicity, higher doses are being given. I've read primary RT can be up to 80GY. Perhaps someone with primary RT will chime in soon. MM

Posts.Title: Been told to go on ADT and chemo

Posts.Content: PC. As chuck points out, once u lose your prostate u no longer need to worry about sex, exercise, and various activities affecting your PSA. As far as your other question, if u are using a UPSA, the score being that low might vary a bit from lab to lab. Example, I was 0.05 six weeks out. At 12 weeks I was .1 My doctor said if we tested the 12 week score 10 times, we may get 10 different numbers. But they would all be around 0.05 to .1. Point is, the score was going north. Look for your trend, not a specific number. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Walking/Exercise Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Prato: The mind is a very powerful tool, it can be your worst or best friend. What you are going thru is quite normal, given the sequence of events that u listed in your post. I am going thru a lot of the same, wondering what the hell might be next! I get past each day by telling myself that I am dealing with the hand I have been dealt, and that I have done and will continue to do all I can to keep my feet north of the grass. I no longer worry about things out of my control. Take solace in the positive/good things in life and stay active, keeping your mind and body sharp. This may sound crazy, but PCa has made me a better person. I have a heightened level of sensitivity to other people, and to life as it pertains to what is really important. Rejoice in your kids, family and friends. In my life I have been the beneficiary of far more than I have deserved, and now because of what WE have all been thru, I can see things with a great deal of clarity. YOUR PCa is not going to get u! U GOT THIS! Stay Strong, MM

Posts.Title: Cancered Out

Posts.Content: Hello Bruce: As Chuck has stated, if u could provide a stat line, it would be most helpful in getting a better understanding of your case. In any event, the care of PCa might be different where u are at, but you should have been on ADT/Chemo some time ago. It is increasing at a rapid rate, and u need the ADT to stem the tide. Every case is different, many men live on ADT/chemo for years, others are not so lucky. Once your primary and secondary treatments failed, and your PSA reached 18.1.....that was the signal that you will probably be on HT for the duration of your life...which could be many years! There is no cure now, but you are in the "manage the disease phase". And many men do "manage" it with ADT and second/third line HT for many years. The SE are what they are, but the alternative is not so great. For now, you need to get that PSA number under control. ADT is no fun, but u can get thru it. Also, if it works, you can go off it and then back on it...again, every case is different. Good luck my friend, please keep us posted. MM

Posts.Title: Hi, New Guy.

Posts.Content: Hello Mrs. Z. As our esteemed Moderator Chuck has noted, if the cancer has remained in the prostate gland or regional area, there is hope for a cure. I am assuming his bone and CT scan were negative, otherwise they would not be offering you surgery. So on that front, good news. I also have G9, and while it has been a long road, I remain optimistic. My I phone doesn't show my signature, but click on my name and see my treatment schedule. U will see there is hope. And more than a glimmer! Ok? To answer your questions.... 1. I am single and did not have a caregiver. I am in good physical condition, so if your husband is also, you don't need to take any days off. There really is not anything for u to do. 2. Yes, he will be able to climb the stairs. It is encouraged. 3. Will he need assistance? I would say it would depend on his general health. I was a solo act 4. Don't go crazy buying things. I bought all kinds of things that the stickey told me, and found most of it to be useless. In my view, u need a recliner for the day, I slept in bed at nite. You need a big catheter bag, and a long rope attached to it. This will allow u the flexibility to move about and sleep on either side. Baggy athletic shorts, where u can hook the catheter in your pocket and walk. That's it. I had a hernia operation in 2009, much worse than PC surgery. Hang in there, and keep us posted. MM
Posts.Title: And . . . here we go!

Posts.Content: Hello Petzelhead: Sorry to hear about this tough time u are having. To answer your topic question, the side effects of hormone therapy are due to the lack of testosterone in your body. So, i am not sure that there would be much difference in the medical vs. chemical castration as it pertains to side effects. You say your in Carolina? Are you at a major medical center? Interested in knowing what was your clinical diagnoses? Why did they only take 2 lymph nodes during your surgery? I would have thought there would be a lot more taken in your case. What was your pathological staging? Your PSA, while not a large number, has seen a alarming velocity in it's movement. But, this case you present is a bit puzzling. I am surprised that your recent scans were not discovered at the beginning. Your PSA is .7. It usually takes a much higher number for these findings to show up. It's not like your PSA is now 5 or 10. What happened in the beginning of your case? Any additional information you can provide would be helpful. You should be taking some calcium supplements. Vit. D3 around 5000mg per day. Vit K2, around 100mg per day. Adva Cal Ultra. 1000 mg per day. The adva cal has many of these in the serving, so check out the label. Your physical fitness regime is something u want to keep up. You are to be applauded for the great condition u are in. This will help a great deal with ADT. Don't give up hope. Many stage 4 patients live for many, many, years. There are a boatload of front line, second line and down the line hormonal treatments. Many new things coming down the pike. Lets hope the PSA takes a nose dive when the chemo is being done. Hang in there, I will will following your posts. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Content: Prato: The mind is a very powerful tool, it can be your worst or best friend. What you are going thru is quite normal, given the sequence of events that u listed in your post. I am going thru a lot of the same, wondering what the hell might be next! I get past each day by telling myself that I am dealing with the hand I have been dealt, and that I have done and will continue to do all I can to keep my feet north of the grass. I no longer worry about things out of my control. Take solace in the positive/good things in life and stay active, keeping your mind and body sharp. This may sound crazy, but PCa has made me a better person. I have a heightened level of sensitivity to other people, and to life as it pertains to what is really important. Rejoice in your kids, family and friends. In my life I have been the beneficiary of far more than I have deserved, and now because of what WE have all been thru, I can see things with a great deal of clarity. YOUR PCa is not going to get u! U GOT THIS! Stay Strong, MM

Posts.Title: Been told to go on ADT and chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Bruce: As Chuck has stated, if u could provide a stat line, it would be most helpful in getting a better understanding of your case. In any event, the care of PCa might be different where u are at, but you should have been on ADT/Chemo some time ago. It is increasing at a rapid rate, and u need the ADT to stem the tide. Every case is different, many men live on ADT/chemo for years, others are not so lucky. Once your primary and secondary treatments failed, and your PSA reached 18.1.....that was the signal that you will probably be on HT for the duration of your life...which could be many years! There is no cure now, but you are in the "manage the disease phase". And many men do "manage" it with ADT and second/third line HT for many years. The SE are what they are, but the alternative is not so great. For now, you need to get that PSA number under control. ADT is no fun, but u can get thru it. Also, if it works, you can go off it and then back on it...again, every case is different. Good luck my friend, please keep us posted. MM

Posts.Title: Been told to go on ADT and chemo

Posts.Content: Hello Karen. I am also a pT3bNO. You can look below at my signature and gain some insight into my case. Not sure where to start, so here goes. Your first urologist has done you no favors. In letting your husbands PSA to climb as it has to .4, he has decreased the optimal outcome you both are hoping for. Lord knows what he is thinking, but I would dump him pronto. With you husbands adverse pathology, he should have been taking action at 0.03 or greater. Studies have shown that for us high risk guys, above that threshold is a good indicator of BCR. I would immediately follow the advice of the RO that u have seen. Please forgive my straight talk. You are wasting precious time, and I am not sure what you are waiting for? The PSA of .4 is still low, and the scans probably will not pick anything up. This 70% stuff? This person has no idea if this is localized or not, there is simply no way of knowing. Your greatest risk is micro-mets, which had you been given better medical advice would perhaps have been treated successfully already. As things stand, your only hope at a possible cure is to start HT yesterday, and SRT tomorrow. The HT will stop any cancer in it's tracks, while your RO arranges the SRT. It's worh a shot, why not? Once again, your Urologist or RO or whoever else you want to talk to has no idea about where this cancer is or confined to. Radiation and HT together produce 50% better outcomes than either one alone. Please take action now, your window is closing. https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/09/v...has-up-to.html Some interesting reading for u. No sense worrying about the past. Time to move forward. Your husbands PSA is still low, and a cure is still possible. HT is tough, be we all get through it. You can do it. Pulling hard for u both, MM

Posts.Title: And On It Goes

Posts.Content: RobLee: Hello. Recent studies have shown that PSA is the major deciding factor in the success or failure of SRT. If your PSA is now<0.02, I would not be concerned. However with your risk profile, I would be using any trend >0.03 to begin the SRT process. Notice I said the Trend. There is no way to determine whether or not it has or will spread beyond that. Only time will tell. Your major risk is the same as mine....micromets. Remember that early HT in addition to SRT can kill off stray cells that may not be sitting in local lymph nodes or the prostate bed. Early action could offer you a cure. I can assure you that if your PSA starts rising and u develop a trend that keeps going north, that it will spread. Remember, cancer control is goal #1. With a G8 and a pT3b NO, I would be throwing everything at this including the kitchen sink. HT/ RT has 50% better chance of success than either one alone. PAY Attention to your PSA. It is the number one factor overriding Gleason score, PM, EPE etc.... On the bright side, so far your looking good and seem to be having a great response. Best of luck, MM......Some interesting reading http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...on-save-lives/ http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/earl...O.2016.68.3425 https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/l...tatectomy.html https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2016/08/h...d-salvage.html Given my risk profile, I try and stay informed. Hope this helps

Posts.Title: Update, Pathology report

Posts.Content: Hello Petzelhead: Sorry to hear about this tough time u are having. To answer your topic question, the side effects of hormone therapy are due to the lack of testosterone in your body. So, i am not sure that there would be much difference in the medical vs. chemical castration as it pertains to side effects. You say your in Carolina? Are you at a major medical center? Interested in knowing what was your clinical diagnoses? Why did they only take 2 lymph nodes during your surgery? I would have thought there would be a lot more taken in your case. What was your pathological staging? Your PSA, while not a large number, has seen a alarming velocity in it's movement. But, this case you present is a bit puzzling. I am surprised that your recent scans were not discovered at the beginning. Your PSA is .7. It usually takes a much higher number for these findings to show up. It's not like your PSA is now 5 or 10. What happened in the beginning of your case? Any additional information you can provide would be helpful. You should be taking some calcium supplements. Vit. D3 around 5000mg per day. Vit K2, around 100mg per day. Adva Cal Ultra. 1000 mg per day. The adva cal has many of these in the serving, so check out the label. Your physical fitness regime is something u want to keep up. You are to be applauded for the great condition u are in. This will help a great deal with ADT. Don't give up hope. Many stage 4 patients live for many, many, years. There are a boatload of front line, second line and down the line hormonal treatments. Many new things coming down the pike. Lets hope the PSA takes a nose dive when the chemo is being done. Hang in there, I will will following your posts. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: Need some clarification/ few questions

Posts.Content: Mike A, and RobLee: As I am sure u are aware, I have the utmost respect for you and your contributions to this forum. ( I am speaking to RobLee). You already know how I feel about your courage and bravery as it pertains to your illness, and also dealing with your wife's issues. I meant no disrespect. Since I am reading in Mike's post a PSA of 40, and I am not hearing anything to the contrary, I can assure him that this high a level is to be taken seriously. With a G8 on biopsy, and a PSA of 40, Mike needs to take decisive action and formulate a game plan immediately. Mike when you get the results, please post and we can guide you on the correct path. When I read thru the thread and saw that nobody commented on your PSA, I was thinking perhaps you meant 4.0...and not 40. Not trying to scare you in anyway, just want you to have the best chance possible. And RobLee, while his PSA is not 3 digits, if it is indeed 40, that to me is a cause for concern. I was not being critical of u, I have great respect for your opinions, and the amount of time you give to others. No disrespect intended. Best to all, MM

Since I am reading in Mike's post a PSA of 40, and I am not hearing anything to the contrary, I can assure him that this high a level is to be taken seriously. With a G8 on biopsy, and a PSA of 40, Mike needs to take decisive action and formulate a game plan immediately. Mike when you get the results, please post and we can guide you on the correct path. When I read thru the thread and saw that nobody commented on your PSA, I was thinking perhaps you meant 4.0...and not 40. Not trying to scare you in anyway, just want you to have the best chance possible. And RobLee, while his PSA is not 3 digits, if it is indeed 40, that to me is a cause for concern. I was not being critical of u, I have great respect for your opinions, and the amount of time you give to others. No disrespect intended. Best to all, MM

Posts.Title: Back again....questions about pathology

Posts.Content: Hello PCH: Welcome to the forum. Your case is a bit puzzling, being that u had surgery and it was a true G6. True G6 has never been found to metastasize. Metastasize is different than people using the word spread. G6 can spread locally, ( get into the surrounding tissue, prostate bed) without metastasizing. Since my Dx, I have read study after study, and I can't find a case of a treated ( true) G6 ending someone's life. You did have positive margins, and as my RO said from the University of Chicago "once the cancer has left the prostate gland, your gleason score becomes irrelevant". ( in terms of having to be treated) In all honesty, as I sit here and look at your PSA, your trend started to become apparent back in Jan. of 2012. In another thread on here, I just posted a link to SRT, and how one's PSA has an effect on outcomes. I will go back and get it for u, and post it in a bit. My guess is that u have something sitting locally , which can be cured by SRT. You may not have to engage in ADT. Lucky u! To answer your last question, I would be acting....yesterday. Found this for you to read from noted pathologist Jonathan Epstein, should make u feel better. Epstein comments: Good News for Men with Gleason Score 6 "In other news, Epstein and colleagues recently took a closer look at the behavior of Gleason score 6 prostate cancer; their findings were published in the American Journal of Surgical Pathology. Although Gleason score 6 cancer is considered slow-growing and not aggressive, it has been found  rarely  in studies of prostate specimens after radical prostatectomy, to have spread outside the prostate. Could Gleason 6 cancer ever spread to the pelvic lymph nodes? Good news: The answer is no. "We performed a search of the radical prostatectomy databases at four large academic centers," says Epstein. "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." It takes a Gleason score of 7 or higher for prostate cancer to become aggressive enough to spread far beyond the prostate. Under the microscope, Gleason score 6 cells appear uniform, "and they have a more predictable, excellent prognosis," Epstein notes. Gleason score 6 disease has such a good reputation as being "indolent"  slow-growing and well behaved, as cancers go  among pathologists that some of them have questioned whether it should still be considered cancer. Yes it should, Epstein says. One important reason why is that the biopsy Gleason score is often adjusted after radical prostatectomy, when the prostate is studied by a pathologist, "because the biopsy often underestimates disease grade and extent." Also, "if men think that Gleason 6 tumors are not cancer, this could result in a missed opportunity for cure."

Posts.Content: Coors: Congrats on the great path report, sounds like you have a excellent chance for a complete cure. You don't need to regain your incontinence to begin penile rehab. Just void yourself out and do what you need to do. You should begin taking 100mg 3x a week of some sort of ED medication. You don't need to be having intercourse, but at least get the blood moving by manual stimulation. I was doing that with good results, until I had to start ADT. Kind of killed my interest, but I am still working on it. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hello guys: As I have stated on a prior thread, my biopsy appt. is this Thursday, OCT 1st. During the past week I have been reading this forum and doing my homework for what may or may not lie ahead. In a few of these threads, it has been mentioned that there are 4 things you should NOT do before taking a PSA test. ( 48-72 hours prior) Do not have sex. Do not ride a bike Do not preform any strenuous exercise Do not allow a doctor to preform a DRE Ok, so for the last 17 years I have been testing for PSA, my highly respected internist ( Loyola Chicago) has never mentioned any of these. The one exception being he asked me about bike riding before the round of antibiotics when my PSA went from 2.9 up to 4.1. Moreover, during the last 4-5 PSA tests, I did not refrain from sex or strenuous exercise. ( 18 holes walk and carry my own bag) Lastly, during each of my physicals, I would get the DRE exam last in the session, then be taken to get the blood work. Is it possible my numbers are flawed? Hard for me to believe my internist would not be aware of this. Thoughts or comments? I'm confused. As always, thanks to all the great people on this site. Chuck, for you, GO IRISH!

Posts.Title: Newbie Question

Posts.Content: Mike A, and RobLee: As I am sure u are aware, I have the utmost respect for you and your contributions to this forum. ( I am speaking to RobLee). You already know how I feel about your courage and bravery as it pertains to your illness, and also dealing with your wife's issues. I meant no disrespect. Since I am reading in Mike's post a PSA of 40, and I am not hearing anything to the contrary, I can assure him that this high a level is to be taken seriously. With a G8 on biopsy, and a PSA of 40, Mike needs to take decisive action and formulate a game plan immediately. Mike when you get the results, please post and we can guide you on the correct path. When I read thru the thread and saw that nobody commented on your PSA, I was thinking perhaps you meant 4.0...and not 40. Not trying to scare you in anyway, just want you to have the best chance possible. And RobLee, while his PSA is not 3 digits, if it is indeed 40, that to me is a cause for concern. I was not being critical of u, I have great respect for your opinions, and the amount of time you give to others. No disrespect intended. Best to all, MM

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hello Prato: Nice to hear from you, not so nice that u are now facing SRT and/or a decision on what to do. One thing is clear, u have a trend, and it's not going away. I am sure u are aware of studies that tell us your PSA level is the single most important factor in the potential outcome of SRT, more so than any other pathological feature. Get yourself into the "very early group" and act no greater than .1. With your pathology, this will all be behind you soon. As u know, i have had the triple whammy...I got thru SRT, so will you. I don't want to go into all my issues, they probably would not apply to your case. My side effects are a result of all 3 treatment modalities, and your situation is quite different. Don't overthink, don't over analyze, just do it. Cancer takes no days off. BTW...I have not forgotten how good u were to me during my bad days post surgery. Please know I am here for u, in whatever way I may be needed. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Jcvdd2: PI-Rads is a interpretation of the images, not the actual cells. It has to do with the likelihood of having cancer depending upon what the images show. Hence, your classification as level 4 would mean it is probably malignant. However, it says nothing about the aggressiveness of the cancer. That is the Gleason score. best of luck Friday, MM

Posts.Title: Update on my other condition...

Posts.Content: Flag: I would echo what Chuck just said: Thank u for your service to our country. My 2 cents: I would try and get a second opinion on your clinical staging. With a G7 (4+3) you might find yourself not being a T1C. Not trying to scare you at all, but I started out this mess as a G8, T1C. On second opinion I was a G7, (4+3) T2c. U can see by my signature where I ended up. Many times these doctors just don't know the clinical staging. Perhaps some sort of enhanced imaging would help you out. I wish I would have done that. Knowing that information will clearly help in the decision process. U have time, just try and get as much info as possible. Please keep us posted, and remember we are here for u. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Results are in

Posts.Content: Hello Sean: Welcome to the other side, glad to hear you are on your way to recovery. I would not be worried about going #2, it takes about 5-6 days after the surgery to get all that in order. Also, when u do finally go, do not strain. U just had major surgery. The catheter will be in for about a week, and I would also be using the big bag. A bit of blood around the tip of the penis for now is ok, but I would look for that to go away shortly. I would try and walk around as much as u can, and when lying down in bed, make sure the bag and the line are below u. I just wore baggy shorts (gym) when walking, and hooked the bag in my pocket. I can be a tough week, but the week will pass quickly. The bag should not be that difficult to empty, give it another look. Maybe u are not seeing the zipper/opening on it correctly..Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: quick update

Posts.Content: Red: I had this exact discussion with my RO. Do not take any of what you have just mentioned while receiving ART. There are some supplements that can have a reverse effect and diminish the effectiveness of the therapy. Anti-oxidation and I believe it is called radical absorption is not what you want during radiation. My RO told me the best way to sensitize the cancer cells was to exercise. Lift weights, fast walking, etc. FWIW. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Just checking in

Posts.Content: Thomasj: I was on Casodex for 4 months, mostly to control any flare ups when I was starting ADT. It was no big deal, really not any different than being on Lupron. I discontinued after the 4 month period ( per my RO) and now I am on a 9 month -2 year Lupron sentence. Got my testosterone test back, sitting at 15! Take charge of your treatment, go to a major medical cancer center if possible. Even though you were dx stage 4, there are many treatments available now, and many more coming down the pike that will keep you around for many, many, years. Hang in there, from what I understand Casodex ( bicalutamide) has been producing great results. Keep us posted. MM

Call us in 2018 if anything changes? Jesus. What the hell is going on with his PCa treatment? Be firm and get some answers. Perhaps when we see his stats, others will be chiming. Best, MM

Posts.Title: First Post - My 81 Year Old Father - Prostate Cancer - Treatment Failure

Posts.Content: Hello jgs. Thank u for putting all your fathers information together for us. Well, sorry to say that he has a serious case of PCa. If Im reading your stats correctly, he is a G9 with a intraductal component. Thats not exactly your garden variety type. I am going to assume that his bone scan and cat scan were negative, otherwise why would they put a 81 year old man thru radiation. ( as opposed to just using HT). The good news is that his PSA is showing a nice response, and the lupron has done its job. With this much PCa and its aggressive nature, I would have to agree with Chuck. Perhaps his other medical issues are not allowing him to be treated. I can tell u that his PCa needs to be addressed and a plan needs to be put in place. Follow Chucks advice and get all his stuff and head to the Mayo Clinic. Without prompt attention, this type of PCa can get out of control. Given your dads situation, he may just be on HT for the rest of his life. I would find out if any additional RT is even possible. Try not to worry. PCa is slow moving, and if treated promptly, your dad will be around for many years. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Content: Hello PCH: Welcome to the forum. Your case is a bit puzzling, being that u had surgery and it was a true G6. True G6 has never been found to metastasize. Metastasize is different than people using the word spread. G6 can spread locally, ( get into the surrounding tissue, prostate bed) without metastasizing. Since my Dx, I have read study after study, and I can't find a case of a treated ( true) G6 ending someone's life. You did have positive margins, and as my RO said from the University of Chicago "once the cancer has left the prostate gland, your gleason score becomes irrelevant". ( in terms of having to be treated) In all honesty, as I sit here and look at your PSA, your trend started to become apparent back in Jan. of 2012. In another thread on here, I just posted a link to SRT, and how one's PSA has an effect on outcomes. I will go back and get it for u, and post it in a bit. My guess is that u have something sitting locally , which can be cured by SRT. You may not have to engage in ADT. Lucky u! To answer your last question, I would be acting....yesterday. Found this for you to read from noted pathologist Jonathan Epstein, should make u feel better. Epstein comments: Good News for Men with Gleason Score 6 "In other news, Epstein and colleagues recently took a closer look at the behavior of Gleason score 6 prostate cancer; their findings were published in the American Journal of Surgical Pathology. Although Gleason score 6 cancer is considered slow-growing and not aggressive, it has been found  rarely  in studies of prostate specimens after radical prostatectomy, to have spread outside the prostate. Could Gleason 6 cancer ever spread to the pelvic lymph nodes? Good news: The answer is no. "We performed a search of the radical prostatectomy databases at four large academic centers," says Epstein. "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." It takes a Gleason score of 7 or higher for prostate cancer to become aggressive enough to spread far beyond the prostate. Under the microscope, Gleason score 6 cells appear uniform, "and they have a more predictable, excellent prognosis," Epstein notes. Gleason score 6 disease has such a good reputation as being "indolent"  slow-growing and well behaved, as cancers go  among pathologists that some of them have questioned whether it should still be considered cancer. Yes it should, Epstein says. One important reason why is that the biopsy Gleason score is often adjusted after radical prostatectomy, when the prostate is studied by a pathologist, "because the biopsy often underestimates disease grade and extent." Also, "if men think that Gleason 6 tumors are not cancer, this could result in a missed opportunity for cure."

Under the microscope, Gleason score 6 cells appear uniform, "and they have a more predictable, excellent prognosis," Epstein notes. Gleason score 6 disease has such a good reputation as being "indolent"  slow-growing and well behaved, as cancers go  among pathologists that some of them have questioned whether it should still be considered cancer. Yes it should, Epstein says. One important reason why is that the biopsy Gleason score is often adjusted after radical prostatectomy, when the prostate is studied by a pathologist, "because the biopsy often underestimates disease grade and extent." Also, "if men think that Gleason 6 tumors are not cancer, this could result in a missed opportunity for cure."

Posts.Title: Pathology Report - Doc says it's good and I'm likely cancer free but I'm not so sure

Posts.Content: Hello PCH: Welcome to the forum. Your case is a bit puzzling, being that u had surgery and it was a true G6. True G6 has never been found to metastasize. Metastasize is different than people using the word spread. G6 can spread locally, ( get into the surrounding tissue, prostate bed) without metastasizing. Since my Dx, I have read study after study, and I can't find a case of a treated ( true) G6 ending someone's life. You did have positive margins, and as my RO said from the University of Chicago "once the cancer has left the prostate gland, your gleason score becomes irrelevant". ( in terms of having to be treated) In all honesty, as I sit here and look at your PSA, your trend started to become apparent back in Jan. of 2012. In another thread on here, I just posted a link to SRT, and how one's PSA has an effect on outcomes. I will go back and get it for u, and post it in a bit. My guess is that u have something sitting locally , which can be cured by SRT. You may not have to engage in ADT. Lucky u! To answer your last question, I would be acting....yesterday. Found this for you to read from noted pathologist Jonathan Epstein, should make u feel better. Epstein comments: Good News for Men with Gleason Score 6 "In other news, Epstein and colleagues recently took a closer look at the behavior of Gleason score 6 prostate cancer; their findings were published in the American Journal of Surgical Pathology. Although Gleason score 6 cancer is considered slow-growing and not aggressive, it has been found  rarely  in studies of prostate specimens after radical prostatectomy, to have spread outside the prostate. Could Gleason 6 cancer ever spread to the pelvic lymph nodes? Good news: The answer is no. "We performed a search of the radical prostatectomy databases at four large academic centers," says Epstein. "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." It takes a Gleason score of 7 or higher for prostate cancer to become aggressive enough to spread far beyond the prostate. Under the microscope, Gleason score 6 cells appear uniform, "and they have a more predictable, excellent prognosis," Epstein notes. Gleason score 6 disease has such a good reputation as being "indolent"  slow-growing and well behaved, as cancers go  among pathologists that some of them have questioned whether it should still be considered cancer. Yes it should, Epstein says. One important reason why is that the biopsy Gleason score is often adjusted after radical prostatectomy, when the prostate is studied by a pathologist, "because the biopsy often underestimates disease grade and extent." Also, "if men think that Gleason 6 tumors are not cancer, this could result in a missed opportunity for cure."

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Hello jgs. Thank u for putting all your fathers information together for us. Well, sorry to say that he has a serious case of PCa. If Im reading your stats correctly, he is a G9 with a intraductal component. Thats not exactly your garden variety type. I am going to assume that his bone scan and cat scan were negative, otherwise why would they put a 81 year old man thru radiation. ( as opposed to just using HT). The good news is that his PSA is showing a nice response, and the lupron has done its job. With this much PCa and its aggressive nature, I would have to agree with Chuck. Perhaps his other medical issues are not allowing him to be treated. I can tell u that his PCa needs to be addressed and a plan needs to be put in place. Follow Chucks advice and get all his stuff and head to the Mayo Clinic. Without prompt attention, this type of PCa can get out of control. Given your dads situation, he may just be on HT for the rest of his life. I would find out if any additional RT is even possible. Try not to worry. PCa is slow moving, and if treated promptly, your dad will be around for many years. Best of luck, MM

AgeInfo.Phrase: why would they put a 81 year old man thru radiation

Posts.Title: First Post - My 81 Year Old Father - Prostate Cancer - Treatment Failure

Posts.Content: Hello jgs: Sorry to hear what you Father has had to go thru. Does this story make sense? No, it does not. Who started the PCa treatment? Was he treated with anything other than RT? Any type of HT? What are his statistics as it pertains to the PC? PSA, G score, any type of diagnostic testing. Given his age, I assume that he did not have surgery option. Tell us more about his PCA, all you can remember. "This means to me that his pancreas is no longer working correctly or at all. Is this something that happens during prostate treatment? I cannot seem to find any other instances of this". I would agree with u. And I do not ever recall hearing anything like this. You need to pressure your RO who started this and get some answers. Call us in 2018 if anything changes? Jesus. What the hell is going on with his PCa treatment? Be firm and get some answers. Perhaps when we see his stats, others will be chiming. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Flag: I would echo what Chuck just said: Thank u for your service to our country. My 2 cents: I would try and get a second opinion on your clinical staging. With a G7 (4+3) you might find yourself not being a T1C. Not trying to scare you at all, but I started out this mess as a G8, T1C. On second opinion I was a G7, (4+3) T2c. U can see by my signature where I ended up. Many times these doctors just don't know the clinical staging. Perhaps some sort of enhanced imaging would help you out. I wish I would have done that. Knowing that information will clearly help in the decision process. U have time, just try and get as much info as possible. Please keep us posted, and remember we are here for u. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: Well, my impression of your report? First I would find the nearest church and thank the good lord, and next I would fly to my favorite party spot with all my friends and spend 90% of my net worth on recreational drugs, hookers, and alcohol. The other 10% I would probably waste. I don't think I would use the cure word, this is cancer and only time will tell. But your doctor did use the word likely, and I would agree. To answer your margin question, u have what is referred to as a focal margin. Generally < 2/3 mm. This means there were only small bits of cancer seen at the ink, and that they probably got it all on the cut out. Congrats!! MM

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: To all my forum brothers: Just wanted to say hello to all and let everyone know my SRT was completed on 8/5/16. I want to thank all of u for the kindness and support that has been directed at me. Of course, also the technical knowledge of helping me develop a game plan. I got to ring the "bell" 3 times, as is the tradition at UC. All the techs and doctors came out and gave me a round of applause, which I felt kind of strange about. It was I that should have been applauding them, and I did. I hugged and thanked each one of them, brought all of them a few parting gifts, and when I spoke I started to get choked up. Could not finish my words, so just kind of thankfully bowed my head and left. Such a great team, I felt fortunate to be in their care. SE have not been all bad, some bowel and urinary issues that will go away in about 6-8 weeks. I was >90% dry going in, and for the most part have stayed that way. I am about 1/2 pad per day. So, I guess that might be one bullet I dodged. I did not celebrate on that Friday, right after I drove to a religious place near my home and went to the grotto. I said a few prayers and walked around this beautiful place. Trees, smell of fresh cut grass, open fields, and suddenly I was at peace with all this PCa mess. Don't mind admitting I had a meltdown, but re-grouped and got home. Where the rest of this journey takes me who knows, but I am glad to take it with all of my Forum brothers ( and sisters) by my side. Warmest Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Dad newly diagnosed w/aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Sara: There is no Stage 5. Stage cT2a means that the cancer can be felt or seen in one half or less of one side of the prostate. I was cT2c...it was felt in both sides of my prostate. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: To all my forum brothers: Just wanted to say hello to all and let everyone know my SRT was completed on 8/5/16. I want to thank all of u for the kindness and support that has been directed at me. Of course, also the technical knowledge of helping me develop a game plan. I got to ring the "bell" 3 times, as is the tradition at UC. All the techs and doctors came out and gave me a round of applause, which I felt kind of strange about. It was I that should have been applauding them, and I did. I hugged and thanked each one of them, brought all of them a few parting gifts, and when I spoke I started to get choked up. Could not finish my words, so just kind of thankfully bowed my head and left. Such a great team, I felt fortunate to be in their care. SE have not been all bad, some bowel and urinary issues that will go away in about 6-8 weeks. I was >90% dry going in, and for the most part have stayed that way. I am about 1/2 pad per day. So, I guess that might be one bullet I dodged. I did not celebrate on that Friday, right after I drove to a religious place near my home and went to the grotto. I said a few prayers and walked around this beautiful place. Trees, smell of fresh cut grass, open fields, and suddenly I was at peace with all this PCa mess. Don't mind admitting I had a meltdown, but re-grouped and got home. Where the rest of this journey takes me who knows, but I am glad to take it with all of my Forum brothers ( and sisters) by my side. Warmest Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: Mike: It is ok to feel blue. It is ok to feel anyway that u want, this PCa business is a life changing event for many of us. I would be concerned if u didn't feel a bit down at the beginning of this ....mess! Sorry to hear about the additional news. With possible SVI and larger volume of cores/cancer involved, this moves you into a higher risk category. This forum, for whatever reason, has more men with surgery than any other treatment choice. Nothing wrong with that. However, as a higher risk patient who is now looking at multiple treatment modalities, I would be looking to lessen the SE of gaining a cure. I have been thru all three. Read about what has occurred with me. If you are going to need radiation, u might want to check out just starting with it at the beginning. Surgery+radiation+ ADT has given me the worst of all worlds. ( in terms of SE) I was doing just fine after surgery, until SRT/ADT came into the picture. With the amount of cancer u are now looking at, there may be more in there than just a G7 (4+3). Surgery will tell u that, but it probably won't change your treatment path. Not with your other risk factors. I have no horse in this race. Just a forum brother who has been thru the ringer, and if I would have known what I was going to have to go thru, I might have looked into the following study. All that said, I seem to be on the correct track, and I am grateful that I may have an opportunity for a cure. It's a long road, hang tough. MM https://pcnrv.blogspot.com/2017/02/f...brt-bt-is.html

Posts.Title: Dad newly diagnosed w/aggressive prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello PCH: Welcome to the forum. Your case is a bit puzzling, being that u had surgery and it was a true G6. True G6 has never been found to metastasize. Metastasize is different than people using the word spread. G6 can spread locally, ( get into the surrounding tissue, prostate bed) without metastasizing. Since my Dx, I have read study after study, and I can't find a case of a treated ( true) G6 ending someone's life. You did have positive margins, and as my RO said from the University of Chicago "once the cancer has left the prostate gland, your gleason score becomes irrelevant". ( in terms of having to be treated) In all honesty, as I sit here and look at your PSA, your trend started to become apparent back in Jan. of 2012. In another thread on here, I just posted a link to SRT, and how one's PSA has an effect on outcomes. I will go back and get it for u, and post it in a bit. My guess is that u have something sitting locally , which can be cured by SRT. You may not have to engage in ADT. Lucky u! To answer your last question, I would be acting....yesterday. Found this for you to read from noted pathologist Jonathan Epstein, should make u feel better. Epstein comments: Good News for Men with Gleason Score 6 "In other news, Epstein and colleagues recently took a closer look at the behavior of Gleason score 6 prostate cancer; their findings were published in the American Journal of Surgical Pathology. Although Gleason score 6 cancer is considered slow-growing and not aggressive, it has been found  rarely  in studies of prostate specimens after radical prostatectomy, to have spread outside the prostate. Could Gleason 6 cancer ever spread to the pelvic lymph nodes? Good news: The answer is no. "We performed a search of the radical prostatectomy databases at four large academic centers," says Epstein. "In more than 14,000 radical prostatectomies, there was not a single case of a Gleason score 6 tumor ever spreading to lymph nodes." It takes a Gleason score of 7 or higher for prostate cancer to become aggressive enough to spread far beyond the prostate. Under the microscope, Gleason score 6 cells appear uniform, "and they have a more predictable, excellent prognosis," Epstein notes. Gleason score 6 disease has such a good reputation as being "indolent"  slow-growing and well behaved, as cancers go  among pathologists that some of them have questioned whether it should still be considered cancer. Yes it should, Epstein says. One important reason why is that the biopsy Gleason score is often adjusted after radical prostatectomy, when the prostate is studied by a pathologist, "because the biopsy often underestimates disease grade and extent." Also, "if men think that Gleason 6 tumors are not cancer, this could result in a missed opportunity for cure."

Posts.Title: Worried about my number

Posts.Content: Hello MRJ. Just wanted to welcome you to the forum. Many great people on here who are more than willing to help you through this. You are not alone. I would start doing my homework, so pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book the "Guide to surviving Prostate Cancer". 3rd edition. Given your PSA and G score, u are classified as high intermediate risk. My only concern would be your dominant pattern 4. But, u won't know anything until the final report is in. ( after surgery). For now, let's just go with learning, asking questions, and having us support you in any way possible. To be fair, your G7 ( 4+3) could always be downgraded. And all PCa can be curable if it has not escaped the gland. Of course, many are cured whose PCa has escaped, but remained local. If you need to talk, send me a PM. This forum has your back. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Pomegranate juice is one of the many supplements that people take as a form of receiving antioxidants. Also found in broccoli, green tea, soy products, etc. Do they actually help prevent the recurrence of PCa? Unclear. One thing does seem a bit more certain, stop taking all these if u are receiving SRT. The antioxidants can have a adverse affect on the job radiation is trying to do destroying the tumor cells. MM

Posts.Title: HAPPY thanksgiving - Lots to be Thankful For

Posts.Content: Hey All: First, thank u for the support in my prior posts before the biopsy. I will make a stats page as soon as I get the printed report. The damn printer was broken when I went in for the results. My biopsy was positive for PC in 9 of the 12 cores taken. 5 of the cores were 3+3=6 gleason. Please hang with me, I'm going from my notes. 4 cores were 4+4=8 Gleason. 3 were neg. My PSA on 9/12/15 was 5.9. Needless to say, when I heard Gleason 8, I kind of went into a trance. For now, I have started this at a well-respected hospital just outside Chicago. Love the uro. She gave me my info on the Partin Tables. Says the following: 59% chance contained to the prostate, 32% chance just outside the capsule, 6% chance it has gone to the seminal vesicles, and 3% chance it has gone to the Lymph nodes. Like I said, I was by myself when I got this news but the uro called me the next day and we talked on the phone. So I am sure this is correct. Cat scan and bone scan set for Monday the 12th. Uro says if all is good on those, I have a very good chance of a cure, ( surgery and possible radiation) depending on what happens. Also, suggests I get a second opinion. So, I am off to the University of Chicago Uro cancer team in another 2 weeks. ( When I get all my results and they can fit me in). Right now, my head is spinning and i'm doing a lot of pacing. I forgot to write down that % involvment aspect. I will include all on a stats page when I get the report. Maybe UC will review all this and have better news on the cores. Posts.Title: 3 Days To Go

Posts.Content: Prato: I am thankful for people like you. Your technical contributions to this forum are invaluable, only exceeded by your kindness, compassion, and willingness to give back. To all the regulars on this site who always give 100% of themselves, thank you. I can assure you it does not go unnoticed. Chuck, thank u for everything. You do so much i would be typing for hours if I had to list it all. Today I was watching CNBC financial news and one of the regular contributors named Joe Terrernova ( sp. ? ) started to speak. But it was not about financial news. One year ago this day, he was discovered to have a lump or mass in his liver. He started telling this story on live TV at noon. I was not sure where he was going with this. They thought it was cancer, but after several tests, etc, it appears to be just a benign mass. He spoke about being thankful. His wife, his children, etc. Then he said words that will stay with me forever. "What am I thankful for this holiday? the next 5 minutes." Kinda put things in perspective for me. Happy Thanksgiving to all. MM

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hey All: First, thank u for the support in my prior posts before the biopsy. I will make a stats page as soon as I get the printed report. The damn printer was broken when I went in for the results. My biopsy was positive for PC in 9 of the 12 cores taken. 5 of the cores were 3+3=6 gleason. Please hang with me, I'm going from my notes. 4 cores were 4+4=8 Gleason. 3 were neg. My PSA on 9/12/15 was 5.9. Needless to say, when I heard Gleason 8, I kind of went into a trance. For now, I have started this at a well-respected hospital just outside Chicago. Love the uro. She gave me my info on the Partin Tables. Says the following: 59% chance contained to the prostate, 32% chance just outside the capsule, 6% chance it has gone to the seminal vesicles, and 3% chance it has gone to the Lymph nodes. Like I said, I was by myself when I got this news but the uro called me the next day and we talked on the phone. So I am sure this is correct. Cat scan and bone scan set for Monday the 12th. Uro says if all is good on those, I have a very good chance of a cure, ( surgery and possible radiation) depending on what happens. Also, suggests I get a second opinion. So, I am off to the University of Chicago Uro cancer team in another 2 weeks. ( When I get all my results and they can fit me in). Right now, my head is spinning and i'm doing a lot of pacing. I forgot to write down that % involvment aspect. I will include all on a stats page when I get the report. Maybe UC will review all this and have better news on the cores. Scared and freakin in the windy city. Congrats to chuck and pratoman on the good news. Pulling for u guys. I will keep u posted. Regards, John. Forgot to mention my current staging T1C

Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: John4803: Are they adding the Chemo because of the positive nodes? Standard of care for pT3bNO has been ( assuming they had surgery) ART/SRT, along with up to 2 years of ADT. I received this answer from 3 different doctors. I have also noticed that some RO/ MO are also throwing Zytiga in the mix with ADT. The studies to which you refer have been around since I started treatment...wondering what has changed. You are correct, G8-10 can be highly predictive of micro-mets. When I asked my uro if SRT/ADT could kill off stray cells, his answer was..."We think it can". But no conclusive evidence. Ask your RO the question as to why the standard of care may or may not have changed. Most of the pT3BNO on this forum have had the triple whammy of Surgery, SRT, ADT. Not many chemo additions. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer (NEJM)

Posts.Content: Nick: Sorry to hear about your post-op PSA, at this point in time it is quite clear that your surgery has failed. My question now is, why are you waiting to begin secondary treatment? You have a ticking time bomb inside you, and you are not seeing the doctor until August? You should be in line for both HT and SRT. You should have already started the process, and your MO and RO should have explained this to u. The chances of side effects from secondary treatment are 100%. No way to avoid them. In order to have any chance at a cure, you need to act now. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Hello Prato: Nice to hear from you, not so nice that u are now facing SRT and/or a decision on what to do. One thing is clear, u have a trend, and it's not going away. I am sure u are aware of studies that tell us your PSA level is the single most important factor in the potential outcome of SRT, more so than any other pathological feature. Get yourself into the "very early group" and act no greater than .1. With your pathology, this will all be behind you soon. As u know, i have had the triple whammy...I got thru SRT, so will you. I don't want to go into all my issues, they probably would not apply to your case. My side effects are a result of all 3 treatment modalities, and your situation is quite different. Don't overthink, don't over analyze, just do it. Cancer takes no days off. BTW...I have not forgotten how good u were to me during my bad days post surgery. Please know I am here for u, in whatever way I may be needed. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: JJ: Welcome to the forum, lots of good folks here to lend support and advice. Nothing easy about this entire process, especially the part that your going thru now. I am a stage 3 and have had many dark moments, most during the initial parts of my treatment. Seemed surreal at times. Kept wanting to wake up from a bad dream, but it was/ is reality. Things will get better with time, and with each day the urge to stand up and fight and not give in or up will return. As brother MF has said, tell us a bit about you history, etc. I am sure others will be along to extend a warm welcome. Hang in, stay the course, and don't give up the ship. You are not alone. Best, MM
Posts.Title: I have metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hey JJ. I would be interested in your timeline. You started lupron, and it failed? You sound like u have been thru the ringer, so sorry about that. When did all this start? They did not offer you any primary treatment other than ADT? Just trying to piece together your case. Hoping that u are finding some peace and I've heard the Zytiga can be effective in cases like yours. Tell us a bit more, only 3/12 cores and this advanced? We are all in your corner. Best to u, MM
Posts.Title: I have metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello m. First, your PSA of .08 at this stage of the game is not the end of the world. I would wait to see what develops over the next few tests. That's not enough of a rise to make any judgements at this time. Why in the world would your oncologist want to take a PSA during radiation treatment? Would be of zero value, no sense at all. Why no HT here? Ur stats are very similar to mine. HT combined with SRT produce results 50% better than either one alone. Early ADT kills local and stray cells, before they get out of hand. Did u have ADT? Not sure where u r receiving treatment, very surprised and concerned that u have not thrown everything at this. Since our stats are alike, I will leave u with what my MO at the university of Chicago told me. It may be a tough ride, but your chances of survival are excellent. I'll go with that. Best, MM
Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: M. Your 2 PSA tests post- surgery were fairly low. U decided to act at .04. That's a great thing! PSA after radiation this soon is hard to get a handle on. U don't want to c it go any higher, but see what the next test brings. It's still pretty low. CC33: why are you saying the RT will work for only 2-3 years? Lack of early HT? No chance at a cure? His Post-op PSA suggested it could be local. Ur thoughts on this comment? Thanks, MM
Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: Good advice from MF. After u get the second test, u can develop a plan for action....or not. Even in the case of additional treatment, I would think the odds of success are in your favor. Your pathology is very mild. Stay strong and good luck Cog, MM

Posts.Title: 3 months post RALP and discouraged

Posts.Content: Hey Nick: Sorry if I came across a bit harsh, our job here is to support and encourage our fellow PCa brothers, while telling them the truth as we see it. As Michael F states quite often, "none of us here are doctors". True enough. What are we? Men who have been afflicted with this terrible disease, and who have the benefit of walking in the path u now find yourself in. I don't blame you for following your doctors advise, their credentials seem impeccable. There is no use worrying about the past. What can you do from here? I would demand some answers. Become pro-active in your case. Something is wrong here. Could you provide the exact details of your case? Your PSA seems very high for a G7. What was your pathology? When your 4W PSA came out why did that not raise any concerns? By your 16W PSA....and still nothing. If u can create a signature, we can help. Remember, you are not alone. Don't worry about what was, let's move forward and find some answers. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Nick: Sorry to hear about your post-op PSA, at this point in time it is quite clear that your surgery has failed. My question now is, why are you waiting to begin secondary treatment? You have a ticking time bomb inside you, and you are not seeing the doctor until August? You should be in line for both HT and SRT. You should have already started the process, and your MO and RO should have explained this to u. The chances of side effects from secondary treatment are 100%. No way to avoid them. In order to have any chance at a cure, you need to act now. Wishing you the best, MM

Not trying to be harsh, act now. Studies have shown that SRT success is almost totally dependent upon when you start as it relates to your PSA. Above ALL other factors. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Rising PSA 7 months post prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hello Fairwind: As one high risk case to another, congrats on the 8 year mark since your dx. Since most of us have a tendency to follow those with a similar case, I have watched over yours the last 2.5 years since my dx. I admire your strength and courage, and the way u always have been helpful to the guys on here. Your contributions here have been many, and your knowledge of the subject matter invaluable. You have a lot of kick left in you Fairwind, this Chemo will just be another chapter in your long life. All of us, especially us high risk guys, owe u a big thank u for all your service here on the forum. I know first hand what u have been thru, and I have much respect for the way you have handled yourself. As you would say, stay strong and stay the course. With heartfelt admiration, MM

Posts.Title: New Member of the "0" Club!!!!

Posts.Content: Steve: According to my Information from UChicago, there can be potential harm in doing Kegels when urinating. They say to only do it once to gain a feel for the correct muscles.( i.e, the pelvic floor muscles) " Doing this exercise while you are urinating can cause problems emptying your bladder and increases your risk for urinary tract infection". My surgeon has me doing 10x10 for 100 per day in preparation for my surgery. Told me to get the correct muscles, and it takes some practice. Sitting, standing, etc. did not matter. Hope this helps. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Kegel Question

Posts.Content: As it pertains to the DRE, I was amazed during the process of what differences there were in findings.... depending upon who was doing the examination. I have come to the conclusion that PCP are not that reliable. They do it quick, and many dont seem to realize they cant feel the far side of the gland. There was a Atlantic Ocean of difference between the PCP, the regular urologist, and the surgeon. Bottom line... have the surgeon do it. Amazing how lousy some doctors are. 1/3 in my case got it correct. Doesnt answer your question, just me venting again. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Three year checkup

Posts.Content: Rob. He should be staged pt3b NO. He has SVI, that is pt3b. LVI and lymph node involvement are two different things. His pelvic LN taken during surgery were negative. That's NO. LVI being positive is saying that the tumor violated the lymph system, another way for it to spread. Same as me.
Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: Tom182. I remember during my research for my SRT that there were significant differences in outcomes based upon when RT was started. PSA level was the single most important factor in determining outcomes. More than G score, PM, ECE, etc. I will do some leg work and find u the link. There were 3 or 4 categories of early, very early, etc. I seem to think starting when it was .1 or less had x times better outcomes. I will find it and report back to u tomorrow. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Pain 8 weeks After robotic surgery

Posts.Content: Dave: For what it's worth, the second opinion from JH ( Dr. Epstein ) costs 250$ and takes a few days. B/4 I went to UC, I had called and inquired. Agree with Ron though, not sure what good it will do u in your situation. On Staging, my first Uro staged me as T1C. She could feel nothing, or nothing that concerned her. My surgeon, after a lengthy DRE, decided I was T2. These things can tend to be fluid and change. In any event, it looks like u caught this early and have a excellent chance for a cure. You have time, so consider all your options. As was said to me on this forum...You only have one chance to get it right. Best wishes

Posts.Title: What supplies to get after removing catheter?

Posts.Content: Hey Rob: Nice to see u back, hope u are doing well. I had my yearly check-up with my PCP, and I requested that my T levels be checked. My next uPSA draw is coming up in 3 weeks. My last Lupron shot wore off on May 15th, 2018. My results: 12/12/18....Free T 42.8...Std Range...47-244. Total T.....262....Std Range...300-720. Not sure how to feel about all this, I am still having a few hot flashes at nite, and very little sexual interest. A touch, but not much. I guess my next uPSA will be a bit more important than I first suspected, kind of nervous. Hoping for good news for u, best of luck. MM

Posts.Title: Number Of Advanced Prostate Cancer Cases Soars

Posts.Content: Hey Nick: Sorry if I came across a bit harsh, our job here is to support and encourage our fellow PCa brothers, while telling them the truth as we see it. As Michael F states quite often, "none of us here are doctors". True enough. What are we? Men who have been afflicted with this terrible disease, and who have the benefit of walking in the path u now find yourself in. I don't blame you for following your doctors advise, their credentials seem impeccable. There is no use worrying about the past. What can you do from here? I would demand some answers. Become pro-active in your case. Something is wrong here. Could you provide the exact details of your case? Your PSA seems very high for a G7. What was your pathology? When your 4W PSA came out why did that not raise any concerns? By your 16W PSA....and still nothing. If u can create a signature, we can help. Remember, you are not alone. Don't worry about what was, let's move forward and find some answers. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Nick: Sorry to hear about your post-op PSA, at this point in time it is quite clear that your surgery has failed. My question now is, why are you waiting to begin secondary treatment? You have a ticking time bomb inside you, and you are not seeing the doctor until August? You should be in line for both HT and SRT. You should have already started the process, and your MO and RO should have explained this to u. The chances of side effects from secondary treatment are 100%. No way to avoid them. In order to have any chance at a cure, you need to act now. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Hey All: First, thank u for the support in my prior posts before the biopsy. I will make a stats page as soon as I get the printed report. The damn printer was broken when I went in for the results. My biopsy was positive for PC in 9 of the 12 cores taken. 5 of the cores were 3+3=6 gleason. Please hang with me, I'm going from my notes. 4 cores were 4+4=8 Gleason. 3 were neg. My PSA on 9/12/15 was 5.9. Needless to say, when I heard Gleason 8, I kind of went into a trance. For now, I have started this at a well-respected hospital just outside Chicago. Love the uro. She gave me my info on the Partin Tables. Says the following: 59% chance contained to the prostate, 32% chance just outside the capsule, 6% chance it has gone to the seminal vesicles, and 3% chance it has gone to the Lymph nodes. Like I said, I was by myself when I got this news but the uro called me the next day and we talked on the phone. So I am sure this is correct. Cat scan and bone scan set for Monday the 12th. Uro says if all is good on those, I have a very good chance of a cure, ( surgery and possible radiation) depending on what happens. Also, suggests I get a second opinion. So, I am off to the University of Chicago Uro cancer team in another 2 weeks. ( When I get all my results and they can fit me in). Right now, my head is spinning and i'm doing a lot of pacing. I forgot to write down that % involvment aspect. I will include all on a stats page when I get the report. Maybe UC will review all this and have better news on the cores. Scared and freakin in the windy city. Congrats to chuck and pratoman on the good news. Pulling for u guys. I will keep u posted. Regards, John. Forgot to mention my current staging T1C
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Hey Rich: Welcome to the other side. Glad to here the surgery went well. I slept in my bed from nite one, just used the big bag and had the long cord to keep the bag below me. It seemed to work well, and I slept better than in the recliner. Get up and move during the day, u will heal quicker. Here's hoping for a clean path report. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Diagnosed with Ductal Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hello cubs: when I read this, it was like reading about myself, only worse. I mean that in the most respectful way, Regrettably, this can happen to some men post RP/SRT. I was never given the chance to really heal, and post SRT my continence just kept getting worse. Not so much at my job ( desk), but In everyday life. Especially having to do with exercise, golf, any sort of exertion. I went thru PT, Kegels, etc.... nothing has worked. Ive probably done thousands of Kegels, just didnt work for me. What the doctors do not tell us is that this CAN happen. Its been 3 years for me, going to have the AUS 800 surgery at Loyola. You are not alone.... let me know if I can help. MM

Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: Rin: I'm not doctor, and I'm not saying your urologist is doing anything wrong. If I was standing in your shoes, I would not be waiting 6 months with a positive DRE. I would take the route of being pro-active. A nodule is not normal. If it's kind of fleshie feeling, maybe nothing. If not..... I would get a second opinion. Additional testing. What's your free PSA? I don't understand why your urologist is not concerned. Not trying to alarm you, I have just seen many examples of doctors who aren't on their game. But hey, it's your call. Best, MM
