Posts.Title: Second Opinions

Posts.Content: Mike: While I applaud your pro-active stance, right now u don't need to do anything. Your numbers could not be any better. Given your pT3b status, I would be testing every 8-12 weeks, and keeping track of my PSA in that manner. ( Even if I had to pay the cost myself) I have read the studies that you have referenced in your letter to Dr. Shah. For the 0.03 threshold that you mention, I do not think it matters on which PSA test it happens on. It will just be telling u that it is time to get your ducks in a row....or do so before hand. In my view the words adjuvant and salvage really are not that much different. Bottom line.....proceed when your PSA tells u so. Use the uPSA assay, and IF your psa should begin to rise, pull the trigger sooner rather than later. Standard of care for your case would be EBRT (IMRT), (IGRT). Today's radiation ( Varian Rapid Arc, or VMAT if I am remembering correctly) will get the job done, and is the radiation that most insurance company's will approve. I do not see why proton therapy would be any better for a salvage situation. BTW...with surgery and radiation, some of the side effects are hard to avoid. The price us high risk guys pay to keep our feet north of the grass. Be grateful if u can avoid ADT and slavage....for now u are doing well. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: Fishhoops: Both ductal and intra-ductal are known to be serious and aggressive forms of prostate cancer. If u could post a signature regarding your treatment history and pathology report, it would give us a better idea of where you stand. Neither supplements or God had anything to do with it being contained. You may just have been lucky, or caught it in the nick of time. G8 is serious. Ductal is serious. You need to be seeing a PCa specialist who handles these type of cases. Not really clear if you knew about this at biopsy, or what your timeline is. Your scans and tests, which you say are negative now, may not stay that way over time. Your initial high PSA, G8, and ductal PCa are telling you that this game may be far from over. For now, congrats on the 3 month test. I would be consulting a MO and RO to secure opinions about your status moving forward. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Any experience with Prolia on Lupron HT?

Posts.Content: Hello Rooster: Welcome to the forum, and best of luck in your upcoming surgery. In all my readings and speaking with surgery patients, I have never heard of any advanced imaging taking place like you are suggesting. Are you sure you understood that correctly? Unless you have a prior medical issue, I am not sure what they would be looking at. The recovery period for surgery is about 8 weeks. ( at least before you may start normal activities) To be honest, my hernia operation 5 years ago was MUCH more painful than the RALP. Many on here have had surgery, if u have specific questions, fire away. I am wondering if they would be looking at Prostate Anastomosis, the reconnection of the bladder and the urethra? Best Wishes for your complete recovery. MM

Posts.Title: No erection

Posts.Content: Hello Jcvdd2: PI-Rads is a interpretation of the images, not the actual cells. It has to do with the likelihood of having cancer depending upon what the images show. Hence, your classification as level 4 would mean it is probably malignant. However, it says nothing about the aggressiveness of the cancer. That is the Gleason score. best of luck Friday, MM

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Red: I had this exact discussion with my RO. Do not take any of what you have just mentioned while receiving ART. There are some supplements that can have a reverse effect and diminish the effectiveness of the therapy. Anti-oxidation and I believe it is called radical absorption is not what you want during radiation. My RO told me the best way to sensitize the cancer cells was to exercise. Lift weights, fast walking, etc. FWIW. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Red: There has been quite a bit of discussion and debate on the diet and supplement issue, and it's potential to halt the progression of PCa, and as you have asked, to keep PSA low. In all my research and studying, I have found very little if any proof that either one of the two have any significant effects on PCa progression. FWIW, my MO at the UC told me to do the following: 1. Pomegranate in pill form. 2. Soy products in food form 3. Green Tea 4. Broccoli All this being said, is it really helping me? Hell if I know. I also take Curcumin (750mg) Calcium/Vit. D3. For your upcoming ART/SRT, I would not be taking anything until the sessions are completed. Some supplements can actually have an adverse effect. Advice: do nothing until it's over. As for diet, it's always good to have a balanced one. It can't hurt, but I have not seen the science behind it for what you are asking. I have had a great diet, in great shape, and look where that got me! Cannabis oil.....NO. Just my views, good luck. MM

Posts.Title: Radiation Days

Posts.Content: Hello Rotty: Welcome to the Forum. Sorry u are here, let's hope your stay is a short one. Answering your questions: 1. Most people who post here are men who have been there, done that. Very few if any doctors. 2. There are several signs of PCa that doctors look for. But please keep in mind that many of them could also be medical issues that are NOT PCa. ( BPH, Urinary Tract infections, Painful Bladder, Postatitis, among them) 3. I would go to a Uro for all opinions regarding PCa. Most family doctors or PCP don't know much about PCa. You will learn far more from this forum than any PCP or family doctor. Your PSA is a bit high for someone your age. Your Uro was correct to give you some antibiotics, you were incorrect not to take them as prescribed. Bad idea. I would agree with your current doctor that u should be considering a biopsy. It is the only way to rule out or confirm PCa. "So I started looking into this and found that a lot of reputable medical people don't want a biopsy this soon into the deal, Also I had a doctor tell me they dont even do the PSA any more due to the un-reliable ness of it. The original doctor also told me that he has patients with a PSA of 15 that have no cancer." If this is the advice you are receiving, I would get several more opinions. PSA testing has saved my life, and these statements in my view are complete nonsense! Example....Yes, some men with a PSA of 15 may not have cancer. So what? What the hell does that have to do with your situation? PSA is a simple blood test, this BS about it not being reliable? Tell that to the men who followed this advice and found themselves in a position where a potential cure was no longer possible. Perhaps others will chime in, that's my take. Best to u, MM

Posts.Content: Hey Rob: Nice to see u back, hope u are doing well. I had my yearly check-up with my PCP, and I requested that my T levels be checked. My next uPSA draw is coming up in 3 weeks. My last Lupron shot wore off on May 15th, 2018. My results: 12/12/18....Free T 42.8...Std Range...47-244. Total T.....262....Std Range...300-720. Not sure how to feel about all this, I am still having a few hot flashes at nite, and very little sexual interest. A touch, but not much. I guess my next uPSA will be a bit more important than I first suspected, kind of nervous. Hoping for good news for u, best of luck. MM

Posts.Content: Hammer: You are going to be just fine. As Brother Fairwind has pointed out, you need to find out about the latest equipment, and make sure that your radiation treatment plan is going to cover all the bases. Prostate bed, lymph nodes, etc. Most men make it thru just fine, and the SE for me were not bad. I went thru it this summer, and if u want to get some exact information, I have all the particulars that I would be willing to share. PM me if needed. Don't worry. With your low Gleason score, most likely this is a local situation. I am sure a cure is right around the corner. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: MDA VISIT- treatment options

Posts.Content: Hello MRJ. Just wanted to welcome you to the forum. Many great people on here who are more than willing to help you through this. You are not alone. I would start doing my homework, so pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book the "Guide to surviving Prostate Cancer". 3rd edition. Given your PSA and G score, u are classified as high intermediate risk. My only concern would be your dominant pattern 4. But, u won't know anything until the final report is in. ( after surgery). For now, let's just go with learning, asking questions, and having us support you in any way possible. To be fair, your G7 ( 4+3) could always be downgraded. And all PCa can be curable if it has not escaped the gland. Of course, many are cured whose PCa has escaped, but remained local. If you need to talk, send me a PM. This forum has your back. Best Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Josey: I would agree with MF, as to what he believes your doctors are thinking. They must be factoring in a high PSA, and the 4+3...No reason to be pessimistic, the ADT and combined hormonal's could knock out any stray cells floating around. They think it kills stray cells, but are not 100% sure. It should also help with the existing tumor burden in the prostate. My guess is with that many positive cores, they must feel there is more to deal with than your biopsy would suggest. All that being said, for now all you know for sure is you are a G7, with a psa of 22. Nothing is confined, until it's confined. You still have a decent shot at a cure, so go with what they are telling you. Hang in there, your case is not that bad. Remember as Josey said...."dying ain't much of a livin boy"..good luck. MM

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Pomegranate juice is one of the many supplements that people take as a form of receiving antioxidants. Also found in broccoli, green tea, soy products, etc. Do they actually help prevent the recurrence of PCa? Unclear. One thing does seem a bit more certain, stop taking all these if u are receiving SRT. The antioxidants can have a adverse affect on the job radiation is trying to do destroying the tumor cells. MM
Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Well, my impression of your report? First I would find the nearest church and thank the good lord, and next I would fly to my favorite party spot with all my friends and spend 90% of my net worth on recreational drugs, hookers, and alcohol. The other 10% I would probably waste. I don't think I would use the cure word, this is cancer and only time will tell. But your doctor did use the word likely, and I would agree. To answer your margin question, u have what is referred to as a focal margin. Generally < 2/3 mm. This means there were only small bits of cancer seen at the ink, and that they probably got it all on the cut out. Congrats!! MM

My doc says I will need to wait until August to see my final results. I did the same thing with the kegels. More, less, none, trying everything. Congrats on the cancer control, and the ED front. Best, MM

Posts.Content: Good luck Nixter. While u have a pT3a pNo, your Gleason score is not very aggressive. This should bode well for u. Agree with what MF said regarding the uPSA...stay on top of your case as much as possible. Use the uPSA as your guide, with 0.03 or > being highly indicative of BCR for pt3 tumors ( higher risk tumors). Stay strong, MM

Posts.Title: Post-op Pathology

Posts.Content: Hello Rooster: Welcome to the forum, and best of luck in your upcoming surgery. In all my readings and speaking with surgery patients, I have never heard of any advanced imaging taking place like you are suggesting. Are you sure you understood that correctly? Unless you have a prior medical issue, I am not sure what they would be looking at. The recovery period for surgery is about 8 weeks. ( at least before you may start normal activities) To be honest, my hernia operation 5 years ago was MUCH more painful than the RALP. Many on here have had surgery, if u have specific questions, fire away. I am wondering if they would be looking at Prostate Anastomosis, the reconnection of the bladder and the urethra? Best Wishes for your complete recovery. MM

Posts.Title: 1st Trimix Experience & Doppler

Posts.Content: Mike A, and RobLee: As I am sure u are aware, I have the utmost respect for you and your contributions to this forum. ( I am speaking to RobLee). You already know how I feel about your courage and bravery as it pertains to your illness, and also dealing with your wife's issues. I meant no disrespect. Since I am reading in Mike's post a PSA of 40, and I am not hearing anything to the contrary, I can assure him that this high a level is to be taken seriously. With a G8 on biopsy, and a PSA of 40, Mike needs to take decisive action and formulate a game plan immediately. Mike when you get the results, please post and we can guide you on the correct path. When I read thru the thread and saw that nobody commented on your PSA, I was thinking perhaps you meant 4.0...and not 40. Not trying to scare you in anyway, just want you to have the best chance possible. And RobLee, while his PSA is not 3 digits, if it is indeed 40, that to me is a cause for concern. I was not being critical of u, I have great respect for your opinions, and the amount of time you give to others. No disrespect intended. Best to all, MM

Posts.Title: Got a new question

Posts.Content: Hello jgs: Sorry to hear what you Father has had to go thru. Does this story make sense? No, it does not. Who started the PCa treatment? Was he treated with anything other than RT? Any type of HT? What are his statistics as it pertains to the PC? PSA, G score, any type of diagnostic testing. Given his age, I assume that he did not have surgery option. Tell us more about his PCA, all you can remember. "This means to me that his pancreas is no longer working correctly or at all. Is this something that happens during prostate treatment? I cannot seem to find any other instances of this". I would agree with u. And I do not ever recall hearing anything like this. You need to pressure your RO who started this and get some answers. Call us in 2018 if anything changes? Jesus. What the hell is going on with his PCa treatment? Be firm and get some answers. Perhaps when we see his stats, others will be chiming. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Zytiga and Radiation, safe?

Posts.Content: Hello Akhlak: Welcome to the Forum. Based on what you have told us, I would say that you are being over treated. With that being said, you are in a different country, so I can only comment on what the standard of care would be if u lived in the United States. You have G6, which is the LEAST aggressive form of PCa. IMO, there is no need for you to be starting HT. With 6 positive cores out of 10, you will probably need some treatment, but you have plenty of time to research your options. Both surgery and radiation could offer you a cure, both with equal rates of success. I would pump the brakes on HT, and get a second opinion. HT has a lot of nasty SE, and if possible, you will want to avoid it. I am sure others will be chiming in soon... Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Requesting Opinion on My Prostate Cancer from Experienced People

Posts.Content: Pomegranate juice is one of the many supplements that people take as a form of receiving antioxidants. Also found in broccoli, green tea, soy products, etc. Do they actually help prevent the recurrence of PCa? Unclear. One thing does seem a bit more certain, stop taking all these if u are receiving SRT. The antioxidants can have a adverse affect on the job radiation is trying to do destroying the tumor cells. MM

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Prato: I am thankful for people like you. Your technical contributions to this forum are invaluable, only exceeded by your kindness, compassion, and willingness to give back. To all the regulars on this site who always give 100% of themselves, thank you. I can assure you it does not go unnoticed. Chuck, thank u for everything. You do so much i would be typing for hours if I had to list it all. Today I was watching CNBC financial news and one of the regular contributors named Joe Terrernova ( sp. ? ) started to speak. But it was not about financial news. One year ago this day, he was discovered to have a lump or mass in his liver. He started telling this story on live TV at noon. I was not sure where he was going with this. They thought it was cancer, but after several tests, etc, it appears to be just a benign mass. He spoke about being thankful. His wife, his children, etc. Then he said words that will stay with me forever. "What am I thankful for this holiday? the next 5 minutes." Kinda put things in perspective for me. Happy Thanksgiving to all. MM

Posts.Title: 3 Days To Go

Posts.Content: Jim215: As you know, u are my favorite on this forum. We are on the same page. My comments were not based on someone having PSA "anxiety". Pardon my straight talk. I think the entire PSA "anxiety" thing is way overrated. So we all have anxiety? Is that going to change the issue? Our numbers are what they are. No amount of "anxiety" or worry will change that. My comments to Gene were based on what he has already done in terms of his treatment. Like myself, it has been damn the torpedoes. If his PSA starts to rise from here, it will make little difference if he finds out at .1 or.2 or.3 etc. Both Gene and I, to just tell it like it is, are basically out of curative options. Talking about Gene, I am talking about myself. Unless there is something else out there I am not aware of. If my PSA starts to rise, I will probably be on HT for the rest of my life. Or as my RO says, it's her job to keep me alive for the next 10-15 years, then benefit from the new drugs and treatments that are in the pipeline. Neither Gene nor I know if we are cured, but a UPSA vs. a standard one is not going to make a difference in terms of HT/ADT starting etc. Hope I am making some sense. Hope u are doing well, always a pleasure to hear from u. Nobody gives the analogies better than u! You got to know when to hold, when to fold, when to walk away, when to run...... Geez, I think u know all that!! Best, MM

Posts.Title: New Chapter...Hospice

Posts.Content: To all my forum brothers: Just wanted to say hello to all and let everyone know my SRT was completed on 8/5/16. I want to thank all of u for the kindness and support that has been directed at me. Of course, also the technical knowledge of helping me develop a game plan. I got to ring the "bell" 3 times, as is the tradition at UC. All the techs and doctors came out and gave me a round of applause, which I felt kind of strange about. It was I that should have been applauding them, and I did. I hugged and thanked each one of them, brought all of them a few parting gifts, and when I spoke I started to get choked up. Could not finish my words, so just kind of thankfully bowed my head and left. Such a great team, I felt fortunate to be in their care. SE have not been all bad, some bowel and urinary issues that will go away in about 6-8 weeks. I was >90% dry going in, and for the most part have stayed that way. I am about 1/2 pad per day. So, I guess that might be one bullet I dodged. I did not celebrate on that Friday, right after I drove to a religious place near my home and went to the grotto. I said a few prayers and walked around this beautiful place. Trees, smell of fresh cut grass, open fields, and suddenly I was at peace with all this PCa mess. Don't mind admitting I had a meltdown, but re-grouped and got home. Where the rest of this journey takes me who knows, but I am glad to take it with all of my Forum brothers ( and sisters) by my side. Warmest Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Gene: Like myself, u have thrown everything at this including the kitchen sink. Given that, I can understand the logic that your urologist is using. For high risk cases, I like the UPSA. But given that u have done all u can do to this point, I would agree with the uro. It probably makes little difference if your PSA started rising which test gave you that information. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Use of ultra sensitive PSA tests

Posts.Content: Jim215: As you know, u are my favorite on this forum. We are on the same page. My comments were not based on someone having PSA "anxiety". Pardon my straight talk. I think the entire PSA "anxiety" thing is way overrated. So we all have anxiety? Is that going to change the issue? Our numbers are what they are. No amount of "anxiety" or worry will change that. My comments to Gene were based on what he has already done in terms of his treatment. Like myself, it has been damn the torpedoes. If his PSA starts to rise from here, it will make little difference if he finds out at .1 or.2 or.3 etc. Both Gene and I, to just tell it like it is, are basically out of curative options. Talking about Gene, I am talking about myself. Unless there is something else out there I am not aware of. If my PSA starts to rise, I will probably be on HT for the rest of my life. Or as my RO says, it's her job to keep me alive for the next 10-15 years, then benefit from the new drugs and treatments that are in the pipeline. Neither Gene nor I know if we are cured, but a UPSA vs. a standard one is not going to make a difference in terms of HT/ADT starting etc. Hope I am making some sense. Hope u are doing well, always a pleasure to hear from u. Nobody gives the analogies better than u! You got to know when to hold, when to fold, when to walk away, when to run...... Geez, I think u know all that!! Best, MM

Posts.Content: JJ: Welcome to the forum, lots of good folks here to lend support and advice. Nothing easy about this entire process, especially the part that your going thru now. I am a stage 3 and have had many dark moments, most during the initial parts of my treatment. Seemed surreal at times. Kept wanting to wake up from a bad dream, but it was/ is reality. Things will get better with time, and with each day the urge to stand up and fight and not give in or up will return. As brother MF has said, tell us a bit about you history, etc. I am sure others will be along to extend a warm welcome. Hang in, stay the course, and don't give up the ship. You are not alone. Best, MM
Posts.Title: I have metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Rob. He should be staged pt3b NO. He has SVI, that is pt3b. LVI and lymph node involvement are two different things. His pelvic LN taken during surgery were negative. That's NO. LVI being positive is saying that the tumor violated the lymph system, another way for it to spread. Same as me.
Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: Hello m. First, your PSA of .08 at this stage of the game is not the end of the world. I would wait to see what develops over the next few tests. That's not enough of a rise to make any judgements at this time. Why in the world would your oncologist want to take a PSA during radiation treatment? Would be of zero value, no sense at all. Why no HT here? Ur stats are very similar to mine. HT combined with SRT produce results 50% better than either one alone. Early ADT kills local and stray cells, before they get out of hand. Did u have ADT? Not sure where u r receiving treatment, very surprised and concerned that u have not thrown everything at this. Since our stats are alike, I will leave u with what my MO at the university of Chicago told me. It may be a tough ride, but your chances of survival are excellent. I'll go with that. Best, MM
Posts.Title: PSA after both prostate removal and radiation going up 2016

Posts.Content: What should you be doing different? Nothing. If you are the person who is responsible for getting this all together, well done! Dattoli, Moffit, and SK? Nice work Tinker. Keep us posted, and good that he has already started the Firmagon. Gives you some time while all this takes place. Best to you and dad, MM

Posts.Content: Cog: Since u asked for others to chime in, I will. Please go see that RO right away, your chances of success are far greater with your PSA where it is. The more it goes up, the worse the odds. This is a case of some uros who have acquired the annoying habit of waiting, and waiting, and waiting. U have shown a clear trend, I would be concerned enough to get a plan in action. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Hello Fairwind: As one high risk case to another, congrats on the 8 year mark since your dx. Since most of us have a tendency to follow those with a similar case, I have watched over yours the last 2.5 years since my dx. I admire your strength and courage, and the way u always have been helpful to the guys on here. Your contributions here have been many, and your knowledge of the subject matter invaluable. You have a lot of kick left in you Fairwind, this Chemo will just be another chapter in your long life. All of us, especially us high risk guys, owe u a big thank u for all your service here on the forum. I know first hand what u have been thru, and I have much respect for the way you have handled yourself. As you would say, stay strong and stay the course. With heartfelt admiration, MM

Posts.Title: Life-changing hiccup

Posts.Content: Rascally: Hello, and welcome to the forum. We are here to help. Yes, there are many of us with similar stats who would be more than willing to share our thoughts and experiences. First thing u should know. G9 is serious business. In your case perhaps even more so, given that your dad's PSA was only 2.7. When u have a PSA that low, and a high grade tumor, it can be even more aggressive. It is not giving off much PSA. Not trying to scare u, just wanting u to get your dad moving towards a treatment decision. Let's see what the bone and cat scan say, and go from there. Anger and a hopeless feeling are normal. On a positive note, any PCa that is contained can be cured. ( and even some that r not) Today's medical advances in PCa are mind-boggling. Your dad has every chance to be around for many, many years. Just get to a top notch cancer facility, and get a plan in place. Let us know how we can help. Once you get the results of the tests, get back to us. Hang in there, u are not alone. Best wishes, MM

Posts.Content: Nick: Sorry to hear about your post-op PSA, at this point in time it is quite clear that your surgery has failed. My question now is, why are you waiting to begin secondary treatment? In order to have any chance at a cure, you need to act now. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Content: Hey Nick: Sorry if I came across a bit harsh, our job here is to support and encourage our fellow PCa brothers, while telling them the truth as we see it. As Michael F states quite often, "none of us here are doctors". True enough. What are we? Men who have been afflicted with this terrible disease, and who have the benefit of walking in the path u now find yourself in. I don't blame you for following your doctors advise, their credentials seem impeccable. There is no use worrying about the past. What can you do from here? I would demand some answers. Become pro-active in your case. Something is wrong here. Could you provide the exact details of your case? Your PSA seems very high for a G7. What was your pathology? When your 4W PSA came out why did that not raise any concerns? By your 16W PSA....and still nothing. If u can create a signature, we can help. Remember, you are not alone. Don't worry about what was, let's move forward and find some answers. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Not Again......

Posts.Content: Hey Nick: Sorry if I came across a bit harsh, our job here is to support and encourage our fellow PCa brothers, while telling them the truth as we see it. As Michael F states quite often, "none of us here are doctors". True enough. What are we? Men who have been afflicted with this terrible disease, and who have the benefit of walking in the path u now find yourself in. I don't blame you for following your doctors advise, their credentials seem impeccable. There is no use worrying about the past. What can you do from here? I would demand some answers. Become pro-active in your case. Something is wrong here. Could you provide the exact details of your case? Your PSA seems very high for a G7. What was your pathology? When your 4W PSA came out why did that not raise any concerns? By your 16W PSA....and still nothing. If u can create a signature, we can help. Remember, you are not alone. Don't worry about what was, let's move forward and find some answers. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Hey All: First, thank u for the support in my prior posts before the biopsy. I will make a stats page as soon as I get the printed report. The damn printer was broken when I went in for the results. My biopsy was positive for PC in 9 of the 12 cores taken. 5 of the cores were 3+3=6 gleason. Please hang with me, I'm going from my notes. 4 cores were 4+4=8 Gleason. 3 were neg. My PSA on 9/12/15 was 5.9. Needless to say, when I heard Gleason 8, I kind of went into a trance. For now, I have started this at a well-respected hospital just outside Chicago. Love the uro. She gave me my info on the Partin Tables. Says the following: 59% chance contained to the prostate, 32% chance just outside the capsule, 6% chance it has gone to the seminal vesicles, and 3% chance it has gone to the Lymph nodes. Like I said, I was by myself when I got this news but the uro called me the next day and we talked on the phone. So I am sure this is correct. Cat scan and bone scan set for Monday the 12th. Uro says if all is good on those, I have a very good chance of a cure, ( surgery and possible radiation) depending on what happens. Also, suggests I get a second opinion. So, I am off to the University of Chicago Uro cancer team in another 2 weeks. ( When I get all my results and they can fit me in). Right now, my head is spinning and i'm doing a lot of pacing. I forgot to write down that % involvment aspect. I will include all on a stats page when I get the report. Maybe UC will review all this and have better news on the cores. Scared and freakin in the windy city. Congrats to chuck and pratoman on the good news. Pulling for u guys. I will keep u posted. Regards, John. Forgot to mention my current staging T1C
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Hey Jim: Hope u are feeling better. Yes, the AUS and the penile implant seem to have a lot in common in terms of healing and pulling down on the pump. The doctor told me to do this at 2 weeks, but it is still so sore and tender it hurts to do it. UGHHHH!! I went to the post-op appt. and was told activation will be in January... looking to hear more about your progress, and the effectiveness of your surgery/implant. Good luck my friend....MM

Enhanced imaging scans might be able to locate the problem. Let me know if I can help. Best, MM
Posts.Title: Honest Thoughts about Advanced Disease

Posts.Content: Nick: Sorry to hear about your post-op PSA, at this point in time it is quite clear that your surgery has failed. My question now is, why are you waiting to begin secondary treatment? You have a ticking time bomb inside you, and you are not seeing the doctor until August? You should be in line for both HT and SRT. You should have already started the process, and your MO and RO should have explained this to u. The chances of side effects from secondary treatment are 100%. No way to avoid them. In order to have any chance at a cure, you need to act now. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: Seems never ending

Posts.Content: Hey Rin: The fact that your first ever biopsy was negative may or may not mean anything. Several of the forum brothers have had negative biopsy's on the first round, only to have additional issues as time passes on. Meaning their PSA kept going up and wanting to find out the reason discovered PCa. If u did not know, a standard 12 core biopsy only covers about 10% of the entire gland. It is kind of like sticking a needle in a haystack. This is the reason that many Gleason scores can change, etc. Not all nodules are PCa, but if its hard, it more than likely is. You are 73. A PSA of 4.7 is not exactly screaming high. Perhaps some additional testing with advanced imaging of suspected areas is in order. You can also have one of several conditions that would elevate your PSA that have nothing to do with PCa. Press your doctor, and keep us informed. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Any experience with Prolia on Lupron HT?

Posts.Content: Daddy's girl. Hang in there. The initial few days, weeks of hearing all this can knock u for a loop. As each day passes, as you start getting a plan together, it will get better. The negative bone scan is great news. He will probably start some sort of ADT right away. That will stop any cancer in its tracks while the decision making process is getting in order. If his pain persists and he can't function, call the urologist and get some answers. Your dad needs a advocate, and it looks like he is lucky to have you as his daughter. Where do u live? Others will be chiming in soon with words of advice and encouragement. If comfortable, create a signature of your dads history with PSA, biopsy, any treatments, results, family history, etc. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Penile implant

Posts.Content: Mike: While I applaud your pro-active stance, right now u don't need to do anything. Your numbers could not be any better. Given your pT3b status, I would be testing every 8-12 weeks, and keeping track of my PSA in that manner. ( Even if I had to pay the cost myself) I have read the studies that you have referenced in your letter to Dr. Shah. For the 0.03 threshold that you mention, I do not think it matters on which PSA test it happens on. It will just be telling u that it is time to get your ducks in a row....or do so before hand. In my view the words adjuvant and salvage really are not that much different. Bottom line.....proceed when your PSA tells u so. Use the uPSA assay, and IF your psa should begin to rise, pull the trigger sooner rather than later. Standard of care for your case would be EBRT (IMRT), (IGRT). Today's radiation ( Varian Rapid Arc, or VMAT if I am remembering correctly) will get the job done, and is the radiation that most insurance company's will approve. I do not see why proton therapy would be any better for a salvage situation. BTW...with surgery and radiation, some of the side effects are hard to avoid. The price us high risk guys pay to keep our feet north of the grass. Be grateful if u can avoid ADT and slavage....for now u are doing well. Best, MM

Posts.Title: How many military vets are here?

Posts.Content: Fishhoops: Both ductal and intra-ductal are known to be serious and aggressive forms of prostate cancer. If u could post a signature regarding your treatment history and pathology report, it would give us a better idea of where you stand. Neither supplements or God had anything to do with it being contained. You may just have been lucky, or caught it in the nick of time. G8 is serious. Ductal is serious. You need to be seeing a PCa specialist who handles these type of cases. Not really clear if you knew about this at biopsy, or what your timeline is. Your scans and tests, which you say are negative now, may not stay that way over time. Your initial high PSA, G8, and ductal PCa are telling you that this game may be far from over. For now, congrats on the 3 month test. I would be consulting a MO and RO to secure opinions about your status moving forward. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: 5 months post surgery update

Posts.Content: Hello C33: Welcome to the forum, sorry about you having to be here. Our cases are quite alike, the difference being the +LN. So here in the states, you would be pT3bN1. Ok, the good news...I would like to stand and give your doctors a standing ovation. This is exactly the type of treatment ( aggressive style) that your case needs. Standard protocol is just what you are doing for a higher risk case. And your doctors are throwing everything at it including the kitchen sink. Well Done!!! You are to be applauded for taking this approach that may cure u. With a G9, positive margins, and +LN, I would be going all out. I assume your ADT will be lasting between 6 months and 2 years. IMHO, I would go the longer route. I would rather find out that 2 years was to long than 6 months being not enough. Congrats on your PSA. That is great news!! It shows that your body and cancer are responding to the treatments. Those are great numbers. For now I would not worry about being cured. I would just take one day at a time. When will you or I be cured? Ask each one of us in 10 years!!. My Medonc and RO have told me its there job to keep me around for 10-15 years. They say by then with the advances and treatments that are coming down the pike, there will be more drugs, etc. to keep guys like us around for many more years. Could we be cured, sure. But even if not we will have a long life ahead of us. This is a long road, hang tough. congrats on facing this head on. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: Rin: I'm not doctor, and I'm not saying your urologist is doing anything wrong. If I was standing in your shoes, I would not be waiting 6 months with a positive DRE. I would take the route of being pro-active. A nodule is not normal. If it's kind of fleshie feeling, maybe nothing. If not..... I would get a second opinion. Additional testing. What's your free PSA? I don't understand why your urologist is not concerned. Not trying to alarm you, I have just seen many examples of doctors who aren't on their game. But hey, it's your call. Best, MM
Posts.Title: Maybe, maybe not? Whats up?

Posts.Content: Hey Rin: The fact that your first ever biopsy was negative may or may not mean anything. Several of the forum brothers have had negative biopsy's on the first round, only to have additional issues as time passes on. Meaning their PSA kept going up and wanting to find out the reason discovered PCa. If u did not know, a standard 12 core biopsy only covers about 10% of the entire gland. It is kind of like sticking a needle in a haystack. This is the reason that many Gleason scores can change, etc. Not all nodules are PCa, but if its hard, it more than likely is. You are 73. A PSA of 4.7 is not exactly screaming high. Perhaps some additional testing with advanced imaging of suspected areas is in order. You can also have one of several conditions that would elevate your PSA that have nothing to do with PCa. Press your doctor, and keep us informed. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Daddy's girl: Sorry to hear of your fathers difficult diagnosis. Given the your dads PCa is small cell, I would be looking to get treated at a major cancer cancer. You need a specialist who is well versed in this type of carcianoma, as this is not garden variety PCa. ( adenocarcinoma) If it has not spread to the LN or bones, you may still have a chance at a cure or at least a long durable remission. Many people with the more aggressive types of PCa use several treatment modalities to achieve cancer control. Seeing a RO is a great start, but make sure you start to develop a game plan. Time is not on your side. I'm sure a CT scan will be in order, and for now there is no telling what the pain is. It could be many things. Focus on getting to the right place and seeing the correct doctors. Don't lose hope, many people with advanced disease can live long lives with today's medical advances. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Assessment & suggestions regarding my advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello C33: Welcome to the forum, sorry about you having to be here. Our cases are quite alike, the difference being the +LN. So here in the states, you would be pT3bN1. Ok, the good news...I would like to stand and give your doctors a standing ovation. This is exactly the type of treatment ( aggressive style) that your case needs. Standard protocol is just what you are doing for a higher risk case. And your doctors are throwing everything at it including the kitchen sink. Well Done!!! You are to be applauded for taking this approach that may cure u. With a G9, positive margins, and +LN, I would be going all out. I assume your ADT will be lasting between 6 months and 2 years. IMHO, I would go the longer route. I would rather find out that 2 years was to long than 6 months being not enough. Congrats on your PSA. That is great news!! It shows that your body and cancer are responding to the treatments. Those are great numbers. For now I would not worry about being cured. I would just take one day at a time. When will you or I be cured? Ask each one of us in 10 years!!. My Medonc and RO have told me its there job to keep me around for 10-15 years. They say by then with the advances and treatments that are coming down the pike, there will be more drugs, etc. to keep guys like us around for many more years. Could we be cured, sure. But even if not we will have a long life ahead of us. This is a long road, hang tough. congrats on facing this head on. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Assessment & suggestions regarding my advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello C33: Welcome to the forum, sorry about you having to be here. Our cases are quite alike, the difference being the +LN. So here in the states, you would be pT3bN1. Ok, the good news...I would like to stand and give your doctors a standing ovation. This is exactly the type of treatment ( aggressive style) that your case needs. Standard protocol is just what you are doing for a higher risk case. And your doctors are throwing everything at it including the kitchen sink. Well Done!!! You are to be applauded for taking this approach that may cure u. With a G9, positive margins, and +LN, I would be going all out. I assume your ADT will be lasting between 6 months and 2 years. IMHO, I would go the longer route. I would rather find out that 2 years was to long than 6 months being not enough. Congrats on your PSA. That is great news!! It shows that your body and cancer are responding to the treatments. Those are great numbers. For now I would not worry about being cured. I would just take one day at a time. When will you or I be cured? Ask each one of us in 10 years!!. My Medonc and RO have told me its there job to keep me around for 10-15 years. They say by then with the advances and treatments that are coming down the pike, there will be more drugs, etc. to keep guys like us around for many more years. Could we be cured, sure. But even if not we will have a long life ahead of us. This is a long road, hang tough. congrats on facing this head on. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: how long after radiation can I go back to roughage?

Posts.Content: " Most radiation oncologists use the "Phoenix" definition of biochemical (PSA) recurrence which is a PSA of nadir +2. So any increase less than 2 ng/ml over your lowest PSA since treatment is officially a bounce. The problem is knowing if your lowest PSA so far is really your nadir, which may not occur for two years or more after radiation. With your history of PSA fluctuations, it may be that you have some recalcitrant prostatitis going on too that may continue to complicate your ability to distinguish a bounce from a biochemical recurrence. I'm two years out and my PSA is still on a long-term declining trend with a few bounces along the way. My RO has a standard line of "let's wait another 3 months and see what happens." It all depends on when those cancer cells come out of hibernation and decide to replicate, at which time the "time bomb" implanted by the radiation will kill them." To be clear, these are not my words. I found this for your benefit. If this in not appropriate, I am sure Chuck will address it. For those with RO as a primary treatment I found this for u to read....hope this helps. This does not apply to those of us who had surgery and then SRT. In my case my RO has stated " we just want to see stability or lower". Then is no Bounce to be considered. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Could I please ask for your help again, re: PSA

Posts.Content: Tilly: Welcome back to the Forum. I am not a doctor, but my opinion is that u r correct, that is not good news. At about the 2 month mark after radiation, the RO will test the PSA to begin a new baseline number. What the RO should be looking for is for the PSA to remain stable or go down. Now I will say that you have not told us what he PSA was prior to the RT. However, my guess is that with a PSA of 0.01 and then going up to .3, this would be indicative of some loose cells in there. There is a radiation "bounce theory" where that could be normal, but at least with surgery and then SRT this would not be a good sign. Do u know what his Nadir was/is? In any event stay positive, they are many treatments available that may still cure u and give many, many years of a quality life. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Could I please ask for your help again, re: PSA

Posts.Content: Hey Rf51: Welcome to the forum. With your high -risk dx, as Chuck has pointed out, please speak with all the various specialists before deciding on a treatment course. And please ask them about SE!! My experience is that sometimes we do not get the entire story. The RO and the surgeon, (especially surgeons painting a picture that is a bit rose colored) may tell you one thing, but your specific case may not turn out like that. All I am saying is that the SE are no joke, and for us high-risk guys, may last much longer than most. One never knows. As Jim215 points out, surgery does de-bulk the tumor. However, it is my understanding that radiation may as well. Please ask these questions to the appropriate doctor. Wishing you good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Hey David. Welcome to the forum. Sorry you have to be here, but lots of good people and information to help you make a decision that is best for you. First, you mentioned you are a veteran. Thank u for your service. If you look at my signature, you will see we have a few things in common. I have 5 cores G6, and 4 cores G7 (4+3). Don't get to set on those Gleason scores, these things tend to be fluid and can change once you receive your post-op report ( should you choose surgery) of if you get a second opinion. I was downgraded from G8 on a second opinion. I'm sure there is a lot going on in your mind now, but it also appears you caught it early. With a G7 (4+3) we are both on the higher end of intermediate risk. But, with a T1 or T2 staging, that means the doc thinks it's contained to the prostate, and that is good news. You have a good chance for a cure. Get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, the guide to surviving prostate cancer, 3rd edition. It will help you understand what lies ahead. Lean on this forum for answers, lots of really smart guys to help u. keep us posted on your progress. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Diagnosed in Atlanta

Posts.Content: Hello Wendy: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here, but u have landed at a great place. I see a few good signs and one that concerns me a bit. Gleason 6 and G7 (3+4) are the kind of PCa you want if it happens to u. G6 is low-risk, and G7 ( 3+4) is low intermediate risk. Both of these are quite curable and either surgery or radiation will offer you a cure. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostate cancer. ( 3rd edition). Lots of great information to get u up to speed. While 3/14 cores isn't to bad, I am not sure you would qualify for certain AS protocols. AS may or may not be a option, and it is not just for the elderly. It just depends upon your situation. Please keep in mind that all cases are different, no 2 are alike. What concerns me in your case is the PSA of 21. That's getting up there. I would consult with your Uro and see if they feel additional testing or enhanced imaging is in order. If all you have is low-risk G6/7 with that high of a PSA, god bless. Not trying to scare you, just wanting to alert you to the fact that something else may be hiding in there. A biopsy only examines a very small portion of the gland, so one never knows. Is Davinci the best option for him? That depends. If his clinical staging is T1 or T2, I would say yes. If not, that could bring other options into play. As you get more information, let us know. Lets see what the scans say, and go from there. We are here to help, keep us posted. Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Hey David. Welcome to the forum. Sorry you have to be here, but lots of good people and information to help you make a decision that is best for you. First, you mentioned you are a veteran. Thank u for your service. If you look at my signature, you will see we have a few things in common. I have 5 cores G6, and 4 cores G7 (4+3). Don't get to set on those Gleason scores, these things tend to be fluid and can change once you receive your post-op report ( should you choose surgery) of if you get a second opinion. I was downgraded from G8 on a second opinion. I'm sure there is a lot going on in your mind now, but it also appears you caught it early. With a G7 (4+3) we are both on the higher end of intermediate risk. But, with a T1 or T2 staging, that means the doc thinks it's contained to the prostate, and that is good news. You have a good chance for a cure. Get a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, the guide to surviving prostate cancer, 3rd edition. It will help you understand what lies ahead. Lean on this forum for answers, lots of really smart guys to help u. keep us posted on your progress. Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Feather: Sorry to hear of your current situation. Standing in your shoes, it's time to reach out to a MO. With your quick PSADT, I would ask your URO about adding a MO who has experience with recurrent PCa. Have you ever had ADT before? Front line hormonal therapy will probably start with casodex and then lupron. Should start controlling your PSA. No, your not in deep tapioca. But don't delay this any further. Good luck. MM
Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: Hello Dave: U don't need to hold it in longer, u just need to time it correctly for when you go in. If u are having SBRT, I would assume that your number of treatments is 10 or less? It takes about 20 minutes for 20oz. of water to fill the bladder and fell like u have to go. Maybe 30....My appt. was at 4pm every day...and they ran a tight ship. I drank the water on the drive, and started at 330. Just got the timing down...it can get tough when your laying on the table, but it is more of a timing issue than anything else...If u can hold it for an hour, u should be fine, assuming no delays. Good luck, MM

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Hello CC33: Assuming that u have at least 1 nerve bundle left, you do have a chance. I am currently working with a doctor who is a specialist in penile rehab. Both of my nerve bundles were spared in the operation, but I am also on ADT and had SRT. The RO said that she avoided the penile blub, so I am good to go there. The doctor has me taking 100mg of sildenafil every other day. In addition, taking the shots 2x a week. The point being to get the blood moving anyway you can. You don't need to reach a climax, but u do need to get things going, by whatever means possible. With the shots, I am seeing some signs of life, but not erect enough to have intercourse. But, getting there. Hope this helps. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Or Not Nerve Sparing That Is The Question

Posts.Content: Hello Wendy: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here, but u have landed at a great place. I see a few good signs and one that concerns me a bit. Gleason 6 and G7 (3+4) are the kind of PCa you want if it happens to u. G6 is low-risk, and G7 ( 3+4) is low intermediate risk. Both of these are quite curable and either surgery or radiation will offer you a cure. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostate cancer. ( 3rd edition). Lots of great information to get u up to speed. While 3/14 cores isn't to bad, I am not sure you would qualify for certain AS protocols. AS may or may not be a option, and it is not just for the elderly. It just depends upon your situation. Please keep in mind that all cases are different, no 2 are alike. What concerns me in your case is the PSA of 21. That's getting up there. I would consult with your Uro and see if they feel additional testing or enhanced imaging is in order. If all you have is low-risk G6/7 with that high of a PSA, god bless. Not trying to scare you, just wanting to alert you to the fact that something else may be hiding in there. A biopsy only examines a very small portion of the gland, so one never knows. Is Davinci the best option for him? That depends. If his clinical staging is T1 or T2, I would say yes. If not, that could bring other options into play. As you get more information, let us know. Lets see what the scans say, and go from there. We are here to help, keep us posted. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Could I please ask for your help again, re: PSA

Posts.Content: Tilly: Welcome back to the Forum. I am not a doctor, but my opinion is that u r correct, that is not good news. At about the 2 month mark after radiation, the RO will test the PSA to begin a new baseline number. What the RO should be looking for is for the PSA to remain stable or go down. Now I will say that you have not told us what he PSA was prior to the RT. However, my guess is that with a PSA of 0.01 and then going up to .3, this would be indicative of some loose cells in there. There is a radiation "bounce theory" where that could be normal, but at least with surgery and then SRT this would not be a good sign. Do u know what his Nadir was/is? In any event stay positive, they are many treatments available that may still cure u and give many, many years of a quality life. Best Wishes, MM

Posts.Title: Could I please ask for your help again, re: PSA

Posts.Content: " Most radiation oncologists use the "Phoenix" definition of biochemical (PSA) recurrence which is a PSA of nadir +2. So any increase less than 2 ng/ml over your lowest PSA since treatment is officially a bounce. The problem is knowing if your lowest PSA so far is really your nadir, which may not occur for two years or more after radiation. With your history of PSA fluctuations, it may be that you have some recalcitrant prostatitis going on too that may continue to complicate your ability to distinguish a bounce from a biochemical recurrence. I'm two years out and my PSA is still on a long-term declining trend with a few bounces along the way. My RO has a standard line of "let's wait another 3 months and see what happens." It all depends on when those cancer cells come out of hibernation and decide to replicate, at which time the "time bomb" implanted by the radiation will kill them." To be clear, these are not my words. I found this for your benefit. If this in not appropriate, I am sure Chuck will address it. For those with RO as a primary treatment I found this for u to read....hope this helps. This does not apply to those of us who had surgery and then SRT. In my case my RO has stated " we just want to see stability or lower". Then is no Bounce to be considered. Good Luck, MM

Posts.Title: Back in the Zero Club

Posts.Content: Gene: Hello there. Glad you found this forum, and we are all here to help. My case is very similar to yours, and I have been down the exact road which you are now traveling. I would like to say "kudos" for all you have accomplished and your decision making process to date. Very well done. I would encourage you to forge ahead, not just with AR, but also with a course of HT. First, a PSA of <0.1 is not necessarily undetectable. I would get a UPSA and see what that tells u. Many doctors now in high risk cases are using 0.03 as the cut off mark. More times than not with your profile and mine, .05 can turn into .1 and higher in short order. You are a pT3a NO, with a G9 and PM. Most likely u have some PCa cells that are local in your prostate bed. Your doctors are giving you sound advice. I would also ask about 4 months of casodex, followed by 6-18 months of lupron injections. HT can be tough, but it is manageable and I am getting thru it. Studies have shown that RT/ADT are 50% more effective together than either one alone. The ADT should begin about 8 weeks before RT starts, to "soften up" the cancer cells for the attack. Also it may kill off other PCa cells that may not be in the bed, but are still ripe to be attacked. ( we both hope) Ask your RO about doing not just the bed, but also the pelvic lymph nodes. With a G9, I would be throwing everything at this including the kitchen sink. The good news is your case is not as bad as you think. You could be cured. Only time will tell. I am a pT3bNO and my RO has told me many cases of folks like me who are around for many, many years. She has guys worse than us ( positive LN) who are around 15-20 years after treatment. and still going. Don't get down, stay focused. What you do NOW is what matters. Don't delay, and my guess is that a cure for you is very possible. I will comment on the ED matter tomorrow, I just saw a specialist with Northshore health. We will be in that game in no time!!!! don't expect to much right now, you just had surgery. I will check in with you tomorrow. Warmest Regards, MM16.....Hey it's that time of year....GO BLUE!!!!

Posts.Title: New to the "Club"

Posts.Content: Hello Wendy: Welcome to the forum, sorry u have to be here, but u have landed at a great place. I see a few good signs and one that concerns me a bit. Gleason 6 and G7 (3+4) are the kind of PCa you want if it happens to u. G6 is low-risk, and G7 ( 3+4) is low intermediate risk. Both of these are quite curable and either surgery or radiation will offer you a cure. Do yourself a favor and pick up a copy of Dr. Patrick Walsh's book, Surviving Prostate cancer. ( 3rd edition). Lots of great information to get u up to speed. While 3/14 cores isn't to bad, I am not sure you would qualify for certain AS protocols. AS may or may not be a option, and it is not just for the elderly. It just depends upon your situation. Please keep in mind that all cases are different, no 2 are alike. What concerns me in your case is the PSA of 21. That's getting up there. I would consult with your Uro and see if they feel additional testing or enhanced imaging is in order. If all you have is low-risk G6/7 with that high of a PSA, god bless. Not trying to scare you, just wanting to alert you to the fact that something else may be hiding in there. A biopsy only examines a very small portion of the gland, so one never knows. Is Davinci the best option for him? That depends. If his clinical staging is T1 or T2, I would say yes. If not, that could bring other options into play. As you get more information, let us know. Lets see what the scans say, and go from there. We are here to help, keep us posted. Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Hello Keith: Throwing my 2 cents into the ring. I was dx in early October of 2015. I went for a second opinion at the UC at the end of October, and my cancer at that time was downgraded to G7 from G8. I was a cT2c, after being examined by the uro surgeon. His 1st appt. for surgery was 12/29/2015, and i asked him if waiting would be a potential negative for my case. Based on the evidence at hand, he said I had up to 3-6 months before any changes would occur to alter my case. Now, that was based on G6-7 PCa. As things turned out, well take a look at my signature. I would agree with the others, sooner always beats later, if at all possible. Best to u, MM

Posts.Content: Steve: I did do the research on EBRT ( IMRT/ IGRT) when I was making my decision. I don't remember anyone on here using SBRT as a primary treatment. Hypofractionated and sterotactic radiation are being evaluated for long-term data and from what I understand, MAY be considered for certain patients. As I am sure you are aware, the dose for SBRT is substantially higher. Since travel is not a issue, I would go to a major cancer center and get all the information you can before deciding on any radiation plan. Since SBRT is given in five or fewer treatments, my guess is u will have to qualify. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Stage IV Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Gene: Hello there. Glad you found this forum, and we are all here to help. My case is very similar to yours, and I have been down the exact road which you are now traveling. I would like to say "kudos" for all you have accomplished and your decision making process to date. Very well done. I would encourage you to forge ahead, not just with AR, but also with a course of HT. First, a PSA of <0.1 is not necessarily undetectable. I would get a UPSA and see what that tells u. Many doctors now in high risk cases are using 0.03 as the cut off mark. More times than not with your profile and mine, .05 can turn into .1 and higher in short order. You are a pT3a NO, with a G9 and PM. Most likely u have some PCa cells that are local in your prostate bed. Your doctors are giving you sound advice. I would also ask about 4 months of casodex, followed by 6-18 months of lupron injections. HT can be tough, but it is manageable and I am getting thru it. Studies have shown that RT/ADT are 50% more effective together than either one alone. The ADT should begin about 8 weeks before RT starts, to "soften up" the cancer cells for the attack. Also it may kill off other PCa cells that may not be in the bed, but are still ripe to be attacked. ( we both hope) Ask your RO about doing not just the bed, but also the pelvic lymph nodes. With a G9, I would be throwing everything at this including the kitchen sink. The good news is your case is not as bad as you think. You could be cured. Only time will tell. I am a pT3bNO and my RO has told me many cases of folks like me who are around for many, many years. She has guys worse than us ( positive LN) who are around 15-20 years after treatment. and still going. Don't get down, stay focused. What you do NOW is what matters. Don't delay, and my guess is that a cure for you is very possible. I will comment on the ED matter tomorrow, I just saw a specialist with Northshore health. We will be in that game in no time!!!! don't expect to much right now, you just had surgery. I will check in with you tomorrow. Warmest Regards, MM16.....Hey it's that time of year....GO BLUE!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello Mike: Welcome home to the other side. Glad to see you are up and around. The PAFP is just that, fatty tissue. In your case, why did they excise it? Having positive lymphatic disease there is actually rare. I had heard of this, but really do not know to much more about it. I would be asking why they were checking in the first place. Metastatic disease in there would be a adverse pathological feature, but i don't think it would be much different than positive LN elsewhere. I would be interested in hearing the explanation. Hang in there Mike, i am sure it is nothing. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Anterior Fat Pad - Huh?

Posts.Content: Gene: Hello there. Glad you found this forum, and we are all here to help. My case is very similar to yours, and I have been down the exact road which you are now traveling. I would like to say "kudos" for all you have accomplished and your decision making process to date. Very well done. I would encourage you to forge ahead, not just with AR, but also with a course of HT. First, a PSA of <0.1 is not necessarily undetectable. I would get a UPSA and see what that tells u. Many doctors now in high risk cases are using 0.03 as the cut off mark. More times than not with your profile and mine, .05 can turn into .1 and higher in short order. You are a pT3a NO, with a G9 and PM. Most likely u have some PCa cells that are local in your prostate bed. Your doctors are giving you sound advice. I would also ask about 4 months of casodex, followed by 6-18 months of lupron injections. HT can be tough, but it is manageable and I am getting thru it. Studies have shown that RT/ADT are 50% more effective together than either one alone. The ADT should begin about 8 weeks before RT starts, to "soften up" the cancer cells for the attack. Also it may kill off other PCa cells that may not be in the bed, but are still ripe to be attacked. ( we both hope) Ask your RO about doing not just the bed, but also the pelvic lymph nodes. With a G9, I would be throwing everything at this including the kitchen sink. The good news is your case is not as bad as you think. You could be cured. Only time will tell. I am a pT3bNO and my RO has told me many cases of folks like me who are around for many, many years. She has guys worse than us ( positive LN) who are around 15-20 years after treatment. and still going. Don't get down, stay focused. What you do NOW is what matters. Don't delay, and my guess is that a cure for you is very possible. I will comment on the ED matter tomorrow, I just saw a specialist with Northshore health. We will be in that game in no time!!!! don't expect to much right now, you just had surgery. I will check in with you tomorrow. Warmest Regards, MM16.....Hey it's that time of year....GO BLUE!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello Keith: Throwing my 2 cents into the ring. I was dx in early October of 2015. I went for a second opinion at the UC at the end of October, and my cancer at that time was downgraded to G7 from G8. I was a cT2c, after being examined by the uro surgeon. His 1st appt. for surgery was 12/29/2015, and i asked him if waiting would be a potential negative for my case. Based on the evidence at hand, he said I had up to 3-6 months before any changes would occur to alter my case. Now, that was based on G6-7 PCa. As things turned out, well take a look at my signature. I would agree with the others, sooner always beats later, if at all possible. Best to u, MM

Posts.Content: Nick: Do not make to many assumptions at this early stage in the game. It has only been a few weeks, and remember when u are lying down and sleeping, u are not dealing with gravity. All u can do for now is the kegel's, and start a walking routine to build up the muscles. It is way to early to worry about anything. Just take one day at a time, and measure your progress in weeks or weekly. BTW...was your G 4+3 downgraded to 3+4? If so, that is a big bonus for u. Stay strong and stay the course, MM

Posts.Title: Bone metastasis

Posts.Content: Big: I think u are over thinking all this. Your pathology report is not all bad. For now, your PSA is ZERO! The SK nonogram is just that, a nonogram. It gives you the range of statistics of men who have been treated with your pathology. Not saying it isn't somewhat reliable, but you are a person. All of us are different, you can't be making hard and fast conclusions based upon a nomogram. They are prediction tools designed to help a patient understand what may or may not be in front of them. "Maybe I am not understanding the technical aspects but how can there be any pertinent data on SRT that is done without any indications of a bio-chemical recurrence as the the wild card is that there is none, there-fore it worked" THe SRT nonogram is based on people who have had a recurrence, and what the odds are of it being treated with success. ( based on your risk factors). For now, just take it easy. You are doing fine, don't borrow any trouble. Based on your pathology, IF additional treatment were necessary, your chances of it being a local disease are high. Especially with the PM, that argues well for a cure. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: New PSA Results & A Little Confusion About Stuff

Posts.Content: Rob: Ok, pump the brakes. There is so much to say here, I don't know where to start. NO is not something that u add yourself. Get ready to feel better...NO means that your Lymph Nodes that were taken during surgery were negative. You had what is called a ePLND. ( extended pelvic lymph node dissection). You were negative. Trust me, that's a great start. The lingo is as follows...p stands for pathological, T is tumor, 3 is stage 3, b is for seminal vesicle invasion ( either one or both). If there is a c in front of all that, it stands for clinical. NO does not say a damn thing about your lifespan, other than thank god u did not also have that. More to follow.....Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Thirty-nine days after IMRT

Posts.Content: Rob: The seriousness of SVI has changed over the last 15-20 years. Many years ago, SVI was a very poor prognostic indicator. This was mainly because many of the cases that came in back then were of a very advanced nature. PSA testing and DRE screening were not like they have been in recent times. Many men with SVI back then were already to far gone. With the advent of regular screening, this has changed. So, many of those stats were not applicable to today's men. There is also good and bad SVI, or should I say one being less of a worry than the other. I will get my notes from my office tomorrow, and give you the medical lingo. In a nutshell, the SV look like rabbit ears. If the tumor invaded the SV at the bottom, it's a far less serious situation. That would mean that the tumor just got thru the tissue and penetrated like a PM issue. However, if the tumor is found in the "ear" of the SV, that would mean it got there thru the bloodstream, etc. Not good. I am giving you the layman's explanation, I will give the medical tomorrow. This info was given to me by the doctors at the UC....enough said. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: New PSA Results & A Little Confusion About Stuff

Posts.Content: Rob: Ok, pump the brakes. There is so much to say here, I don't know where to start. NO is not something that u add yourself. Get ready to feel better...NO means that your Lymph Nodes that were taken during surgery were negative. You had what is called a ePLND. ( extended pelvic lymph node dissection). You were negative. Trust me, that's a great start. The lingo is as follows...p stands for pathological, T is tumor, 3 is stage 3, b is for seminal vesicle invasion ( either one or both). If there is a c in front of all that, it stands for clinical. NO does not say a damn thing about your lifespan, other than thank god u did not also have that. More to follow.....Regards, MM

Posts.Content: Nippbee; Welcome to the forum. Hope u are healing well from the surgery. What you are dealing with now is called the half-life of PSA. There is a mathematical formula that you can plug in your PSA to calculate the exact time it will take to get a accurate reading. Bottom line: For most men, 6-8 weeks gives a very accurate indication of where you stand. At 12 weeks, you can take it to the bank. Not knowing anything else about your case, that's about all I can tell u. Wishing you the best, MM

Posts.Title: Had preop call with nurse for HDR BT, guess this is real!

Posts.Content: Hello Lee. Welcome to the forum, u will find many good people to offer lots of support. Your history was a bit hard to read in the order that you presented it, but here is what I can tell u. Your PSA right after the RP was just fine. 3 months later it was then .63. You don't state if u then began ADT prior to the SRT. Doesn't matter now, but for all newbies out there who read this, It may have given u a better chance at success. Your PCa right after SRT was 3.53. That was not a good sign. Should have been around the .5 area. U didn't really have a big turnaround, your PCa was not a local case to start with. I don't want to rehash what I think you should or should not have done, that's already gone. Your PSA never went undetected while on lupron. You need to see a MO to get this straightened out. Did you have a RO, I assume? There is still plenty u can do, I believe there are several hormonal therapies available to u, lupron is just step 1. Plenty of bullets to be fired. U can spot radiate for just one met, maybe some form of SBRT. It won't cure u, but it can be of added benefit. Hang in there, lots of positives to keep you going for years, but u need to see a MO right now. Keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Roller Coaster Getting Bumpy last few weeks

Posts.Content: Hey Lee. First, hang in there and feel free to vent and ask as many questions as you like. We are here to help u, and be a support system. I know what u mean about your head spinning, I have been spinning for quite awhile, but it gets better with time. Ok, as far as your stats. Just start at the top and go in chronological order of time. For everything. Just start with the first date and list it on down. This way other members can see what treatments you have received and when. Also your PSA at certain times, etc. I see the Brother Brandon has answered many of your questions, and I agree with what he has said. Lee, hear me good on this. While your PCa at this point probably cannot be cured, know that you are not going anywhere. There are several treatments and 1st, 2nd, and 3rd line therapies that can effectively manage your cancer for many, many years. You need to see a MO who is a specialist in PCa. That is step 1. If you would post exactly where you live, perhaps some folks on here can recommend someone for u. Keep us posted. My best, MM

Posts.Title: Just had the Prostate Ultrasound and Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello Lee. Welcome to the forum, u will find many good people to offer lots of support. Your history was a bit hard to read in the order that you presented it, but here is what I can tell u. Your PSA right after the RP was just fine. 3 months later it was then .63. You don't state if u then began ADT prior to the SRT. Doesn't matter now, but for all newbies out there who read this, It may have given u a better chance at success. Your PCa right after SRT was 3.53. That was not a good sign. Should have been around the .5 area. U didn't really have a big turnaround, your PCa was not a local case to start with. I don't want to rehash what I think you should or should not have done, that's already gone. Your PSA never went undetected while on lupron. You need to see a MO to get this straightened out. Did you have a RO, I assume? There is still plenty u can do, I believe there are several hormonal therapies available to u, lupron is just step 1. Plenty of bullets to be fired. U can spot radiate for just one met, maybe some form of SBRT. It won't cure u, but it can be of added benefit. Hang in there, lots of positives to keep you going for years, but u need to see a MO right now. Keep us posted. Best, MM

Posts.Content: R2F: First of all, in this case, I am not sure what exactly his 3 month PSA is. Did he mean <.1 on a standard test? Is there a typo? Not sure given the lack of information, including his pathology report. As I am sure u are aware, there is a Atlantic ocean between <.1 and .1 on the standard test. IMO, if at 3 months I was not <.1, I would assume that I have a issue. The half life of PSA still may be around at 6 weeks, but not at 12. And I sure as hell would not be waiting around to see what is happening. IMO, the likelihood of it going down to <0.03 would be remote. Just sayin. MM

Posts.Content: Hey Dooley. Hope you are hanging in there. If u could list your stats on the signature page, some of our smarter members may be able to help you out. Kind of tough not knowing any of your history. There may not be any reason for you to feel pessimistic about your situation. Each case is different, and the important thing is to catch it early. Sorry, I do see that u gave some information in your opening post. the more the better. Take your time and don't feel rushed, another month or so will probably not matter. Do u have a current staging? Did the surgeon do a DRE? What medical basis are you using to assume it is not contained? Keep us posted on your progress. We are all in your corner. BTW...my Gleason went from 8-7-9.......let's hope yours goes to all 3+3. Regards, MM

Posts.Title: Question for the members re: Repeat biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello Mr. Ed. Welcome to the forum. It's sounds like you are in good hands and have done your homework. You are where I started out, which was G7 ( 4+3). I choose surgery, at the time my staging was cT2c. I am using my I phone, which doesn't show my signature. But I post a lot, u can find it. Things turned out to be upgraded, and I have been thru the ringer. Reason I'm telling u this..... not sure I would have made the surgery decision if I would have known my high/ risk profile. Right now, you are intermediate high risk. Any Gleason primary pattern 4 can be a wild card. Check out all options, the side effects of surgery, radiation, and HT have been tough. They are no damn joke. What I'm saying is that it's a big decision. Make it and don't look back, just know all the facts before hand. Ask questions here, the various doctors will preach or push their specialty. One problem, they don't have to live with it. Good luck, pick up Dr. Patrick Walsh's book. Good Read. Best, MM
