Posts.Title: Kind of freaking out a little!

Posts.Content: Probability of remaining recurrence-free after salvage radiation In 2007, Stephenson et al. published a nomogram that predicted the probability of success of salvage radiation after post-prostatectomy biochemical failure. Biochemical failure was defined as a PSA0.2 ng/ml. Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center has made the nomogram publicly available at this link. But that data was put together before ultrasensitive PSA tests became widely available, and before three randomized clinical trials demonstrated an advantage to adjuvant radiation over waiting. Several studies now suggest (see this link) that early salvage may provide the same benefit as adjuvant radiation therapy, but with less risk of overtreatment. Tendulkar et al. have now updated the Stephenson nomogram.. The original nomogram was based on 1,540 patients treated between 1987 and 2005 at 17 tertiary care facilities. All patients had a confirmed PSA 0.2 ng/ml before SRT. Outcomes were based on 6-year progression-free probability after SRT. The updated nomogram is based on 2,460 patients treated between 1987 and 2013 at 10 academic medical centers. It included post-op ultrasensitive PSA test results for some (18 percent) of the patients, but only 18 patients were treated at a PSA0.05 ng/ml. The nomogram predicts 5- and 10-year probability of freedom from biochemical failure (PSA0.2 ng/ml) after SRT. The authors also constructed a nomogram that predicts 5- and 10-year probability of incidence of metastasis. Their model has a predictive accuracy of about 68 percent for freedom from biochemical failure, and 74 percent for incidence of metastasis. The tables below approximate the nomogram for predicting the 10-year probability of remaining free of biochemical failure after SRT treatment. Risk Factor Score (points) Points ADT Yes: 0 No: 49 Gleason score 6: 0 7: 54 8: 70 9/10: 90 Extraprostatic Extension No:0 Yes:22 Surgical Margins Positive: 0 Negative: 27 Seminal Vesicle Invasion No: 0 Yes: 24 Pre-RT PSA (ng/ml) 0.05: 2.5 0.1: 5 0.2:10 0.3: 15 0.5: 25 1.0: 50 1.5: 75 Radiation dose (Gy) 66 Gy: 0 <66 Gy: 17 Total points Total points Probability 100 70% 150 50% 195 30% 220 20% 245 10% 265 5% As an example, take the case of a man who, after his prostatectomy, had a Gleason score of 9 (=90 points), seminal vesicle invasion (=24 points), margins were negative (=27 points), PSA before SRT was 0.5 ng/ml (=25 points), and his radiation oncologist plans on treating him with a dose of 65 Gy (=17 points) without ADT(=49 points). His total score is 90+24+27+25+17+49= 232. This corresponds to about a 15% probability of success. The doctor and his patient probably would not consider this SRT treatment, given the risk of adverse side effects. Now, let’s suppose the same man is treated earlier when his PSA is only 0.05 ng/ml (2.5 points) and his radiation oncologist proposes a dose of 70 Gy (=0 points) with ADT beginning two months before SRT (=0 points). His total score is 90+24+27+2.5+0+0= 143.5. This corresponds to about a 55% probability of success. This SRT treatment is a lot more tempting. Because of database limitations, they could not incorporate PSA doubling time or increases in their model. They also could not include the duration of ADT use or more precise radiation dosage. With more data, a genomic classifier (Decipher) also might improve the predictive accuracy of their model. Together with other factors like co-morbidities, risk of adverse effects and life expectancy, this nomogram should prove useful in helping the patient and doctor decide whether SRT is worthwhile. Note: Thanks to Dr. Rahul Tendulkar for providing me with the full text of his original article. Posted by Allen Edel at 5:56 PM Print Friendly and PDF Email This BlogThis! Share to Twitter Share to Facebook Share to Pinterest

Posts.Title: New PSA Results & A Little Confusion About Stuff

Posts.Content: Big: I think u are over thinking all this. Your pathology report is not all bad. For now, your PSA is ZERO! The SK nonogram is just that, a nonogram. It gives you the range of statistics of men who have been treated with your pathology. Not saying it isn't somewhat reliable, but you are a person. All of us are different, you can't be making hard and fast conclusions based upon a nomogram. They are prediction tools designed to help a patient understand what may or may not be in front of them. "Maybe I am not understanding the technical aspects but how can there be any pertinent data on SRT that is done without any indications of a bio-chemical recurrence as the the wild card is that there is none, there-fore it worked" THe SRT nonogram is based on people who have had a recurrence, and what the odds are of it being treated with success. ( based on your risk factors). For now, just take it easy. You are doing fine, don't borrow any trouble. Based on your pathology, IF additional treatment were necessary, your chances of it being a local disease are high. Especially with the PM, that argues well for a cure. Best of luck, MM

Posts.Title: Just had the Prostate Ultrasound and Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello All: Just wanted to say thank u to all the folks on this site who take their time to help myself and others. The procedure went well and was rather painless. A touch uncomfortable here and there, but for the most part It went easy and I did not feel any pain. One thing the uro did say was that she felt my prostate was enlarged. ( she had told me a week ago that the DRE felt normal, with the exception of that nodule on the side) She did biopsy the nodule and commented it looked to be of the benign type she has seen many times before. I guess after the ultrasound/biopsy her opinion has changed and the prostate is enlarged. Anyway, the waiting game begins. Any comments, thoughts, please feel free. Thanks again for the support I have received, u all have been great. regards, John

Posts.Title: Just had the Prostate Ultrasound and Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hello Dave and Barb: To answer your questions. Yes, your continence will probably be "frozen" about where it is at the time that u go in for ART. If u can put it off for say 3-6 months, perhaps u can go into the RT with a good sense of where u are. One option would be to track his PSA using the uPSA, and try and get/buy as much time as u can. If u have HT with the radiation, which in your case is standard of care, this will stop the cancer from progressing and buy u time. Typically, u will be on ADT for 2 months prior to RT. Casodex/ lupron, etc. Honestly, they use the terms ADT/SRT like there is a big difference...I think it is more about when u begin in relation to your PSA. As far as ED, during RT the RO will be able to avoid the penile bulb, and perhaps his ED will improve over time. Tough to say for now...but with RT and ADT, sadly he will not even care. The good news: While your report is not the greatest, it isn't the end of the world either! You still have a chance at a cure, and if that is what u are most concerned about, leave no stone Unturned. As the saying goes...erections do u no good with your feet south of the grass. Wishing u and your husband the best, MM

Posts.Title: Surgery is done and at home

Posts.Content: I just had to post this. I received my Lupron shot on April 15. (7.5mg) 1 month's worth for starters. I look at my insurance online to make sure all is good. I have Coventry One, a division of Atena. UC hospitals billed the insurance company $7,469 for the Lupron. The nurse who gave me the shot billed $423. That's a total of $7892 for a 5 minute visit. Really? I used to think that the insurance company"s were a bunch of criminals. ( For the most part they are) Who the hell do these hospitals think they are to bill that sum? Guess what they got paid per their contract with Coventry? $266. So they bill $7892, but are willing to accept $266. So, for some poor soul who has no insurance, they walk in and are charged $7892. But, the insurance company pays $266 and the hospital is thrilled to accept. This system sucks!!

Posts.Title: Come on Man!!

Posts.Content: Shu: I mean having the the same prices ( 266 vs. 7892) for everyone. This poses a problem when it comes to cash pay patients, because patients are billed at the same high rates unless a cash price is previously negotiated. The "adjusted rate" or "negotiated rate" only applies to the insurance company.This information alone is proof that the prices of healthcare are not set. They are inflated and filled with erroneous charges. These "adjusted rates" are guarded like top level espionage. A doctors office will bill a insurance company and a unrelated person for the same service. The insurance company pays several times less. The patient faces financial ruin. This is even more of a problem for the self-insured, those of us who don't work for the post office, fire department, police or have company plans. If these people saw my health premiums and out-of-pocket costs over the years, they would faint. Nothing against any of those occupations. If I knew I could pay the lower price, I might be able to do the math and just self-insure. My RALP all in was close to 90,000. The UC hospitals received less than 20K. The "free market" does not seem to be working.

Posts.Title: Update on SRT + ADT

Posts.Content: At the 6 month mark, given what u have written, I would say u are doing very well. I would continue the sildenafil at least 3x weekly, (60mg to 100mg) and make sure when u use it that you are increasing blood flow by whatever means necessary. Since u are doing this well at 6 months, I would not take any other action. Pump and injections are not much fun, especially injections. They can be painful, and can lead to other SE that u don't even want to hear about. Give yourself some time. If u want, consult a ED specialist. Not your Uro/surgeon, they really don't do much in this space. For now, work on the leakage, and time may be your best bet. Best, MM

Posts.Title: Immediate or delayed ADT

Posts.Content: Hello MJ: Do yourself a favor and get the biopsy. It's not that bad. You can get a local jell, and then the uro can inject the prostate so that you will feel almost nothing. Don't be afraid to ask the Uro to give you the local anesthesia. Please forgive me for saying so, but many of the reasons you have cited sound like you are trying to convince yourself. You have more than one factor that gives me cause to pause. Of the 7 points you listed, only #4 really holds any water. The other six are seriously open for debate. The biopsy takes 15 minutes and to be honest, I have had worse trips to the dentist. This way you will know for sure, and can have a clear mind. Sleep at nite. Sorry, but most of the things you have said I could make a compelling case for the opposite. Don't wait or ignore this. Just one man's thoughts. Best wishes, MM

Age.Phrase: digits  if it is indeed 40  that to me is a

PatientDecided.Sample: I guess what I am saying is you may end up having to have radiation and end up in the same place if you just would have started radiation in the first place. Had I have known this in my situation, I may have choose some sort of brachytherapy/ ADT and not had the additional issues associated with surgery....It all depends on when those cancer cells come out of hibernation and decide to replicate, at which time the "time bomb" implanted by the radiation will kill them." To be clear, these are not my words....Now that he has PM, if he does end up having radiation, make sure the plan covers the prostate bed and local lymph nodes, known as a "boost". Get them all done at once....Because of database limitations, they could not incorporate PSA doubling time or increases in their model. They also could not include the duration of ADT use or more precise radiation dosage....Having a chance to do it over, I may have chosen a different route. Best, MM https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...-or-ebrt-only/...The case to which you refer was G7 (3+4) so maybe that's why. Now that he has PM, if he does end up having radiation, make sure the plan covers the prostate bed and local lymph nodes, known as a "boost"....Had I have known this in my situation, I may have choose some sort of brachytherapy/ ADT and not had the additional issues associated with surgery. I don't know, tough call....At about the 2 month mark after radiation, the RO will test the PSA to begin a new baseline number. What the RO should be looking for is for the PSA to remain stable or go down....My RO has a standard line of "let's wait another 3 months and see what happens." It all depends on when those cancer cells come out of hibernation and decide to replicate, at which time the "time bomb" implanted by the radiation will kill them."...If you need to go through what men like you and I have/will, I would choose the radiation path. Both surgery and radiation will "de-bulk"the tumor....Steve: I did do the research on EBRT ( IMRT/ IGRT) when I was making my decision. I don't remember anyone on here using SBRT as a primary treatment....Steve: I did do the research on EBRT ( IMRT/ IGRT) when I was making my decision....If your intention is to give yourself the best chance at a cure, you may want to reconsider your decision. Above data is with RT, but I think I have some files as it pertains to surgery....
